"{{c1::Fibrous dysplasia::Musculoskeletal condition?}} has an ""<b>alphabet soup</b>"" trabeculae appearance on histology"	"<div><div>""alphabet soup""; fibroblasts surrounding islands of osteoid; no osteoblastic rimming&nbsp;</div><br><img src=""paste-3818225926486.jpg"" class=""resizer""></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::FibrousDysplasia"
What are the <i>contraindications</i> (2) to <b>RSA</b>?<div><br></div><div>1) {{c1::Axillary nerve dysfunction}}</div><div>2) {{c1::Acromion deficiency}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-14 at 9.35.33 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-14 at 9.36.11 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::AdultReconstruction::ReverseShoulder"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Average adult <b>femoral neck shaft angle</b> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::135°}}"	"<img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>femoral neck shaft angle</b> can be measured by placing <b>one line</b> down the <b>center</b> of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::femoral shaft}}</b>&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">and a <b>second</b> line down the <b>center</b> of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::femoral neck}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.&nbsp; &nbsp;</span>"	"Average is <b>130 degrees +/- 7</b><br><img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<b>{{c2::High}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;femoral neck shaft angle =<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::Valgus}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>Hip<br></span><div><b>{{c2::Low}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">femoral neck shaft angle =&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Varus}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;Hip</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The amount of <b>varus</b> or <b>valgus</b> can also be measured by placing a point at the <b>center of the femoral head</b> (representing the <b>hip center</b>) and extending a line out to the<b> tip of the greater trochanter</b> (see picture).</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">Hip and Knee Book: Hip Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In a ""normal hip"" the <b>center of the femoral head </b>should be&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">at the&nbsp;</span>same level as}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;the tip of the <b>greater trochanter</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The amount of <b>varus</b> or <b>valgus</b> can also be measured by placing a point at the <b>center of the femoral head</b> (representing the <b>hip center</b>) and extending a line out to the<b> tip of the greater trochanter</b> (see picture).</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg"">"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In a <b>Varus</b> <b>hip</b>, the <b>center of the femoral head </b>is located&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::<font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)"">below</font></b><b>}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;the tip of the <b>greater trochanter</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The amount of <b>varus</b> or <b>valgus</b> can also be measured by placing a point at the <b>center of the femoral head</b> (representing the <b>hip center</b>) and extending a line out to the<b> tip of the greater trochanter</b> (see picture).</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg"">"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In a <b><i>Valgus</i></b> <b>hip</b>, the <b>center of the femoral head </b>is located&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::<font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)"">above</font></b><b>}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;the tip of the <b>greater trochanter</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The amount of <b>varus</b> or <b>valgus</b> can also be measured by placing a point at the <b>center of the femoral head</b> (representing the <b>hip center</b>) and extending a line out to the<b> tip of the greater trochanter</b> (see picture).</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg"">"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)"">The<b> femoral neck shaft angle</b> affects <b>forces across the hip</b> because it changes the&nbsp;</font>{{c1::tension of the abductor mechanism}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;A <b>valgus hip</b> results in improved <b>mechanical advantag</b>e to the<b> abductor</b> while a <b>varus hip </b>generates <b>greater forces</b> across the hip center.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-72d21600d053aa800538de1a92d63fb6796a7b71.jpg""><br></div>"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Most <b>femoral</b> components of a <b>total hip replacement</b> rely on&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bony ingrowth}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;for long term fixation.&nbsp;</span>"								"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"			"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Bony ingrowth</b> occurs during the first&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6 weeks}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;after a <b>THA</b></span>"											"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Similar to the fracture healing, <b>THA bony ingrowth</b> requires <b>micromotion &lt;</b>&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::50 nm}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;for<b> ingrowth</b> to occur, otherwise,<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::fibrous ingrowth}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;occurs.</span>"	"Fibrous ingrowth increases<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;risk for <b>persistent motion, early loosening</b> and symptoms of<b> thigh pain</b>.&nbsp;</span>"							"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"			"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">For proper <b>THA ingrowth</b> to occur, the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::press-fit}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>must be obtained at the <b>time of surgery</b> - the implant must <b>fill </b>the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::proximal canal}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>and place enough&nbsp;</span>{{c1::hoop stress}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;on the <b>rim</b> of <b>cortical bone</b> to <b>prevent micromotion</b>.</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Both<b> axial</b> (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and <b>torsional</b> (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) <b>stability</b> are required for <b>initial stem fixation</b>.</span>"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"

"<b><u>THA</u></b><div><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>Dorr Classification</b> describes the relationship of the <b>diameter</b> of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::proximal femoral canal}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;relative to the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::femoral diaphysis}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.</span><br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Calculated by measuring the <b>ratio </b>between the <b>canal width</b> at<b> lesser trochanter</b> and the<b> c</b>anal width <b>10 cm below the lesser troch</b>.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">It actually measures the<b> relative thickness of the cortex</b> by calculating the difference between the<b> full diameter of the bone</b> compared to the <b>diameter of the canal alone</b> (see diagram).</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"							"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches""><font color=""#000000"">ANATOMY</font></a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"			"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
"<b><u>DORR CLASSIFICATION</u></b><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE&nbsp;</strong><b>{{c2::A}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;femurs have a <b>thick cortex</b> and <b>narrow canal</b> (referred to as a “<b>champagne flute</b>”) and commonly found in <b>men</b> and<b> younger patients</b>.&nbsp; It permits <b>good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture</b>, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the <b>metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch</b>. A&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::single wedge stem}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>design is often used.&nbsp;</span><br></div>"	"<div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""><br></div>"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"
<b><u>DORR CLASSIFICATION</u></b><div><b><u><br></u></b><div><div><b>TYPE&nbsp;</b>{{c1::B}} femurs demonstrate some&nbsp;<b>medial</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>posterior cortex bone loss</b>, and therefore a&nbsp;<b>wider canal</b>, and are an intermediary between Type {{c1::A}} and {{c1::C}}.</div></div></div>	"<div>Most femurs are a type B</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""><br></div>"	"<h1><a href=""https://hipandkneebook.com/tha-chapters/2017/3/1/basic-hip-approaches"">ANATOMY</a></h1><div><div></div><div><br></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><img src=""varus+hip+valgus+hip+on+X-ray+how+to+determine+hip+angle.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div>Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135, but this is only an average. The neck angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.</div><div><br></div><div>A high neck angle is a Valgus Hip,&nbsp; a low neck angle is a Varus hip. &nbsp;The amount of varus or valgus can also be measured by placing a point at the center of the femoral head (representing the hip center) and extending a line out to the tip of the greater trochanter (see picture). &nbsp;In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter, while a Varus Hip the center of the femoral head lies below the tip of the greater troch, and a Valgus Hip the center of the femoral head lies above the tip of the greater troch.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Importantly the neck angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism. &nbsp;A valgus hip results in improved mechanical advantage to the abductor while a varus hip generates greater forces across the hip center. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation. &nbsp;Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA, and similar to the fracture healing, it requires micromotion &lt; 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs and there is increased risk for persistent motion, early loosening and symptoms of thigh pain. &nbsp;Thus, for proper ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion. &nbsp;Both axial (the stem doesnt sink into the femoral canal) and torsional (the stem cannot rotate within the canal) stability are required for initial stem fixation.</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal. &nbsp;The challenge is the variability of proximal femur anatomy within the population. &nbsp;The&nbsp;<strong>Dorr Classification</strong>&nbsp;is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the emoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index. &nbsp;This can help with surgical planning to select a stem that will maximize the ability of achieving a press-fit during surgery. In general, as we get older, we lose bone stock, and the metaphyseal region of the proximal femoral canal becomes more and more capacious.&nbsp; This has implications on the ability to use a non-cemented/press-fit stem.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div></div><div>More specifically the Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis. &nbsp;Its calculated by measuring the ratio between the canal width at lesser trochanter and the canal width 10 cm below the lesser troch. &nbsp;It actually measures the relative thickness of the cortex by calculating the difference between the full diameter of the bone compared to the diameter of the canal alone (see diagram).</div></div></div><div><br></div><div><div><div><div><img src=""dorr+classification+type+on+xray.jpg""></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><strong>TYPE A</strong>&nbsp;femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.&nbsp; It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. &nbsp;A single wedge stem design is often used. &nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE B</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C. &nbsp;Most femurs are a Type B.</div><div><br></div><div><strong>TYPE C</strong>&nbsp;femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Anatomy"

<div><b><u>ANTERIOR APPROACH TO HIP</u></b></div><div><br></div>The <b>{{c1::Lateral Femoral Cutaneous}} nerve</b> reaches the <b>thigh</b> by passing over, behind, or through (<b>usually over</b>) the <b>{{c1::Sartorius}}</b> muscle, about <b>2.5 cm below</b> the <b>ASIS</b>. <div><b><u>ANTERIOR APPROACH TO HIP</u></b></div><div><br></div>The <b>sartorius</b>&nbsp;is retracted <b>{{c1::upward}} </b>and<b> {{c1::medially}} </b>and the <b>tensor fasciae latae</b> is retracted <b>{{c1::downward}} </b>and<b> {{c1::laterally}}</b>. <div><b><u>ANTERIOR APPROACH TO HIP</u></b></div><div><br></div>The <b>{{c1::Ascending}}</b> <b>branch</b> of the <b>{{c1::Lateral Femoral Circumflex}}</b> artery crosses the gap between the <b>sartorius </b>and <b>TFL </b>below the <b>ASIS </b>and must be <i><b>ligated or coagulated</b></i>. <b><u>ANTERIOR APPROACH TO HIP</u></b><div><br></div><div>If you are having difficulty ID'ing the plane b/w the <b>rectus femoris</b> and <b>gluteus medius</b>, palpate the {{c1::femoral}}<b>&nbsp;artery</b>.</div>	The femoral pulse is well medial to the intermuscular interval; if you dissect near it, you are out of plane. <b><u>ANTERIOR APPROACH TO HIP</u></b><div><br></div><div><b>DEEP:&nbsp;</b>The <b>{{c1::Rectus Femoris}}</b> is <b>detached</b> from <b>both</b> its <b>origins</b> and retracted <b>{{c2::medially}}</b>. <li>Posterior&nbsp;<a href=""https://radiopaedia.org/articles/acetabulum?lang=us"">acetabular</a>&nbsp;wall</li>
<li>Obturator foramen</li><li>Acetabular roof&nbsp;</li></ol>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
<div><b>{{c1::Shenton's}} Line</b> is a <b>congruent </b>line from the <b>{{c2::medial femoral neck}}</b> extending to the <b>superior</b> portion of the <b>{{c3::obturator foramen}}</b></div>	"<div><div>Interruption of the Shenton line can indicate:</div><div>-Developmental dysplasia of the hip <b>(DDH)</b></div><div>-<b>Fractured Neck</b> of Femur</div><div><br></div><div>See below Shenton's line in adults (1st XR) and children (2nd XR)</div><img src=""25a4d4b8ff12a2f1ab1e308aa19294_gallery.jpg""><img src=""fa8040edd14d62ac5ec5384d0363c7_gallery.jpg""><br><img src=""trochanter-acetabulum-radiology-shentons-hipxray-original.jpeg""><br><img src=""Radiograph-of-a-typical-patient-with-type-II-ON-of-the-left-hip-showing-a-valgus.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"The ""<b>{{c1::Spur}} Sign</b>"" is a radiographic finding seen on the <b>{{c2::obturator oblique}} view</b> that is pathognomonic for a <b>{{c3::both column acetabular}}</b> fracture"	"<div>The ""spur"" represents the&nbsp;<u><b>most caudal part</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>intact ilium</b></u>&nbsp;due to&nbsp;<b>medialization</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>articular components</b><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-05-04 at 9.25.15 AM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""XRAY - Obturator Oblique - Both column fx (emed).jpg""></div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"The ""<b>{{c1::gull}} sign</b>"" is a radiographic view of the <b>fractured&nbsp;{{c2::posterior wall}}&nbsp;of the pelvis</b> that resembles a <b>flying seagull</b>"	"<i>Can also be used to describe <b>superomedial dome impaction</b> seen in <b>elderly</b> patients<br><br>Seen on <b>ILIAC OBLIQUE VIEW</b><br></i><div><img src=""gullsign.jpg"" class=""resizer""><div><img src=""1-s2.0-S1877132718300289-gr9.jpg"" class=""resizer""></div></div><div><img src=""acetabular-48-638.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 539px;""><i><br></i></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"The ""{{c1::Throckmorton}} sign"" is seen when the<b> radiographic shadow of the penis</b> points<b> towards</b> the side of the fracture (<b>pelvis </b>or <b>hip</b>)"	"<img src=""DKvPLDyUMAAX9-b.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"

What <b>scoring system</b> can be used in evaluating patients who may have <b>necrotizing fasciitis</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::LRINEC}}<br></div>	"""Laboratory Risk Indicator for Necrotizing Fasciitis""<div><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-05-06 at 7.38.40 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 192.438px;""></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::Infections"
What 6 laboratory markers are needed to calculate the<b> LRINEC</b> score?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>CRP</b>&nbsp;≥ 150 (4 points)}}</div><div>{{c2::<b>WBC</b>&nbsp;&lt;15 (0), 15-25 (1),&nbsp;&gt;25 (2)}}</div><div>{{c3::<b>Hemoglobin</b> &gt;13.5 (0), 11-13.5 (1), &lt;11 (2)}}</div><div>{{c4::<b>Sodium</b> &lt;135 (2 points)}}<br></div><div>{{c5::<b>Creatinine</b> &gt;1.41 (2 points)}}</div><div>{{c6::<b>Glucose</b> &gt;180 (1 point)}}</div>	"Laboratory Risk Indicator for Necrotizing Fasciitis<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-05-06 at 7.38.40 AM.png"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::Infections"
