What <b>bacteria</b> is associated with <b>orthopaedic infections</b> in<b> sickle cell </b>patients?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Salmonella}}<br></div>											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::Infections"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>Knee</b> is <b>more complex</b> than a <b>simple hinge</b> joint</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Motion</b> occurs not only in <b>flexion-extension</b>, but also involves&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::rotation}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">,</span><span style=""font-weight: bold; color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::pivot}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, and&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::gliding}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;movements</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">medial femoral condyle (</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">MFC)::LFC/MFC</span>}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the <b>knee&nbsp;</b>is <b>larger</b> and <b>more circular</b> – meaning a <b>uniform radius of curvature</b>.</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In contrast, the<b>&nbsp;</b></span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>lateral femoral condyle (</b></span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>LFC) is smaller </b>and the two condyles,&nbsp;<b>distal condyle</b> and <b>posterior condyle</b>,&nbsp;have <b>very different radii of curvature</b> to promotes <b>LFC motion</b> during knee <b>flexion</b>.</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""native+knee+kinematics+anatomic+differences+between+medial+femoral+condyle+and+lateral+femoral+condyle.png"" class=""resizer""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::lateral femoral condyle (LFC)::Lateral/Medial Femoral Condyle}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the <b>knee&nbsp;</b>is <b>smaller</b></span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The two condyles,&nbsp;distal condyle and posterior condyle,&nbsp;have very different radii of curvature to promote LFC motion during knee flexion</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""native+knee+kinematics+anatomic+differences+between+medial+femoral+condyle+and+lateral+femoral+condyle.png""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
<div><div><div>In the <b>{{c1::LFC::LFC/MFC}}</b>, the <b>distal condyle</b> and <b>posterior condyle</b> have <b>very different radii of curvature</b> to promote&nbsp;<b>{{c1::LFC}} motion </b>during knee flexion</div></div></div>	"<div><br></div><div><img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""native+knee+kinematics+anatomic+differences+between+medial+femoral+condyle+and+lateral+femoral+condyle.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::MFC::LFC/MFC}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;radius of curvature</b> is relatively<b> uniform </b>and so the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::MFC}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;remains <b>mostly stationary</b> during knee <b>f</b></span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>lexion</b></span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">while the LFC travels posteriorly on the tibia (</span><strong>posterior rollback</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">) due to the change in radius of curvature</span><div><img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""native+knee+kinematics+anatomic+differences+between+medial+femoral+condyle+and+lateral+femoral+condyle.png""><br></div><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">What is it called when the <b>LFC travels posteriorly</b> on the <b>tibia during flexion</b>&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">due to the <b>change in radius of curvature</b> in the <b>distal </b>and posterior condyles?</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::posterior rollback}}<br></div>"	"<div><img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""native+knee+kinematics+anatomic+differences+between+medial+femoral+condyle+and+lateral+femoral+condyle.png""><br></div>"	"<b>Posterior rollback</b>&nbsp;- as the&nbsp;<b>knee flexes</b>, the instant&nbsp;<b>center</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>rotation</b>&nbsp;on the&nbsp;<b>femur</b>&nbsp;moves&nbsp;<b>posteriorly</b><br><br><img src=""rollback.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>difference</b> in <b>posterior rollback</b> between the <b>LFC</b> and <b>MFC</b> (<b>LFC rolls back</b> while the<b> MFC remains relatively in place</b>) drives the <b>distal femur </b>to&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::externally::externally/internally}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;rotate</span></b>"	"<img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg"">"	"<b>Posterior rollback</b>&nbsp;- as the&nbsp;<b>knee flexes</b>, the instant&nbsp;<b>center</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>rotation</b>&nbsp;on the&nbsp;<b>femur</b>&nbsp;moves&nbsp;<b>posteriorly</b><br><br><img src=""rollback.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The majority of <b>external rotation </b>of the <b>femur&nbsp;</b>occurs in the first&nbsp;</span>{{c1::15::#}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">° of <b>knee flexion.&nbsp;</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">This contributes to patellar tracking because at 15° of knee flexion the<b> patella engages the trochlear groove</b> and this is the stress point where the patella needs to be centrally located to prevent lateral dislocation or subluxation</span><br></div><div><img src=""d65e78c3fa0b4658a672e856dda52ea5.aspx""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg"">"	"<b>Posterior rollback</b>&nbsp;- as the&nbsp;<b>knee flexes</b>, the instant&nbsp;<b>center</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>rotation</b>&nbsp;on the&nbsp;<b>femur</b>&nbsp;moves&nbsp;<b>posteriorly</b><br><br><img src=""rollback.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
At how many <b>degrees of flexion</b> does the <b>patella engage</b> the <b>trochlear groove</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::15 degrees}}</div>	"<div>This is the stress point where the patella needs to be centrally located to prevent lateral dislocation or subluxation<br><br></div><div><div>So as the femur flexes, it externally rotates about 15° in relation to the tibia and thus the trochlear groove moves a little laterally to help with patellar tracking</div><br></div><div><img src=""d65e78c3fa0b4658a672e856dda52ea5.aspx""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
<div>As the <b>femur flexes</b>, it <b>externally rotates</b> about <b>15°</b> in <b>relation</b> to the <b>tibia</b> and thus the <b>trochlear groove moves</b> a little {{c1::laterally::medially/laterally}} to <b>help</b> with <b>patellar tracking</b></div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Patellar maltracking can occur if the femur doesn’t rotate or if there is insufficient medial structures (specifically the medial patellofemoral ligament) acting as a harness to guide the patella, or a hypoplastic trochlear groove can also lead to patellar subluxation by failing to provide a bumper to guide tracking.&nbsp;</span><br></div><img src=""d65e78c3fa0b4658a672e856dda52ea5.aspx"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Patellar maltracking </b>can occur if the <b>femur doesn’t rotate during flexion</b> or if there is <b>insufficient medial structures</b> (specifically the<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::medial patellofemoral}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;ligament</b>) acting as a <b>harness </b>to <b>guide </b>the <b>patella</b></span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">a <b>hypoplastic trochlear groove</b> can also lead to <b>patellar subluxatio</b>n by <b>failing</b> to <b>provide a bumper</b> to <b>guide tracking</b></span>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.54.35 PM.png""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.54.48 PM.png""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.54.59 PM.png"">"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">A <b>hypoplastic&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::trochlear groove}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;can lead to <b>patellar subluxation</b> by <b>failing to provide a bumper</b> to <b>guide tracking</b></span>"	"<img src=""d65e78c3fa0b4658a672e856dda52ea5.aspx"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Posterior rollback</b> determines the point of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::terminal}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>flexion before impingement</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Rollback is essential to achieve full deep flexion</span><br></div><div><img src=""posterior+roll+back+in+a+knee.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""explaining+posterior+rollback+of+the+femur+diagram.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In many ways it’s the holy grail of TKA. Rollback is essential to achieve full deep flexion (which is seen with squatting or deep bends).&nbsp; Without rollback, the back of the femoral diaphysis will impinge on the tibia around 90°, however, if the distal femur moves posteriorly in relation to the tibia, it increases the clearance before impingment, and thus allows for extra flexion. Ultimately, impingement does occur (between the lateral tibia and the posterior cortex of the distal femur) and this marks terminal flexion. We talk more about the importance of rollback when discussing TKA designs (see link).</span>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>lateral tibial plateau</b> is&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">flat (or even slightly&nbsp;</span><em>convex</em><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">)::dished/flat</span>}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and is designed this way to <b>encourage LFC roll back</b> during <b>knee flexion</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In contrast the medial tibial plateau is dished (concave), allowing for less MFC rollback, and enabling a pivot type motion whereby the LFC rotates around the stable MFC</span><br></div><img src=""articular+geometry+of+the+knee+joint.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>medial tibial plateau</b> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::dished (concave)::dished/flat}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, allowing for<b> less MFC rollback</b>, and <b>enabling a pivot type motion</b> whereby the<b> LFC rotates</b> around the stable MFC</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In contrast, the lateral tibial plateau is flat (or even slightly&nbsp;</span><em>convex</em><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">) and is designed this way to encourage LFC roll back during knee flexion</span><br></div><div><img src=""articular+geometry+of+the+knee+joint.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
The {{c1::medial::lateral/medial}} compartment of the knee has <b>better articular congruence</b> and acts as the <b>pivot point of the knee</b>	"<br><div><img src=""articular+geometry+of+the+knee+joint.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
The <b>LFC</b>&nbsp;is <b>smaller</b>, with a <b>variable center of rotatio</b>n between <b>distal</b> and <b>posterior condyles</b> to&nbsp;<b>encourage&nbsp;</b><b>{{c2::</b><b>more motion}}</b>	"<div><img src=""articular+geometry+of+the+knee+joint.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<strong>Collateral Ligaments </strong>of the <b>knee</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;control&nbsp;</span>{{c1::coronal::coronal/sagital}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;plane stability</b></span>"	"<strong>Cruciate Ligaments:</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;provide stability in the sagittal plane</span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<strong>Cruciate Ligaments </strong>of the <b>knee</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;provide <b>stability</b> in the</span> {{c1::sagittal::coronal/sagital}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;plane</span>"	"<strong>Collateral Ligaments</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">: control coronal plane stability</span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The&nbsp;</span>{{c1::superficial::deep/superficial}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>MCL</b> is the <b>major medial stabilizer</b>,&nbsp;originating at the <b>medial epicondyle</b> and <u>traveling <b>deep</b> to the <b>pes</b> muscles</u> to insert broadly on the <b>tibia 4.5 cm distal </b>to the <b>joint line</b></span>"	"<br><div><img src=""paste-fe54c8dac57819887ad98c704b2adc50a2e56567.jpg""><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The deep MCL is only a thickening of the capsule (as known as the medial capsular ligament). The posterior-medial corner (posterior oblique ligament, semimembranosus, posterior horn medial meniscus) provide 30% of valgus restraint in full extension and with greater flexion the MCL assumes more responsibility. 60%&nbsp;in 5° flexion and 80% in 25° flexion.</span><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The&nbsp;</span>{{c1::deep::deep/superficial}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;MCL is only a thickening of the capsule (as known as the medial capsular ligament)</span><br></div><div><br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The posterior-medial corner (posterior oblique ligament, semimembranosus, posterior horn medial meniscus) provide 30% of valgus restraint in full extension and with greater flexion the MCL assumes more responsibility. 60%&nbsp;in 5° flexion and 80% in 25° flexion.</span><br></div><img src=""paste-fe54c8dac57819887ad98c704b2adc50a2e56567.jpg""><div><br></div><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>MCL</b> assumes more <b>valgus restraint</b> in knee&nbsp;</span>{{c1::flexion::extension/flexion}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">MCL -&gt; <b>60%</b> of valgus restraint in <b>5° </b>flexion and <b>80%</b> in <b>25°</b> flexion</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>posterior-medial corner (posterior oblique ligament, semimembranosus, posterior horn medial meniscus)</b> provide 30% of valgus restraint in <b>full extension</b></span><br></div><img src=""paste-fe54c8dac57819887ad98c704b2adc50a2e56567.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>LCL (""fibular collateral ligament"")</b> provides lateral stability,&nbsp;originating&nbsp;</span>{{c1::proximal::distal/proximal}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior::anterior/posterior}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;to the <b>lateral epicondyle</b> and <u>inserts on</u> the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::lateral fibular head}}"	"<br><div><img src=""251artMain.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The anterior cruciate ligament (<b>ACL</b>) <b>prevents anterior subluxation </b>of the<b> tibia</b>, particularly <b>near terminal extension</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>ACL</b> is <b>taut</b> around&nbsp;</span>{{c1::15::#}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">° of <b>flexion</b>, which corresponds to the region where your <b>quad </b>has the <b>worst mechanical advantage </b>to <b>extend the leg</b>, and thus exerts the <b>greatest anterior directed force</b> on the <b>proximal tibia.&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In <b>ACL-deficient</b> knee, <b>full extension </b>causes the <b>femur</b> to<b>&nbsp;</b>be <b>shifted posteriorly</b> due to <b>un-resisted anterior pull</b> on the <b>tibia</b></span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Cartilage wear</b> occurs in the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::anterior-medial}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;aspect of the <b>tibia</b> when the <b>ACL</b> is&nbsp;</span>{{c2::intact::injured/intact}}"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>ACL function changes the location</b> of cartilage wear.&nbsp; Wear occurs in the <b>anterior-medial </b>aspect of the knee when the ACL is <b>intact</b>, however if the ACL is <b>deficient</b>, the t<b>ibia translates forward</b>, and <b>cartilage wear occurs</b> in the<b> posterior-medial</b> aspect of the knee. Its important to <b>recognize wear-pattern differences when considering UKA.</b></span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Cartilage wear</b> occurs in the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::posterior-medial}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;aspect of the <b>knee </b>when the<b> ACL</b> is&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::injured::injured/intact}}</b>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">ACL function changes the location of cartilage wear. Wear occurs in the anterior-medial aspect of the knee when the ACL is intact, however if the ACL is deficient, the tibia translates forward, and cartilage wear occurs in the posterior-medial aspect of the knee. Its important to recognize wear-pattern differences when considering UKA.</span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">If the <b>tibia subluxes posteriorly</b> as seen in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::PCL::ACL/PCL}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;injury, the <b>femur</b> is <b>unable</b> to achieve <b>proper posterior rollback</b>, which is essential for achieving <b>terminal flexion</b></span></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">PCL prevents posterior subluxation of the tibia</span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>menisci</b> improve <b>joint congruity</b> by <b>smoothing</b> out the difference between <b>relatively round femoral condyles</b> and <b>flat tibial plateaus</b>.</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>menisci increase</b> the <b>effective joint surface</b> (a complete meniscectomy <b>reduces</b> the <b>contact area</b> by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::50::#}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">%), which <b>reduces contact forces</b>.</span></div>"											"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Menisci </b>transmit&nbsp;</span>{{c1::50}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">% of the load in <b>extension</b> and&nbsp;</span>{{c2::90}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">% in<b> flexion</b> by transferring <b>axial load</b> into <b>hoop stress</b></span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Hoop stress is <b>circumferential stress</b><br>Complete meniscectomy increases joint forces by 2-3x, with 20% of people developing significant arthritis in just 3 years, and 100% of people develop significant arthritis by 20 years.&nbsp;</span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Complete meniscectomy</b> increases joint forces by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2-3}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">x,&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div>{{c2::20}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">% of people developing significant arthritis in just 3 years</span></div><div>{{c3::100}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">% of people develop significant arthritis by 20 years</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The menisci improve joint congruity by smoothing out the difference between relatively round femoral condyles and flat tibial plateaus. The <b>menisci increase the effective joint surface</b> (a<b> complete meniscectomy reduces the contact area by 50%</b>), which <b>reduces contact forces</b>.&nbsp;&nbsp;Menisci<b> transmit 50% of the load in extension and 90% in flexion</b> by transferring <b>axial load</b> into <b>hoop stress</b>. &nbsp;Complete meniscectomy increases joint forces by 2-3x, with 20% of people developing significant arthritis in just 3 years, and 100% of people develop significant arthritis by 20 years.&nbsp;</span><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Over time, the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::posterior::anterior/posterior}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;horn </b>of the <b>medial meniscus</b> becomes <b>degenerated</b> in people without a(n)&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::ACL}}</b>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The medial meniscus is relatively stationary,&nbsp;similar to the MFC, and the posterior horn of the medial meniscus can act as an A-to-P stabilizer, and is particular important where the ACL is absent</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""meniscus-posterior-horn.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<strong>The Quad</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is the knee extensor and <b>weakness/atrophy</b> affects<b> patellar&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::tracking}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and is associated with <b>patellofemoral pain</b></span>"											"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
What muscle unlocks the knee as it begins to flex?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::popliteus, by enabling posterior rollback of the LFC}}</div>	"<div>It's a <b>posterior muscle</b>, that <b>crosses</b> the <b>knee</b> from the <b>medial tibia</b> to the <b>lateral femur</b>, the <b>tendonous</b> portion becomes <b>intraarticular</b>,&nbsp;runs just <b>behind</b> the <b>lateral meniscus</b>, and inserts at the <b>lateral femoral condyle </b>(<b>anterior</b> and <b>distal </b>to the <b>epicondyle</b>)<br></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Langford_illo1.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><b>Posterior rollback</b> - as the <b>knee flexes</b>, the instant <b>center</b> of <b>rotation</b> on the <b>femur</b> moves <b>posteriorly</b><br><br><img src=""rollback.jpg""><br></div>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>Mechanical Axis of the leg</b> is a line drawn from the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::center of the hip}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>to the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::center of the ankle}}</b><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">This line should <b>cross</b> through the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::center}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the knee, meaning the knee has <u>neutral alignment</u></span></div>"	"<img src=""anatomic+axis+of+the+leg+alignment+of+native+knee+joint.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>anatomic axis</b> is the <u>center of the&nbsp;</u></span><u>bones</u><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;making up the leg, and the anatomic axis of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::femur::femur/tibia}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::6}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>°</b> from the <b>mechanical axis</b>&nbsp;</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>anatomic axis</b> of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::tibia::femur/tibia}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is <b>in-line</b> with the <b>mechanical axis</b></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Therefore the Knee Angle (referring to the Femoral-Tibial Angle: FTA) is 6° valgus (relative to the mechanical axis).</span><br></div><div><img src=""anatomic+axis+of+the+leg+alignment+of+native+knee+joint.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
The <b>knee angle</b> is also known as the {{c1::femoral-tibial}}<b> angle</b>	"<div>Therefore the Knee Angle is 6° valgus (relative to the mechanical axis)</div><img src=""anatomic+axis+of+the+leg+alignment+of+native+knee+joint.png""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>joint line of the knee</b> is variable person-to-person, however, on average it's in about<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::3}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>° </b>of<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c2::varus::valgus/varus}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;on the <b>tibial</b> side (relative to the <b>mechanical axis</b>)</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">While on the femoral side, the <b>femoral articular</b> surface is in <b>3°</b> of <b>valgus</b></span><br></div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg"" class=""resizer""><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>tibial articular surface</b> is in <b>3°</b>&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::varus::valgus/varus}}</b> to the <b>mechanical axis</b>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">On the femoral side, the femoral articular surface is in 3° of valgus</span><div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"	<br><br>									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">On the <b>femoral side</b> of the <b>knee</b>, the <b>femoral articular surface</b> is in <b>3°</b> of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::valgus::valgus/varus}}"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">On the tibial side, it means the tibial articular surface is in 3° varus</span><div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">On the <b>femoral side</b> of the knee joint, the <b>joint line</b> is in&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::9}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>°</b> of <u><b>valgus</b></u> relative to the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::ANATOMIC::anatomic/mechanical}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;axis&nbsp;</span></b>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Thats 6° from the femoral center to the mechanical axis and then 3° more from the mechanical axis to the line across the distal femoral condyle</span><br></div><div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">On the <b>tibial side</b> of the knee, the joint line is in&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::3}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>°</b> of<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c2::varus::valgus/varus}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;relative to <u>the anatomic axis</u></span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Thats 0° from the tibial center to the mechanical axis because these two are parallel, and then 3° from the mechanical axis to the tibial joint line</span><div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In a standard TKA, </span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::femoral cuts (all of them)::femoral cuts/tibia cut}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;get adjusted to line up with the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::tibial cut::femoral cuts/tibia cut}}"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Knee angles are simplified in TKA by<b> cutting the tibia perpendicula</b>r to the <b>mechanical/anatomic axis</b>, which is<b> 0°</b></span><div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg"" class=""resizer""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Knee angles </b>are simplified in <b>TKA</b> by <b>cutting</b> the <b>Tibia</b>&nbsp;<u>Perpendicular</u> to the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::mechanical/anatomic (both)::mechanical or anatomic}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;axis</b>, which is&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::0}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">°</span></b>"	"<div><div>All of the femoral cuts are then adjusted to line up with this tibial cut</div></div><img src=""mechanical+axis+compared+to+anatomic+axis+in+knee.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">A&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::varus::valgus/varus}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;knee (due to common medial sided DJD) will deviate&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::laterally::laterally/medially}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;with respect to the <b>mechanical axis</b>&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">due to narrowing of the medial compartment and gradual attenuation of the lateral soft tissue</span><br></div><img src=""leg+alignment+in+valgus+knee+and+varus+knee.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">A&nbsp;</span>{{c1::valgus}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;knee will deviate medially (the knock-kneed appearance on clinical exam)</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">due to narrowing of the lateral compartment and attenuation of the medical soft tissue</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></div><img src=""leg+alignment+in+valgus+knee+and+varus+knee.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Alignment"
<b><u>6 P's of Compartment Syndrome</u></b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Pain out of proportion (POOP), Pain with passive stretch, Paresthesias, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia}}<b><br></b></div>											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
The most sensitive finding for <b>compartment syndrome</b> on <b>physical exam</b> is {{c1::pain with passive stretch}}											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
The <b>2 compartments </b>of the <b>upper arm</b> are {{c1::Anterior}} and {{c1::Posterior}}	"<img src=""fascial-compartments-of-arm-5-638.jpg"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"

What are the <b>compartments </b>of the foot? (6)<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Medial, lateral, Central Superficial, Central Deep, Adductor, Interosseus (x4)}}<br></div></div>	"<img src=""compartment-syndrome-acute-chronic-anatomy-and-operation-29-638.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
In <b>adults</b>, {{c1::Closed Tibial Shaft Fractures}} are the most common cause of <b>acute compartment syndrome</b>											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
In <b>pediatric</b> patients, {{c1::Supracondylar Humeral}} <b>fractures</b> are the most common cause of <b>acute compartment syndrome</b>											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
Intra-compartmental pressures are suggestive of compartment syndrome:<div><br></div><div>- <b>{{c2::Absolute value}} <u>&gt;</u>&nbsp;{{c1::30}}</b> mmHg</div><div>- <b>{{c2::Delta P}} <u>&lt;</u>&nbsp;{{c1::30}}</b> mmHg</div>	Delta P = DBP (<b>pre-anesthesia</b>) - Compartment Pressure	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-05-19 at 5.28.17 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"									"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
In the setting of a <b>fracture</b>, <b>compartment pressure</b> should be measured within {{c1::5 cm}} of the <b>fracture site</b>								"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-05-19 at 5.28.17 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
Treatment for compartment syndrome is {{c1::emergent fasciotomy}}											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
"<div><u style=""font-weight: bold;""><b>Locations of Incisions for a 2-incision lower leg fasciotomy:</b></u><br></div><div><u style=""font-weight: bold;""><b><br></b></u></div><div>- {{c1::<b>Anterolateral</b>: Halfway between the <b>tibial crest</b> and <b>fibula</b>}}</div><div>- {{c2::<b>Medial</b>: Just <b>posterior</b> to the <b>posteromedial border</b> of the <b>tibia</b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""14642.myextj"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
