Which <b>compartment</b> is most commonly <b>inadequately released</b> in the <b>lower leg</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Deep Posterior}}<br></div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Musclecompartmentsoftheleg.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
What condition may occur following <b>missed compartment syndrome</b> of the <b>forearm</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Volkmann Ischemic Contracture}}<br></div>			"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-20 at 11.37.55 AM.png"">"								"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::CompartmentSyndrome"
<b>{{c1::Type A</b><b>}}</b><b>&nbsp;AO/OTA</b>&nbsp;Classification = <b>{{c2::Extraarticular}}</b> Fracture	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>Extraarticular—Type A</b>: The fracture line may be <b>metaphyseal</b> or
<b>epiphyseal</b>, but it always <b>spares the articular surface</b> although it may
be intracapsular.</div><div><br></div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-04-07 at 11.22.57 AM.png"" class=""resizer""></div>
</div>
</div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::AO_OTA_Classification"
<b>{{c1::Type B}} AO/OTA</b>&nbsp;Classification = <b>{{c2::Partial Articular}}</b> Fracture	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>Partial articular—Type B:</b> The fracture involves <b>part of the articular
surface</b> while the <b>remainder of the joint remains intact</b> and is <b>solidly
connected</b> to the supporting <b>metaphysis </b>and<b> diaphysis</b>.&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-04-07 at 11.22.57 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::AO_OTA_Classification"
<b>{{c1::Type C}} AO/OTA</b>&nbsp;Classification = <b>{{c2::Articular}}</b> Fracture	"<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-04-07 at 11.22.57 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::AO_OTA_Classification"
<b><u>Bone Numbering in the AO/OTA Classification:</u></b><div><b><u><br></u></b></div><div><b>1 - {{c1::Humerus}}</b></div><div><b>2 - {{c1::Radius / Ulna}}</b></div><div><b>3 - {{c2::Femur / Patella}}</b></div><div><b>4 - {{c2::Tibia / Fibula}}</b></div><div><b>5 - {{c3::Spine}}</b></div><div><b>6 - {{c3::Pelvis / Acetabulum}}</b></div><div><b>7 - {{c4::Hand}}</b></div><div><b>8 - {{c4::Foot}}</b></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-04-07 at 11.25.16 AM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::AO_OTA_Classification"
How is <b>fracture location</b> subclassified?<div><br></div><div>1 - {{c1::Proximal 1/3}}</div><div>2 - {{c1::Shaft}}</div><div>3 - {{c1::Distal 1/3}}</div>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Proximal end segment = 1&nbsp;</div><div>Diaphyseal segment = 2&nbsp;</div><div>Distal end segment = 3&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::AO_OTA_Classification"
How would you classify a <b>simple, extraarticular midshaft femur</b> fracture using the AO/OTA classification?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::32A}}</div>	<b>3 - Femur, 2 - Midshaft, A - Extraarticular</b>										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::AO_OTA_Classification"
What are the different types of nonunions? (4)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Atrophic, oligotrophic, hypertrophic, infectious}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-03 at 9.39.53 PM.png"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.23.46 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.27.11 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.27.48 AM.png"" class=""resizer"">"								"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Non-Unions"
What causes an <b>atrophic nonunion</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>Too stiff of a construct</b> (no motion)}} or <b>{{c2::metabolic disorders}}</b></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-03 at 9.39.53 PM.png"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.23.46 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.27.11 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.27.48 AM.png"">"							"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Non-Unions"
What causes a <b>hypertrophic nonunion</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Too much motion at the fracture site}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-91ad70dae5ffc4ddac8ebd8752674917360bc884.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""paste-fa77eb5808517d177058580cd4a9e5cef0fb79c6.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Non-Unions"
What labs should be ordered in the workup of a <b>non-union</b>?<div><br></div><div><b>Infectious</b>: {{c1::CBC w/ diff, ESR, CRP}}</div><div><b>Endocrine</b>: {{c2::Vitamin D, calcium, TSH, PTH}}</div>	"A <b>nonunion</b> is an <b>arrest </b>in the <b>fracture repair process -&nbsp;</b>progressive evidence of non-healing of a fracture of a bone<br><br><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/original/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_119/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_119_Fig1_HTML.gif"" class=""resizer"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.23.46 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.27.11 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-06-10 at 6.27.48 AM.png"" class=""resizer"">"								"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Non-Unions"
What is the classification for <b>soft tissue injuries</b> associated with <b>closed fractures</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Oestern and Tscherne}} Classification</div>	"<img src=""Oestern+and+Tscherne+classification+(Close+Fracture).jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Closed"
"<b style="""">Oestern </b>and<b style=""""> Tschern </b>Classification of&nbsp;<b>soft tissue injuries</b>&nbsp;associated with&nbsp;<b>closed fractures</b>:<div><b><u><br></u></b></div><div><b>Grade C0</b> = {{c1::<b>Negligible</b> soft tissue injury}}<br><b>Grade CI</b>&nbsp;= {{c2::<b>Superficial contusio</b>n or <b>abrasian</b> with a <b>simple fracture</b>}}<br><b>Grade CII</b>&nbsp;= {{c3::<b>Deeper</b> contusion or abrasion with <u><b>risk</b> of compartment syndrome</u>}}<br><b>Grade CIII</b>&nbsp;= {{c4::Significant <b>contusion</b>, <b>muscle destruction</b>, subcutaneous<b> degloving</b>, <b>compartment </b>syndrome, <b>nerve</b> or <b>vascular injury</b>}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""Oestern+and+Tscherne+classification+(Close+Fracture).jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Closed"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Appropriate placement of the <b>acetabular component</b> depends on 4 important things:</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">version</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">inclination</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">depth</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">height</span></div>}}<br></div>"	"<div><b>proper version</b> aka not anteverted / retroverted</div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png""><div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg""><br></div><div><div><div><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"The <u>goal of acetabular cup placement</u> is to <b style="""">match the implant's range of motion</b> to:<div><br></div><div>{{c1::the native hip's range of motion}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""native+hip+range+of+motion+falls+within+implant+permitted+range+of+motion.png""><br></div><div><img src=""overlap+of+native+hip+motion+and+implant+motion.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"{{c1::Impingement}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;in <b>THA&nbsp;</b>occurs when <b>our anatomy</b> wants to <b>move</b> the <b>hip beyond</b> what is <b>permitted</b> by the <b>orientation</b> of the <b>implant</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">For example, the architecture of our body is designed to allow the femur to adduct about 30 degrees, however, if the cup is not properly anteverted, neck of the implant will impinge on the cup at only 20 degrees</span><br></div><div><img src=""overlap+of+native+hip+motion+and+implant+motion.png""><img src=""native+hip+range+of+motion+falls+within+implant+permitted+range+of+motion.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">If <b>acetabular impingement</b> occurs with an <b>implant</b>, its like a car hitting a brick wall: motion comes to a halt, and the implant can:</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">1.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::dislocate}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">2.&nbsp;</span>{{c1::generate wear particles at an accelerated rate}}<br></div>"	"<div><img src=""overlap+of+native+hip+motion+and+implant+motion.png""><img src=""native+hip+range+of+motion+falls+within+implant+permitted+range+of+motion.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
<b>Version </b>is the <b>orientation</b> of <b>hip implants</b> in the {{c1::sagittal::axial/coronal/sagittal}} plane	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Neutral version</b> means the cup is facing <u>completely lateral</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Anteversion</b> means the cup is facing <u>slightly anteriorly</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Retroversion</b> means the cup is opening up <u>slightly posteriorly</u></span><br><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png""><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"{{c2::Neutral}}&nbsp;<b>version</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;means the cup is facing&nbsp;</span>{{c1::completely lateral}}"	"<div><font color=""#020011""><i style="""">i.e. completely in line with the sagittal plane</i></font></div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b><br></b></span></div><b>Neutral version</b> means the cup is facing <u>completely lateral</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Anteversion</b> means the cup is facing <u>slightly anteriorly</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Retroversion</b> means the cup is opening up <u>slightly posteriorly</u></span><br><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png""><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"{{c1::Ante}}<b>version</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;means the acetabular cup is facing&nbsp;</span>{{c2::slightly anteriorly}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">anteversion allows for <b>increased hip AD-duction</b></span></div><div><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></b></div><div><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Neutral version</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""> means the cup is facing </span><u style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">completely lateral</u><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Anteversion</b> means the cup is facing <u>slightly anteriorly</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Retroversion</b> means the cup is opening up <u>slightly posteriorly</u></span><br><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"{{c1::Retro}}<b>version</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;means the acetabular cup is opening up&nbsp;</span>{{c2::slightly posteriorly}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">This allows for <b>increased hip AB-duction</b>, but<b> less adduction</b>, and if the hip moves into <b>too much adduction</b> it will <b>impinge</b> on the <b>rim of the cup</b></span><br></div><div><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></b></div><div><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Neutral version</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""> means the cup is facing </span><u style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">completely lateral</u><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Anteversion</b> means the cup is facing <u>slightly anteriorly</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Retroversion</b> means the cup is opening up <u>slightly posteriorly</u></span><br><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"The <b>target acetablular cup version</b> is {{c2::slight anteversion}}<div><b><br></b></div><div><b>""safe zone"" </b>is between <b>{{c2::5}} </b>and<b> {{c2::25}}</b> degrees to <b>match native hip motion</b> and <b>avoid impingement</b></div>"	"<div><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Neutral version</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""> means the cup is facing </span><u style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">completely lateral</u><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Anteversion</b> means the cup is facing <u>slightly anteriorly</u></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Retroversion</b> means the cup is opening up <u>slightly posteriorly</u></span><br><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png""><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Acetabular cup version</b> can be assessed <b>postoperatively</b> by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::cross leg lateral XR::Specific Imaging}}</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">i.e. a <b>frog-leg lateral</b> gives lateral view of femur, but an AP of the acetabulum</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""frog-leg beam.jpg"" class=""resizer""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The target Acetabular Cup version is slight Anteversion. There is a “safe zone” between 5° and 25° (ie 15° +/- 10°) to match native hip motion and avoid impingement.<br>&nbsp; &nbsp;</span><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png"" class=""resizer""></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"The femoral stem in axial plane should also be angled slightly {{c1::anterior}} at about {{c1::15}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">°</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The goal of <b>combined anteversion</b> is 35° (+/- 10°)</span><div><img src=""tha+cup+anteversion+compared+to+femoral+stem+anteversion.jpg""><font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Studies demonstrate that maximal range of motion before impingement occurs when the acetabular components are placed within this “safe-zone” which corresponds to the the native acetabular positioning within the pelvis</span><br></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The goal angle of&nbsp;</span><b>combined hip anteversion</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;in <b>THA&nbsp;</b>is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::35° (+/- 10°)}}"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Combined hip anteversion</b> = cup version + stem version</span></div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>The stem version should be angled slightly forward (anterior), about 15°</span><br><div><img src=""tha+cup+anteversion+compared+to+femoral+stem+anteversion.jpg""><font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)""><br></font><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Studies demonstrate that maximal range of motion before impingement occurs when the acetabular components are placed within this “safe-zone” which corresponds to the the native acetabular positioning within the pelvis</span><br></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>True version of pelvis</b> is angle between:<br><br></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">a)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the line from the posterior to anterior wall of acetabulum (essentially the ilioischial line)}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">b)&nbsp;</span>{{c1::a line directly from A to P (this is the alpha angle)}}</div>"	"<div><font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)"">pretend the far right image was a native hip - the cup version would be the true version of the pelvis</font></div><div><img src=""tha+cup+anteversion+compared+to+femoral+stem+anteversion.jpg""></div><div><img src=""Iliopectineal_line,_ilioischial_line,_tear_drop,_acetabular_fossa,_and_anterior_and_posterior_wall_of_the_acetabulu.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The expectation for <b>hip ROM after THA</b> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::110}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>° flexion</b> and&nbsp;</span>{{c1::30}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>° extension</b></span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Increasing </b>the acetabular <b>anteversion</b> increases the <b>flexion</b> (<b>decreases extension</b>)</span><br></div><div><img src=""tha+cup+anteversion+compared+to+femoral+stem+anteversion.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div><div><img src=""Iliopectineal_line,_ilioischial_line,_tear_drop,_acetabular_fossa,_and_anterior_and_posterior_wall_of_the_acetabulu.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Increasing</b> the acetabular&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::anteversion::anteversion/retroversion}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>in <b>THA increases </b>the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::flexion::extension/flexion}}</b></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The expectation for hip ROM after THA is 110 ° flexion and 30 ° extension</span><br></div><div><img src=""tha+cup+anteversion+compared+to+femoral+stem+anteversion.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""Iliopectineal_line,_ilioischial_line,_tear_drop,_acetabular_fossa,_and_anterior_and_posterior_wall_of_the_acetabulu.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
<b>Inclination </b>in<b> THA</b> is the orientation of <u>the acetabular cup</u> in the {{c1::coronal::axial/coronal/sagittal}} plane	"<div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>target acetabular cup inclination</b> is a ""<b>safe zone</b>""&nbsp;between&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::30-50}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>° abduction</b> (assessed by AP of hip)</span>"	"<div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg""><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Below is a&nbsp;<b>vertically oriented</b>&nbsp;acetabular cup, can cause recurrent dislocations<br></span><img class=""resizer"" src=""blinded pelvis.jpg"" style=""width: 1000px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""></span>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<b style="""">Excessive inclination (a vertically oriented acetabular cup)</b>&nbsp;in <b style="""">THA</b>&nbsp;{{c1::decreases::decreases/increases}}&nbsp;the <b>surface area of articulation</b> along the&nbsp;{{c1::superior dome}}&nbsp;of the <b style="""">cup&nbsp;</b>"	"<div>and therefore<b style=""""> increases contact forces </b>causing<b style=""""> higher wear rates</b> (known as <b style="""">edge loading</b>)<br></div><div><br>Below is a <b>vertically oriented</b> acetabular cup, can cause recurrent dislocations<br><img src=""blinded pelvis.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1000px;""><br><br></div><div><b>safe zone</b> is <b>30-50</b><b>° abduction</b> (assessed by <b>AP of hip</b>)</div><div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Insufficient inclination (a horizontal acetabular cup)</b> decreases&nbsp;</span>{{c1::range of motion}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, but is generally considered <b>less problematic</b> than <b>too much</b> inclination</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Insufficient</b> inclination = risks <b>impingement </b>with <b>hip abduction</b></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Excessive</b> inclination (vertically oriented cup) = <b>edge loading</b>, higher rates of <b>wear</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)""><b>safe zone </b>is <b>30-50</b></font><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>° abduction</b> (assessed by AP of hip)</span></div><div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Below is a&nbsp;<b>vertically oriented</b>&nbsp;acetabular cup, can cause recurrent dislocations<br></span><img class=""resizer"" src=""blinded pelvis.jpg"" style=""width: 1000px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""></span>"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Target acetabular cup depth</b>&nbsp;in THA is to<b> recreate </b>the <b>anatomic hip center</b> for that patient by <b>reaming</b> to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::bleeding cancellous}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;bone</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Assessed by <b>AP of hip</b>: <b>cup</b> should be <b>up to</b>, but <b>not past</b>&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Kohler’s line, aka ilioischial line}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""Cortical-Cancellous-Bone-Adapted-from-41-and-42.png""><img src=""Iliopectineal_line,_ilioischial_line,_tear_drop,_acetabular_fossa,_and_anterior_and_posterior_wall_of_the_acetabulu.jpg""><br></div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><u>Over medializing depth</u> of <b>the acetablular cup</b> removes excess bone (always preserve bone, “A.P.B”, is a mantra for TJA surgeons)</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">However, <b>failure to sufficiently medialize the cup</b> provides less surface area for&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::bony ingrowth}}</b></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-and the <b>cup does not reach </b>the<b> bleeding cancellous </b>bone that <b>promotes ingrowth</b>.</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-Target is to recreate the anatomic hip center for that patient by </span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">reaming to bleeding cancellous bone</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-c</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">up should be up to, but not past Kohler’s line, aka ilioischial line</span><br></div><div><img src=""Cortical-Cancellous-Bone-Adapted-from-41-and-42.png"" class=""resizer""><img src=""Iliopectineal_line,_ilioischial_line,_tear_drop,_acetabular_fossa,_and_anterior_and_posterior_wall_of_the_acetabulu.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">A&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lateralized::medialized/lateralized}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;hip center depth</b> <b>shortens</b> the “<b>abductor lever arm</b>” and thus requires the <b>abductors to work harder</b> to <b>counteract the body weight force</b> acting on the <b>hip</b></span>"	"<img src=""joint+reactive+forces+of+the+hip.jpg""><div></div><div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
<div><b>Inferior border of acetabular cup</b> should be at the “{{c1::tear drop}}”, assessed by AP of hip</div>	"<div></div><div><u>Clinical Correlate</u>: <b>A high hip center</b> (which is sometimes done intentionally in cases of DDH when there is poor native bone stock around the native acetabulum) affects the abductor muscle tension and increases the joint reactive forces&nbsp;&nbsp;<br></div><div><img src=""tha+cup+inclination.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::CupPlacement"
"<div>The normal <b>hip joint</b> is best understood as a Lever-Arm. The <b>hip center is the fulcrum</b> that sits between 2 opposing forces:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Lever arm <b>#1</b> is the <b>distance</b> from the <b>{{c1::hip center}}</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>{{c1::</b><b>center of body weight}}</b></div><div>Lever arm <b>#2</b> is the <b>{{c2::abductor mechanism}}</b>, which is distance from the <b>hip center</b> to the {{c2::<b>greater trochanter</b> (aka the <b>insertion</b> point of our <b>abductors</b>)}}</div>"	"<div><br></div><img src=""joint+reactive+forces+of+the+hip.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In a normal hip, the <b>body weight lever arm</b> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2.5}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;times <u><b>longer</b></u> than the <b>abductor level arm</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">which means that the <b>abductor force</b> must be&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2.5}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;times <u><b>stronger</b></u> than <b>body weight</b></span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>greater the body weight</b>, the <b>more force across the hip joint</b> by multiple factors.&nbsp; This is one theoretic <u>correlation between obesity and hip arthritis</u>.<br><br></span><img src=""joint+reactive+forces+of+the+hip.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 870px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Joint reactive forces</b> depend on the activity</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><u>Force of walking</u> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::2.5}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">x body weight</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><u>Force of jogging</u> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">x body weight</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><u>Force of running</u> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::8}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">x body weight</span></div>"	"<div><img src=""joint+reactive+forces+of+the+hip.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In <b>progressive hip degeneration</b>,&nbsp;the <b>head </b>begins to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::collapse}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">,&nbsp;the <b>neck</b>&nbsp;</span>{{c1::shortens::lengthens/shortens}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, and the <b>abductor</b> mechanism <b>loses</b>&nbsp;</span>{{c1::tension}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;causing <b><u>weakness and pain</u> </b>due to <b>increased joint reactive forces</b>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><img src=""joint+reactive+forces+of+the+hip.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
<div><div><div>Current techniques for <b>hip reconstruction</b> focus on restoring the <u><b>native anatomical</b> geometry</u> of the hip—<b>placing the acetabular component</b> in a {{c1::low::high/low}} and {{c1::medial::medial/lateral}} position to <b>restore the center of rotation</b></div><div><br>and<br><br></div><div>Selecting a<b> femoral stem</b> that will restore <b>offset</b> by <b>{{c1::maximizing::maximizing/minimizing}}</b> <b>tension </b>of the<b> abductors </b>and <b>leg length</b></div></div></div>	"<div><img src=""joint+reactive+forces+of+the+hip.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
The <b>lumbar spine</b> gains <b>{{c1::lordosis::lordosis/kyphosis}}</b> with<b> {{c2::standing::sitting/standing}}</b>	"<div>and the pelvis shifts to the center of the hip under the spine (pelvic inclination)</div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
When <b>standing</b>, the <b>lumbar&nbsp;</b>spine {{c1::gains::gains/loses}}&nbsp;<b>lordosis</b> and the <b>pelvis {{c1::decreases::increases/decreases}} tilt</b>	"<div><b>decreasing pelvic tilt</b> is <u>on the left</u>&nbsp;and CCW in this picture, and it moves the hip center&nbsp;<u>posteriorly</u> under the spine center (pelvic inclination)</div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
When <b>sitting</b>, the<b> lumbar</b> spine <b>{{c1::loses::gains/loses}} lordosis</b> and the <b>pelvis {{c1::increases::decreases/increases}} tilt</b>	"<div><b>decreasing pelvic tilt</b> is <u>on the right</u>&nbsp;and CW in this picture, and it moves the hip center&nbsp;<u>anteriorly</u> under the spine center</div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg"">&nbsp;<img alt=""Spinal curvatures and pelvic orientation are postural dependent ..."" src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kaja-Kastelic/publication/336210444/figure/fig1/AS:809504069410818@1570012218949/Spinal-curvatures-and-pelvic-orientation-are-postural-dependent-Compared-with-relaxed.ppm""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
<b>Pelvic tilt (PT)</b> and <b>sacral slope (SS)</b> are {{c1::dynamic::dynamic/static}} pelvic parameters&nbsp;	"<div>Pelvic tilt and sacral slope change with body position, but their sum represents the Pelvic Incidence, which is static (always the same number regardless of position).<br></div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
<b>{{c1::Pelvic Incidence}}</b> = <b>{{c2::Pelvic tilt}} + {{c2::Sacral Slope}}</b>	"<div>Pelvic tilt and sacral slope change with body position, but their sum represents the Pelvic Incidence, which is static (always the same number regardless of position)<br></div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
Of <b>sacral slope, pelvic incidence</b>, and <b>pelvic tilt</b>, which one(s) is/are a&nbsp;<b>static variable (stays the same regardless of position)</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pelvic Incidence}}</div>	"<div>Pelvic tilt and sacral slope change with body position, but their sum represents the Pelvic Incidence<br><br></div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<strong>Pelvic incidence (PI)</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is <b>static</b> and is the <b>main axis</b> of <b>sagittal balance </b>of the spine (ranges&nbsp;</span>{{c1::48}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">° -&nbsp;</span>{{c1::53}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">°). It is the angle between:</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Line <b>1</b>: <b>perpendicular</b> to&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<b>Sacral Promontory</b>, aka <b>superior plate</b> of <b>S1</b>}}</div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Line <b>2</b>: <b>center</b> of&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<b>sacral prominitory</b>}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;to <b>center</b> of&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::hip}}</b></div>"	"<div>Pelvic Tilt (dyanmic) + Sacral Slope (dynamic) = Pelvic Incidence (static)<br></div><div><img src=""The-Anterior-Pelvic-Surface-of-the-Sacrum.jpg""><br></div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-02 at 8.21.56 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"									"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<strong>Sacral slope (SS)</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is<b> dynamic</b> and is the <b>angle</b> of the <b>sacrum</b>.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Angle between:</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Line <b>1</b>: <b>line&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::parallel::parallel/perpendicular}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;to <b>sacral promontory</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Line <b>2</b>: </span><b>{{c1::horizontal reference}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;line</span></b></div>"	"<div>Pelvic Tilt (dyanmic) + Sacral Slope (dynamic) = Pelvic Incidence (static)<br></div><div><img src=""The-Anterior-Pelvic-Surface-of-the-Sacrum.jpg""><br></div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<strong>Pelvic Tilt (PT)</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is a dynamic angle of the pelvis. Angle between:</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Line 1: center of&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::sacral promontory}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;to center of&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::hip}}</b></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Line 2:&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::vertical reference}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;line</span></div>"	"<div><div>Pelvic Tilt (dyanmic) + Sacral Slope (dynamic) = Pelvic Incidence (static)<br></div><div><img src=""The-Anterior-Pelvic-Surface-of-the-Sacrum.jpg""></div></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">As the upper pelvis moves posterior, the pelvic tilt increases, therefore pelvic tilt can be thought of as the degree of pelvic extension.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">When the upper pelvis tilts forward (anterior flexion), there is less pelvic tilt. &nbsp;Pelvic tilt does not change after THA.&nbsp;With normal saggital balance (PI), the PT should be &lt; 22°</span><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">As the upper pelvis moves&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior::anterior/posterior}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, the <b>pelvic tilt increases</b>, therefore pelvic tilt can be thought of as the degree of <b>pelvic extension.</b></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg"" class=""resizer""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">When the upper pelvis tilts forward (anterior flexion), there is less pelvic tilt. &nbsp;Pelvic tilt does not change after THA.&nbsp;With normal saggital balance (PI), the PT should be &lt; 22°</span><br></div><div><br></div><div>Pelvic Tilt (dyanmic) + Sacral Slope (dynamic) = Pelvic Incidence (static)<br></div><div><img src=""The-Anterior-Pelvic-Surface-of-the-Sacrum.jpg""></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<div><div>When the&nbsp;<b>upper pelvis</b>&nbsp;tilts&nbsp;<b>{{c2::anterior::anterior/posterior}}</b>, there is&nbsp;<b>less pelvic tilt</b></div>
<div><br></div>
<div>Pelvic tilt <b>does not change</b> after <b>THA</b>.&nbsp;With <b>normal</b> sagittal balance (<b>PI</b>), the <b>PT</b> should be <b>&lt;&nbsp;{{c2::22}}</b>°</div></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg"" class=""resizer""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div>"	"<div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b> (dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) + <b>Sacral Slope </b>(dynamic) = <b>Pelvic Incidence</b> (static 48-53)<br></div><div><img src=""The-Anterior-Pelvic-Surface-of-the-Sacrum.jpg""></div></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The Sacral Slope (SS) and Pelvic Tilt (PT) change by the same amount in a normal flexible spine-sacrum to maintain the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Pelvic Incidence}}<br></div>"	"<div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b> (dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) + <b>Sacral Slope </b>(dynamic) = <b>Pelvic Incidence</b> (static 48-53)<br></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Sitting</b> after <b>THA</b> risks&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::posterior::anterior/posterior}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;dislocation </b>because of&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::anterior::anterior/posterior}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;impingement</b> as the <b>acetabulum</b> moves&nbsp;<b>anteriorly</b></span>"	"<div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b> (dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) + <b>Sacral Slope </b>(dynamic) = <b>Pelvic Incidence</b> (static 48-53)<br></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">A mobile&nbsp;</span>{{c1::lumbo-pelvic}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;segment is essential to <u>minimizing THA dislocation</u></span>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">However, Lumbar Fusion reduces lumbo-pelvic motion and risks THA dislocation.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The more lumbar segments fused, the less lumbo-pelvic flexibility and the higher the dislocation risk:</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">No fusion: 1.5% risk</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">1-2 levels: 2.7% risk</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">3-7 levels: 4.6% risk</span><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b> (dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) + <b>Sacral Slope </b>(dynamic) = <b>Pelvic Incidence</b> (static 48-53)<br></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"{{c1::Lumbar Fusion}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;reduces lumbo-pelvic motion and risks THA dislocation.&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The more lumbar segments fused, the less lumbo-pelvic flexibility and the higher the dislocation risk:</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">No fusion: 1.5% risk</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">1-2 levels: 2.7% risk</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">3-7 levels: 4.6% risk</span><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c18ce5c432ed182ef0e7c6f994ae0968217b0563.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b> (dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) + <b>Sacral Slope </b>(dynamic) = <b>Pelvic Incidence</b> (static 48-53)<br></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br></div></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Increasing Pelvic Tilt</b>&nbsp;increases Acetabular&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Anteversion::anteversion/retroversion}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-at a rate of <b>1.0° pelvic tilt to 0.7° of anteversion<br></b></span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-increasing the anteversion <b>prevents anterior impingement</b> (it's important to avoid anterior impingement bc it causes the femoral head to lever out posteriorly)</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b>&nbsp;(dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) +&nbsp;<b>Sacral Slope&nbsp;</b>(dynamic) =&nbsp;<b>Pelvic Incidence</b>&nbsp;(static 48-53)<br><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png"" class=""resizer""></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Increasing Pelvic Tilt</b> Increases <b>Acetabular Anteversion</b> (at a rate of <b>1.0° pelvic tilt</b> to <b>0.7° of anteversion</b>), preventing&nbsp;</span>{{c1::anterior::anterior/posterior}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;impingement, which is important to prevent&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior::anterior/posterior}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">dislocation</span>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-<b>increasing the anteversion</b> <u>prevents anterior impingement</u></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-important to avoid anterior impingement bc it causes the femoral head to lever out posteriorly</span><br></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><b>Pelvic Tilt</b>&nbsp;(dyanamic, should be &lt;22 degrees) +&nbsp;<b>Sacral Slope&nbsp;</b>(dynamic) =&nbsp;<b>Pelvic Incidence</b>&nbsp;(static 48-53)<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""pelvic+tilt+sacral+slope+and+pelvic+incidence.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""3-Figure4-1.png""></div><div><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Biomechanics"
The <b>direct anterior approach to THA</b> is minimally invasive because it is {{c1::muscle sparing}}	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">When defining the term “minimally invasive” its important to recognize that skin incision size is important, but its not the whole story. The amount of muscle stripping and reflection is probably more important to postoperative pain and speed of recovery. The DA utilizes native inter-nervous muscle planes to approach the hip leading to less muscle injury (in contrast to both anterior-lateral and posterior-lateral, which require greater degrees of muscle reflection)</span><br></div><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
<div>Multiple studies suggest that <b>Direct Anterior Approach</b>&nbsp;for <b>THA&nbsp;</b>leads to a(n) {{c1::early::early/late}} <b>recovery</b>.</div>	<div><b>Reduces immediate postop pain</b> and <b>systemic inflammation</b>. In comparison to the posterior or antero-lateral approach, the DA shows:</div><div><br></div><div>Improved postop pain scores</div><div>Reduced pain medication</div><div>Improved Function</div><div>Decreased length of stay</div><div>Greater discharge home</div>										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
<div>In comparison to the posterior or antero-lateral approach, the <b>Direct Anterior approach</b> shows:</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Improved::improved/worsened}} postop pain scores</div><div>{{c1::Decreased::increased/decreased}} pain medication</div><div>{{c1::Improved::improved/worsened}} Function</div><div>{{c1::Decreased::decreased/increased}} length of stay</div>	"<div>Greater discharge home<br></div><div><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">It is<b> unclear</b> how many <b>weeks postop</b> the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Direct Anterior}} <b>THA approach</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;offers <b>improved outcomes </b>compared to other approaches</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Functional outcomes </b>for this approach generally<b> diminish</b> after&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;weeks</span></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Some studies suggest the improvements last only 2 weeks</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, while others suggest 6 weeks</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, or 6 months to 1 year</span><br></div><div><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In the<b> Direct Anterior </b>THA approach, <u>lower dislocation rates</u> have been shown because the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::posterior capsule}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and <b>soft tissue</b> is <b>preserved</b></span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">this <b>protects</b> the hip during&nbsp;</span>{{c1::sitting::sitting/standing}};&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">where it <b>most susceptible</b> to<b> dislocation</b></span></div>"	"<div>Advantages of the <b>direct anterior</b> approach include <b>preservation</b> of the <b>abductor mechanism </b>and <b>decreased dislocation rates</b> compared to the <b>posterior </b>approach.<br><br><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
There is a(n)&nbsp;<b>{{c2::</b><b>increased</b><b>}}</b><b>&nbsp;</b>rate of <b>femur fracture</b> via the&nbsp;<b>Direct Anterior THA </b>approach	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The acetabulum is very accessible during the DA, however, the femur is less accessible.&nbsp; Broaching is a challenge, and the femur can be torqued or over tensioned to obtain exposure</span><br></div><div><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
"<div><b style="""">Direct Anterior THA Approach</b></div><div><br></div>Supine on a standard&nbsp;{{c1::radiolucent}}&nbsp;table or placed on a specialized table, such as the Hana Table.&nbsp;C-arm fluoroscopy is typically available<div><br></div><div>On a standard table the pubic symphysis is placed over&nbsp;{{c2::the break in the table}}, and a small bump is placed under the coccyx slightly off-center (closer to the operative side).</div>"	"<div><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
"<div><div><b>Direct Anterior THA Approach</b></div>
<div><br></div>
<div>During <b>femoral exposure</b>, a <b>femoral elevator</b> (<b>hook </b>that goes <b>posterior behind</b> the the <b>femur</b>) is fixed to the table and <b>pulls </b>the <b>proximal femur out</b> of the wound, while the table is “<b>opened</b>” <b>foot </b>of table <b>dropped </b>to&nbsp;<b>{{c1::45}}° </b>and the<b> bed </b>is&nbsp;<b>{{c2::15}}°</b> of <b>Trendelenburg</b></div></div>"	"<div>Advantages of the&nbsp;<b>direct anterior</b>&nbsp;approach include&nbsp;<b>preservation</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>abductor mechanism&nbsp;</b>and&nbsp;<b>decreased dislocation rates</b>&nbsp;compared to the&nbsp;<b>posterior&nbsp;</b>approach.<br><br><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br></div>"					"<a href=""https://www.vumedi.com/video/the-direct-anterior-approach/"">VuMedi: Direct Anterior (Modified Hueter) Approach to the Hip</a><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-02-22 at 9.12.39 PM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-02-22 at 9.13.09 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-02-22 at 9.13.30 PM.png""><br></div><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-02-22 at 9.13.48 PM.png""></div>"					"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Posterior Approach to THA gives excellent exposure to:</span><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div>{{c1::<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">the entire femur</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">the posterior wall</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">acetabulum&nbsp;</span></div>}}<br></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Gives excellent</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-exposure distally to access the entire femur</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-exposure proximally to access the posterior wall and acetabulum</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">When broaching the femur, the surgeon is in-line with the femoral shaft, giving excellent access and low risk for femoral cortex injury.</span><br></div><div><br><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
The <b>Posterior THA approach</b> has a {{c1::low::high/low}} risk for <b>Femoral Cortex injury</b>	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">When broaching the femur, the surgeon is in-line with the femoral shaft, giving excellent access and low risk for femoral cortex injury</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Gives excellent</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-exposure distally to access the entire femur</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">-exposure proximally to access the posterior wall and acetabulum</span></div><div><br><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">While <b>initial studies</b> suggested <u>increased risk of THA dislocation with the posterior approach</u>, what two surgical techniques significantly reduce dislocation risk?</span><div><br></div><div><div>{{c1::<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">a meticulous soft-tissue repair&nbsp;</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">larger femoral head</span></div>}}</div></div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">This helps make rates similar to other approaches (anterolateral and direct anterior).&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">However, hip precautions are recommended for posterior approach regardless of the quality of soft tissue repair. Precautions are not required for Direct Anterior approach.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Because hip instability is related to both patient factors (ie compliance) and surgical factors, patients are faced with additional risk factors for dislocation with the posterior approach (as compared with DA)</span><br></div><div><br><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
Hip precautions (for dislocation) are recommended for which THA approach?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::posterior approach (gold standard)}}</div>	"<div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Avoid&nbsp;</span>hip flexion, adduction, IR<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br><br>Hip precautions are recommended for posterior approach regardless of the quality of soft tissue repair and increased size of femoral head implant. Precautions are not required for Direct Anterior approach.</span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span></div><div><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Because hip instability is related to both patient factors (ie compliance) and surgical factors, patients are faced with additional risk factors for dislocation with the posterior approach (as compared with DA).</span><br></div><div><br><img src=""approaches+to+the+hip+for+tha+direct+anterior+approach+anterior-lateral+ap-758b2fb3fff29faf3d0706d1d8958d4c3c0d54ec.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::Approaches"
<b>Open fractures</b> are classified based on the {{c1::Gustilo and Anderson}} system	"<img src=""maxresdefault-7ba6f2638117d19667279fc769156d0608e4bcff.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Gustilo-Anderson-Classificatin.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Open"
<u>Gustilo and Anderson Classification of Open Fractures</u><div><u><br></u></div><div><b>Type I:</b>&nbsp;{{c1::&lt;1 cm open wound, low energy fracture}}<br><b>Type II:</b>&nbsp;{{c2::1-10cm wound}}<br><b>Type III:</b>&nbsp;{{c3::&gt;10cm wound and/or high energy fracture (ie. segmental, comminuted)}}<br><b>IIIA:</b>&nbsp;{{c4::Adequate soft tissue for coverage (Includes split thickness skin grafts)}}<br><b>IIIB:</b>&nbsp;{{c5::Requires free or rotational flap for coverage }}<br></div><div><b>IIIC:</b>&nbsp;{{c6::Vascular injury requiring repair&nbsp;}}<br></div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""maxresdefault-7ba6f2638117d19667279fc769156d0608e4bcff.jpg""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Gustilo-Anderson-Classificatin.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::Open"

"<div>What is <b>Young's modulus of elasticity</b>? <br>
</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Resistance of a material to <u>Elastic Deformation</u>&nbsp;}}<br></div>"	"<div>Measure of the <b>stiffness</b> (ability to <b>resist deformation</b>) of a material in the <b>elastic zone</b></div>
<div>Calculated by <b>measuring</b> the <b>slope</b> of the <b>stress/strain curve</b> in the <b>elastic zone</b><br><b>
Higher </b>modulus of elasticity indicates a <b>stiffer </b>material</div><img src=""1200px-Stress_strain_ductile.svg.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::PrinciplesProperties"
"<div>What <b>material </b>has a <b>Young's </b>modulus of <b>Elasticity</b> most <b>similar</b> to <b>bone</b>? <br>
</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Titanium&nbsp;}}<br></div>"											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::PrinciplesProperties"
"<div>What is <b>Wolff’s law</b>? <br>
</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Remodeling of bone occurs in response to stress&nbsp;}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""phpfGNqdD.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::PrinciplesProperties"
"<div>What is the <b>{{c2::Hueter-Volkmann}}&nbsp;law</b>? <br>
</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Compression}} <b>inhibits</b> growth of bone and {{c1::tension}} <b>stimulates</b> bone growth</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-09 at 3.16.26 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::PrinciplesProperties"
"<div>What is the <b>Bernoulli's effect</b>? <br>
</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::A decrease in pressure causes an Increase in fluid speed}} (Arthroscopy)</div>"											"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::PrinciplesProperties"
"<div>What are the two ways in which <b>lag screws</b> are placed? <br>
</div><div><br></div>
<div>Lag by <b>technique</b>: {{c1::The <b>near cortex</b> is <u>over-drilled</u> relative to the <b>far</b> cortex}} <br>
</div>
<div>Lag by <b>design</b>: {{c2::The <b>proximal</b> aspect of the screw <u>does not</u> have <b>threads</b> (ie. partially threaded)}}</div>"	"<img src=""41_x010_i100b.ashx"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::General::PrinciplesProperties"

"<div>Postoperatively, what type of <b><u>weight-bearing</u></b> has the<b> lowest joint reactive forces</b>?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Touch-down/Toe-Touch weight-bearing}}<br></div>"	"<b>Touchdown weight bearing</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;is defined as not supporting any&nbsp;</span><b>weight</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;on the affected side by only&nbsp;</span><b>touching</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;the plantar aspect of the foot to the ground to maintain balance to protect the affected side from mechanical loading.</span><div><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div><div><img src=""weight-table.jpg"" class=""resizer""><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);""><br></span></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-25 at 3.11.33 PM.png"">"									"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Acetabulum"

"<div>What<b> imaging</b> should be obtained following a <b>native hip reduction</b>?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>

"<div>What is the classification for <b>femoral head fractures</b>?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Pipkin Classification&nbsp;}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-01 at 3.24.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Summary-of-the-Pipkin-classification-of-femoral-head-fractures.ppm"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Femoral_Head_Neck"
"<div><u><b>Pipkin</b> Classification of <b>Femoral Head</b> Fractures:</u></div><div><u><br></u></div>
<div>Type <b>I</b>: <b>{{c1::Infrafoveal}}</b> fracture&nbsp;</div>
<div>Type <b>Il</b>:<b> {{c2::Suprafoveal}}</b> fracture&nbsp;</div>
<div>Type <b>Ill</b>: <b>Type I or Il</b> associated <b>{{c3::femoral neck}}</b> fracture&nbsp;</div>
<div>Type <b>IV</b>: <b>Type I or Il</b> with associated <b>{{c4::acetabulum}}</b> fracture</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-01 at 3.24.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Summary-of-the-Pipkin-classification-of-femoral-head-fractures.ppm"">"	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">The fovea capitis is a&nbsp;</span><b>small, oval-shaped dimple on the ball-shaped end</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">&nbsp;(head) on top of your femur (thigh bone). Your hip is a ball-and-socket joint. The femoral head is the ball. It fits into a cup-shaped “socket” called the acetabulum in the lower part of your pelvic bone.</span><br><img src=""femur.jpg"" style=""width: 450px;"" class=""resizer"">"									"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Femoral_Head_Neck"
"<div>What are the Operative indications for <b>Femoral Head Fractures</b>?</div><div><br></div>

What are the 2 classifications for <b>femoral neck fractures</b>?<div><br></div><div><b>{{c2::Garden}}</b> Classification - Based on <b>{{c1::displacement}}</b></div><div><div><b>{{c2::Pauwel}}&nbsp;</b>Classification - Based on the {{c1::<b>trajectory</b> of the <b>fracture line</b> from the <b>horizontal plane</b>&nbsp;}}</div></div>	"<img src=""Fig-1-Garden-classification-of-hip-fractures_660.jpg"" class=""resizer""><div><br></div><div><img src=""2-Figure2-1-d5c6752cf913865d7d2574080e9be546a910a52c.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Femoral_Head_Neck"
"<div><u><b>Garden Classification of Femoral Neck Fractures:</b></u>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>Type I: {{c1::<b>Incomplete, non-displaced</b> fracture (Valgus impacted)}}</div>
<div>Type II: {{c2::<b>Complete, non-displaced</b> fracture&nbsp;}}</div>
<div>Type III: {{c3::Complete fracture with <b>&lt;100% displacement</b>&nbsp;}}</div>
<div>Type IV: {{c4::Complete fracture with <b>&gt;100% displacement.</b>&nbsp;<b>Trabecular</b> pattern of <b>Head</b> assumes a <b>Parallel Orientation </b>to the&nbsp;<b>Acetabulum</b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""Fig-1-Garden-classification-of-hip-fractures_660.jpg"" class=""resizer""><div><br></div><div><img src=""2-Figure2-1-d5c6752cf913865d7d2574080e9be546a910a52c.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"	"Type I:<br><img src=""xray - AP - garden II (other)_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Type II:<br><img src=""Xray - AP - Garden 1 - emed_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 339.141px;""><br><br>Type III:<br><img src=""Xray - AP - Garden III - emed_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 331.438px;""><br><br>Type IV:<br><img src=""Xray - AP - Garden IV - emed_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 329.547px;"">"									"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Femoral_Head_Neck"

<div>{{c1::Compression sided}}</div>"	"<img src=""maxresdefault-22a030bf7b671872204fe20409c167f88f179a9e.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""aad1ec0e7b6ec8e1950ecbd23458c3f6.gif"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Femoral_Head_Neck"
<div>How does the <b>healing potential</b> of <b>intertrochanteric (IT) fractures</b> differ from <b>femoral neck fractures</b>?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>IT </b>fractures are <b>extracapsular</b> and have a better healing potential due to their&nbsp;<u><b>periosteum</b> and <b>soft&nbsp;</b></u><b><u>tissue attachments</u></b>}}</div>	"<img src=""common-hip-trochanteric-fractures.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""it.jpg"" style=""width: 718px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Xray - AP - stable intertroch_moved.jpg"" style=""width: 487px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""screen_shot_2016-07-19_at_3.17.29_pm.jpg"" style=""width: 1422px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""screen_shot_2016-07-19_at_3.17.44_pm.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::IT_Fractures"
"<div>What makes an <b>IT hip</b> fracture<b> unstable</b>? (<b>Evans </b>Classification)</div>
<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>Reverse obliquity</b>&nbsp;}}<br></div>
<div>{{c2::Fracture <b>extension</b> into the <b>subtrochanteric</b> region&nbsp;}}<br></div>
<div>{{c3::Disrupted <b>medial calcar&nbsp;</b>}}<br></div>
<div>{{c4::Disruption of the <b>lateral cortex</b>&nbsp;}}<br></div>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""maxresdefault-5006d7257a90dcb3cb32c94655eaf345057e24b0.jpg"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><br><img src=""PE3720f02.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 200px;"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::IT_Fractures"
"<div>What are the <b>non-arthroplasty surgical</b> treatment options for <b>IT fractures</b>?</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::<b>Sliding hip screw</b> (SHS)}} and {{c2::<b>cephalomedullary nail</b> (CMN)&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<b>Sliding hip screw</b>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>stable</b>,&nbsp;<b>CMN</b>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>unstable</b><br><img src=""1-s2.0-S2210491710000072-gr1.jpg""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-01 at 3.44.45 PM.png""><br><div>Type 1: Fractures that extend along the intertrochanteric line&nbsp;</div><div>Type 2: Comminuted fractures with the main fracture line along the intertrochanteric line but with multiple secondary fracture lines (may include coronal fracture line seen on lateral view)&nbsp;</div><div>Type 3: Fractures that extend to or are distal to the lesser trochanter&nbsp;</div><div>Type 4: Fractures of the trochanteric region and proximal shaft with fractures in at least two planes&nbsp;</div>"	"<img src=""big_58aecb9eacd2c.jpg""><br><div>A dynamic hip screw (DHS) is indicated for osteosynthesis following pertrochanteric femoral fractures. A DHS consists of a large lag screw that is inserted into a plate attached to the outer bone, with bone screws into the neck and head of the femur. This enables interfragmentary compression through sliding of the femoral head in the direction of the fracture gap. In the case of rotational instability of the femoral head, an additional hip screw can be inserted as an antirotation screw.<br><br><img src=""big_58aecfd6f3907.jpg""><br><div>Osteosynthesis of an intertrochanteric fracture using a gamma locking nail: An intramedullary nail is placed directly into the bone marrow through the greater trochanter and held in position using a distal fixation screw. A lag screw is then placed through the nail, which enters the neck and head of the femur. This nail also allows for compression (weight-bearing) of the fracture site. The combination of intramedullary nail and lag screw resembles the Greek letter ""γ"" (gamma), which is why it is called a gamma locking nail.</div></div>"									"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::IT_Fractures"
"<div><b>Sliding hip screws</b> should be avoided in which type of <b>IT fractures</b>?</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Unstable}} fracture patterns</div>"	"<img src=""paste-96c9237e47c4caa7b44ac84c813eb478b40d9268.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><img src=""ambi1.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 262.5px;"">"	"<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""big_58aecb9eacd2c.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><div>A dynamic hip screw (DHS) is indicated for osteosynthesis following pertrochanteric femoral fractures. A DHS consists of a large lag screw that is inserted into a plate attached to the outer bone, with bone screws into the neck and head of the femur. This enables interfragmentary compression through sliding of the femoral head in the direction of the fracture gap. In the case of rotational instability of the femoral head, an additional hip screw can be inserted as an antirotation screw.<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""big_58aecfd6f3907.jpg"" style=""width: 991px;""><br><div>Osteosynthesis of an intertrochanteric fracture using a gamma locking nail: An intramedullary nail is placed directly into the bone marrow through the greater trochanter and held in position using a distal fixation screw. A lag screw is then placed through the nail, which enters the neck and head of the femur. This nail also allows for compression (weight-bearing) of the fracture site. The combination of intramedullary nail and lag screw resembles the Greek letter ""γ"" (gamma), which is why it is called a gamma locking nail.</div></div>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""it.jpg"" style=""width: 718px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Xray - AP - stable intertroch_moved.jpg"" style=""width: 487px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""screen_shot_2016-07-19_at_3.17.29_pm.jpg"" style=""width: 1422px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""screen_shot_2016-07-19_at_3.17.44_pm.jpg"">"								"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::IT_Fractures"
"<div>What is the <b>Tip-to-Apex distance (TAD) </b>in <b>IT femur fractures</b>?&nbsp;</div>
<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Combined distance from the<b> tip of the screw</b> to the <b>apex of the femoral head</b> on the <b>AP</b> and <b>lateral views&nbsp;</b>}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""maxresdefault-aa1a279d0870e819263ca4331e1388a4f9fc8748.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::IT_Fractures"
<div><b>TAD</b> &gt;{{c1::25}} <b>mm </b>in ORIF of <b>Intertrochanteric</b> femur fractures&nbsp;is associated with <b>screw cutout&nbsp;</b></div>	"<img src=""maxresdefault-aa1a279d0870e819263ca4331e1388a4f9fc8748.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""it.jpg"" style=""width: 718px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Xray - AP - stable intertroch_moved.jpg"" style=""width: 487px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""screen_shot_2016-07-19_at_3.17.29_pm.jpg"" style=""width: 1422px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""screen_shot_2016-07-19_at_3.17.44_pm.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::IT_Fractures"
"<div>What is the <b>Classification</b> system for <b>Subtrochanteric Femur </b>fractures?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Russel-Taylor}} Classification</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-04-20 at 3.14.59 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><div><img src=""russel taylor.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Trauma::Subtrochanteric_Fractures"
"<div><b>Russel-Taylor</b> Classification of <b>subtrochanteric femur</b> fractures</div><div><br></div><div><div>Type <b>I</b>: {{c1::<b>Intact</b> piriformis fossa&nbsp;}}</div>
<div>Type <b>IA</b>: {{c3::Lesser trochanter <b>attached to the proximal</b> fragment&nbsp;}}</div></div><div><div>Type <b>IB</b>: {{c3::Lesser trochanter <b>detached from the proximal</b> fragment&nbsp;}}</div></div><div><br></div><div><div>Type <b>Il</b>: {{c2::Fracture <b>extends into </b>the piriformis fossa}}&nbsp;</div>

"<div>What is the <b>posterior (Southern-Moore)</b> approach to the <b>hip</b>?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>1. <b>Split {{c1::Gluteus maximus}}</b> (Inferior gluteal nerve).&nbsp;</div>
<div>2. Retract <b>{{c1::Gluteus medius}} anteriorly</b>.&nbsp;</div><div>3. Identify <b>{{c2::Piriformis}} </b>and<b> {{c2::short external rotators}}</b>.&nbsp;</div><div>4. Detach the <b>{{c3::Piriformis}}, {{c3::Superior gamellus}}, {{c3::Obturator internus}}</b>,&nbsp;</div>
<div>and <b>{{c3::Inferior gamellus}}</b> from bone.&nbsp;</div><div>5. <b>Dislocate</b> the hip</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2020-10-02 at 7.17.49 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-10-02 at 7.17.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-10-02 at 7.17.59 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-10-02 at 7.18.05 AM.png"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Adult_Recon::THA"

"<div>During a <b>THA</b>, what <b>soft tissue structure</b> may be used to <u>judge the position</u> of the <b>acetabular cup</b>?&nbsp;</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Transverse acetabular ligament (TAL)&nbsp;}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""1-s2.0-S0883540316000796-gr2.jpg"" class=""resizer""><div><img src=""2-Figure3-1.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""paste-38da2ceb67aaa2dddd6061e3030ccae1f2e93c6b.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Hip::Adult_Recon::THA"
"<div>In what <b>quadrant</b> of the <b>acetabulum</b> can <b>screws</b> be placed most safely?</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Posterior-superior}}</div>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""safe zones 3.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;"">"	<b>Long</b>&nbsp;screws placed into the&nbsp;<b>posterior superior or posterior inferior</b>&nbsp;quadrant may pass into&nbsp;<b>sciatic notch</b>&nbsp;and endanger the&nbsp;<b>sciatic nerve</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>superior gluteal vessels</b>. This is particularly a risk in&nbsp;<b><u>revision surgery</u></b>&nbsp;when the a<b>cetabular component</b>&nbsp;may be placed in a&nbsp;<b><u>high hip center position</u></b>, as the&nbsp;<b>sciatic nerve</b>&nbsp;is at&nbsp;<b>increased risk</b>&nbsp;when placing&nbsp;<b>transacetabular screws posteriorly</b>. "<div>When evaluating an <b>AP pelvis radiograph </b>during THA, where should the <b>acetabular cup</b> be positioned relative to the <b>radiographic lines</b> of the <b>pelvis</b>?</div><div><br></div>

point is in line with the femoral shaft&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<img src=""3-Figure1-1-897b48c327c2a9bf10fa864de3752cc14de710c7.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Femur::Trauma::FemoralShaft"
"<div>In which patients is it more <b>difficult</b> to use a <b>pirifomis
IMN</b>?</div><div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Obese
patients&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<div>The correct position for the piriformis fossa entry point is<b> just medial to the tip of the greater trochanter</b>. In certain cases, the greater trochanter may be curved and medialized. It may then be necessary to ream through the medial tip of the greater trochanter.<br><br></div><div>If the<b> first guide wire is not in line with the femoral canal, eccentric nail placement may result</b>. This may ultimately cause an <b>iatrogenic femoral neck fracture </b>when the <b>nail is inserted</b>, because the <b>oblique insertion increases stress</b> upon the <b>femoral neck</b>.</div><img src=""32_a010_i020.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 620px;""><br><img src=""32_a010_i120.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 620px;"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Femur::Trauma::FemoralShaft"
"<div>What
are indications for use of a<b> retrograde IMN</b>? </div><div><br></div>

</b></div>
<div>{{c2::<b>Bilateral</b>
femur fractures (Avoids Repositioning)}} </div>

knee </b>(Use same incision for tibial nail)}} </div>
<div>{{c4::<b>Distal
femoral shaft </b>fracture}} </div>
<div>{{c5::<b>Ipsilateral
femoral neck</b> or <b>acetabular</b> fracture&nbsp;}}</div>"	"Also <b>pregnancy</b> (especially <b>1st trimester</b>) to <b>avoid radiation</b> exposure to fetus<br><br><img src=""Entry-point-of-the-retrograde-intramedullary-nail-which-could-affect-the-posterior.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-17 at 12.17.24 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Femur::Trauma::FemoralShaft"

<div><b>Lateral </b>— {{c1::<b>Transverse humeral</b> ligament&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<img draggable=""false"" src=""256_2018_3139_Fig2_HTML.png""><br><img src=""f1af981fb51eb4bd7985d4383a14c832.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"							<div>The<b>&nbsp;rotator interval</b>&nbsp;is a triangular anatomical area in the <b>anterosuperior aspect of the shoulder bounded&nbsp;superiorl</b>y&nbsp;by the anterior margin of the <b>supraspinatus</b> tendon, and inferiorly by the superior margin of the <b>subscapularis</b> tendon, and ranging from the c<b>oracoid process</b> to the <b>biceps groove</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>It is better to describe it as a triangular-shaped space instead of a two-dimensional ‘area’: the joint capsule is the as a ceiling and he floor of this space is the articular surface&nbsp;of the humeral head.&nbsp;At the capsuloligamentous level, the roof of this space is formed by the anterior part of the superior complex (the superior glenohumeral ligament and coracohumeral ligament). The inferior border of the rotator interval is formed by the middle glenohumeral ligament.</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>The rotator interval contains several important anatomical structures that contribute to the <b>stability and normal function</b> of the shoulder joint, including <b>biceps tendon, coracohumeral ligament, superior glenohumeral ligament, rotator interval capsule</b>, anterior fibers of the supraspinatus tendon, and superior fibers of the subscapularis tendon.&nbsp;The rotator interval allows the biceps tendon to become intra-articular as it runs to the superior labral insertion.&nbsp;</div>			"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::GeneralAnatomy"
"<div>What
structures are located within the <b>rotator interval</b>?</div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>{{c1::<div><b>Anterior
Posterior Compression (APC) </b></div>
<div><b>&nbsp;</b></div>
<div>APC
I: <u>&lt;</u>&nbsp;2.5cm pubic
symphysis diastasis </div>
<div>APC
Il: &gt;2.5cm pubic symphysis diastasis, sacrotuberous and sacrospinous
ligaments disrupted,
anterior SI ligaments disrupted.&nbsp; Posterior
SI ligaments intact, <u>Rotationally Unstable</u></div>
<div>APC
III: APC II + Posterior Sl ligament disruption. <u>Rotationally
and Vertically</u> unstable</div>}}<br></div>

Compression (LC) </b></div>
<div><b>&nbsp;</b></div>

I: Pubic symphysis fracture + SI compression fracture </div>
<div>LC
Il: LC I + Posterior Iliac wing fracture (Crescent fracture) </div>
<div>LC
III: LC II + Contralateral APC III (Windswept pelvis)</div>}}<br></div>

"<div>What

Il: <b>{{c2::Sclerosis, osteopenia}}</b></div>

Ill: {{c3::<b>Crescent</b> sign}}</div>
<div>Stage
IV: {{c4::<b>Flattening </b>and<b> collapse</b>}}</div>
<div>Stage
V: {{c5::<b>Degenerative</b> changes of the <b>glenoid&nbsp;</b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""789802"" class=""resizer""><img src=""illus_a-a39f2bcac5a9a1682b1fd4f4f304b86a21b96145.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::Trauma::ProximalHumerus"

"<div>What
are the <b>O'Driscoll principles</b> for <b>ORIF</b> of <b>distal humerus
fractures</b>? </div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>1. {{c1::A<b>s
many screws as possible</b> should be placed in the <b>distal fragments</b>}} </div>
<div>2. {{c2::<b>Every
</b>screw in the <b>distal</b> fragments should <b>pass through a plate</b>}} </div>
<div>3. {{c3::<b>Every</b>
screw should be <b>as long as possible</b>}} </div>
<div>4. {{c4::<b>Every</b>
screw should <b>engage as many <u>articular</u> fragments</b> as possible}} </div>
<div>5. {{c5::Screws
should <b>engage a fragment</b> on the <b>opposite</b> side}} </div>
<div>6. {{c6::Screws
should be <b>interdigitated</b>}} </div>
<div>7. {{c7::Plates
are positioned such that <b>compression is obtained</b> at the <b>supracondylar level</b> for
<b>both columns</b>&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<img src=""comment_attachment_image_637385494004503339.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 328px;"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-02 at 2.15.14 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::PP::Arm::Trauma::Humerus"
"<div>What
<b>distal humerus approach</b> allows for <b>direct visualization</b> of the <b>joint
surface</b>? </div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
