approach with an olecranon osteotomy&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<img src=""6.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Arm::Trauma::Humerus"
"<div>What
is the <b>shape</b> of the <b>olecranon osteotomy</b> in <b>a posterior
approach</b> to the <b>distal humerus</b>? </div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>{{c1::Distal

"<div>What
is the <b>most common complication</b> following <b>ORIF</b> of <b>fractures</b> about
the <b>elbow</b>? </div>

stiffness&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/original/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-1-4471-6572-9_16/MediaObjects/328656_1_En_16_Fig1_HTML.gif"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Elbow::Trauma::Capitellum_Trochlea"
"<div>What

<div>{{c1::<b>Regan
Morrey</b>}} Classification </div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>Type
1: <b>Coronoid tip</b> fractures </div>
<div>Type
2: Fracture involving <b>&lt;50%</b> of coronoid height </div>
<div>Type
3: Fracture involving <b>&gt;50%</b> of coronoid height </div>
<div>&nbsp;</div>
<div>{{c2::<b>O'Driscoll</b>}} Classification: Descriptive
of <b>fracture location</b> and <b>number</b> of fracture <b>fragments</b></div>

How do you measure a <b>Cobb angle</b> in <b>scoliosis</b>?<br><br>{{c1::A line is drawn along the&nbsp;<u>superior end plate</u>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<u>most tilted vertebrae proximally</u>. A second line is drawn on the&nbsp;<u>inferior end plate</u>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<u>most tilted vertebrae distally</u>.&nbsp;<u>Perpendicular lines</u>&nbsp;are then drawn to these two lines and the&nbsp;<u>angle of intersection</u>&nbsp;is measured.}}	"<div>10-30*: mild and monitor</div><div>30-40*: Thoracolumbar brace</div><div>40-50*+: Surgical fixation<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a387db85f4f63fbe127be10ef259e8484d08c056.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 186px;""></div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Peds::Spine::Scoliosis"

How is <b>spondylolisthesis classified</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Meyerding}} Classification	"<div><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-08-15 at 4.22.53 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-08-15 at 4.22.32 PM.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Peds::Spine::Spondylosis_Spondylolisthesis"
<b>Meyerding</b>&nbsp;Classification of&nbsp;<b>spondylolisthesis:</b><br><br><div>Grade I: {{c1::&lt;25}}%</div><div>Grade II: {{c1::25-49}}%</div><div>Grade III: {{c2::50-75}}%</div><div>Grade IV: {{c2::75-100}}%</div><div>Grade V: <b>Spondyloptosis</b></div>	"Spondyloptosis: a vertebra having slipped so far w.r.t. the vertebra below is that the two endplates are no longer congruent. Most commonly occurs at L5 on S1 but can be seen elsewhere rarely<br><br><img src=""wu_spondylolisthesis_grades600.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 344.641px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-08-15 at 4.22.53 PM.png"" style=""width: 350px;"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Peds::Spine::Spondylosis_Spondylolisthesis"

<div>The&nbsp;<b>radiographic hallmarks</b>&nbsp;of primary&nbsp;<b>osteoarthritis</b>&nbsp;include&nbsp;<b>{{c1::nonuniform joint space}}&nbsp;loss</b>,&nbsp;<b>{{c2::osteophyte}}</b>&nbsp;formation,&nbsp;<b>{{c2::cyst}}&nbsp;</b>formation and&nbsp;<b>{{c1::subchondral sclerosis}}</b>.</div>	"<img src=""afp20010715p279-f2.jpg"" style=""width: 550px;"" class=""resizer""><br>A - Joint space narrowing<br>B - Subchondral sclerosis and osteophytes<br>C -&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(9, 20, 42);"">Marked osteoarthritic changes with medial joint space narrowing&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(9, 20, 42);"">(white arrow)</span><span style=""color: rgb(9, 20, 42);"">&nbsp;causing a varus deformity of the knee and collapse of the joint space with destruction of the medial cartilage and the subchondral cortex&nbsp;</span><span style=""font-style: italic; color: rgb(9, 20, 42);"">(open arrowheads).</span><br>D - Subchondral cysts"	"<img src=""DS5_i7BVwAEXXEw.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2020-05-12 at 9.16.32 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 290px;"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-23 at 3.12.00 AM.png"">"								"#Ortho::Radiology::Anatomy"

What are the normal <b>radiographic parameters</b> for <b>radial height, volar tilt and radial inclination </b>of the wrist?<br><br><u>Radial height:</u>&nbsp;{{c1::11}} mm<div><u>Volar tilt:</u>&nbsp;{{c1::11}}<sup>o</sup></div><div><u>Radial inclination:</u>&nbsp;{{c1::22}}<sup>o</sup></div>	"<img src=""paste-c0f0fcef96beef4bd8d0bb46ff90845de49e4ef5.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 703px;""><br>"	"<div><b>Radial inclination</b>: In the&nbsp;<b>posteroanterior</b>&nbsp;view of a normal&nbsp;wrist joint, a line that is drawn tangential to the&nbsp;radial styloid, connecting the ends of the&nbsp;distal&nbsp;radius, makes a 30º angle with a line drawn perpendicular to the long axis of the radius (see diagram below).</div><div><br></div><div><b>Volar inclination</b>: In the&nbsp;lateral&nbsp;view of a normal&nbsp;wrist joint, a line that is drawn parallel to the articular surface of the&nbsp;distal&nbsp;radius makes a 10° angle with a line drawn perpendicular to the long axis of the radius.<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-08-14 at 1.01.47 PM.png"" style=""width: 1422px;""><br></div>"									"#Ortho::PP::Forearm&Wrist::Trauma::Wrist"

What are the<b> acceptable post-reduction parameters</b> for treating a<b> distal radius fx nonoperatively</b>?<u><br><br><b>Radial height:</b></u>&nbsp;&lt; {{c1::5}} mm <b>shortening</b><div><u><b>Volar </b>tilt<b>:</b></u>&nbsp;<b>Dorsal angulation</b> &lt; <b>{{c2::5}}</b><sup><b>o</b></sup> or within <b>{{c2::20}}</b><sup><b>o</b></sup> of the <b>contralateral side</b></div><div><u><b>Radial inclination:</b></u>&nbsp;&lt; <b>{{c3::5}}<sup>o</sup></b> <b>difference</b> to <b>contralateral</b></div><div><u><b>Articular step-off</b>:</u>&nbsp;&lt; <b>{{c4::2}}</b> mm</div>	"<img src=""paste-c0f0fcef96beef4bd8d0bb46ff90845de49e4ef5.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 703px;""><br>"	"<div><b>Radial inclination</b>: In the <b>posteroanterior</b> view of a normal&nbsp;<a href=""https://next.amboss.com/us/article/3p0S6S#Z3dd83a840b78ce860bf343f5b7e6a31b"">wrist joint</a>, a line that is drawn tangential to the&nbsp;<a href=""https://next.amboss.com/us/article/3p0S6S#Zc47ed0cfb0aab2dc38521344d20783c7"">radial styloid</a>, connecting the ends of the&nbsp;<a href=""https://next.amboss.com/us/article/xo0EVS#Zce232f978ea5a8fb9edbb980a41502b8"">distal</a>&nbsp;radius, makes a 30º angle with a line drawn perpendicular to the long axis of the radius (see diagram below).</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>Volar inclination</b>: In the&nbsp;<a href=""https://next.amboss.com/us/article/xo0EVS#Zad8f9786872edfa102f7204c82b56244"">lateral</a>&nbsp;view of a normal&nbsp;<a href=""https://next.amboss.com/us/article/3p0S6S#Z3dd83a840b78ce860bf343f5b7e6a31b"">wrist joint</a>, a line that is drawn parallel to the articular surface of the&nbsp;<a href=""https://next.amboss.com/us/article/xo0EVS#Zce232f978ea5a8fb9edbb980a41502b8"">distal</a>&nbsp;radius makes a 10° angle with a line drawn perpendicular to the long axis of the radius.<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-08-14 at 1.01.47 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1422px;""><br><br></div>"									"#Ortho::PP::Forearm&Wrist::Trauma::Wrist"
Which <b>nerve</b> is at risk with the <b>radial shaft pin</b> of a <b>wrist spanning external fixator</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Superficial radial n.}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-23 at 2.34.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;""><br><img src=""paste-eecc96753e44e93121493e6debe8bd16ec7ddcb9.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;"">"							"<img src=""f042-013-9780323611145.jpg""><br>Technique of external fixator application. (A)<b>&nbsp;Pin sites</b>&nbsp;are marked over the&nbsp;<b>dorsoradial radius</b>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<b>index metacarpal</b>. (B)&nbsp;<b>Radial pins</b>&nbsp;are placed between the&nbsp;<b>tendons&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis</b>&nbsp;just&nbsp;<b>proximal&nbsp;</b>to the&nbsp;<b>first compartment</b>&nbsp;outcropper muscles. (C) Homan retractors and drill guides protect the soft tissues. (D) Pin sites are loosely closed while easily sutured without the frame in place. (E) The index metacarpal pins are placed through a small open incision, allowing direct visualization and central pin placement within the bone. Branches of the radial sensory nerve must be protected in each of these incisions. (F) The fixator is then assembled. Early digital flexion (G) and extension (H) should be stressed during fixator wear."			"#Ortho::PP::Forearm&Wrist::Trauma::Wrist"

What<b> tumors</b> are found in the <b>posterior column</b> of the spine?<br><br>{{c1::Osteoid Osteoma/Osteoblastoma}}<br>{{c1::Aneurysmal Bone Cyst}}	"ABC of posterior spinal column:<br><br><img src=""1-s2.0-S2214751918302706-gr2.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology"
A <b>mass</b> that is <b>&gt; 5 cm, growing</b>, and <b>deep</b> to the <b>superficial fascia</b> should be presumed to be a(n) {{c1::soft tissue sarcoma (STS)}} until <u>proven otherwise</u>, and it should be assessed with <b>three-dimensional imaging</b> first (ideally {{c1::MRI}})	"<div>Patients often experience <b>enlarging painless or painful</b> soft tissue masses.<br>
<br>
In some instances, the masses are <b>small </b>and may be present for a<b> long time before</b> they are <b>recognized</b> as tumors</div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::STS"
On <b>{{c1::T1}}</b>-weighted images, <b>Soft tissue sarcomas</b> have a <b>{{c2::Low}}</b> signal intensity ({{c2::<b>isointense with muscle</b>}}), and on <b>{{c1::T2}}</b>-weighted images, they have a <b>{{c2::High}}</b> signal intensity.	"<div><div>With the administration of <b>IV gadolinium contrast </b>agent, an STS typically demonstrates a <b>peripheral enhancing zone</b> and a <b>nonenhancing, necrotic center</b>.</div></div><b><div><b><br></b></div>MRI</b> provides information on tumor <b>size, grade, depth</b>, and <b>anatomic location</b> and aids in surgical planning.<br><br>With the administration of intravenous gadolinium contrast agent, an STS typically demonstrates a peripheral enhancing zone and a nonenhancing, necrotic center.<br><br><div><div><b>CT </b>of the <b>chest </b>is performed to evaluate for<b> metastasis<br><br></b><img src=""g08nv27g06c.jpeg""><b><br></b></div></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::STS"
<b>Poor prognostic factors</b> for <b>soft tissue sarcomas</b> include the presence of {{c1::metastases}}, high {{c1::histologic grade}}, and size &gt; {{c1::5 cm}}	Unplanned removal of a soft tissue sarcoma is the most common error in treatment of STSs.										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::STS"
<div>{{c2::<b>Atypical lipomatous tumors</b> (ALT, or <b>well-differentiated liposarcomas</b>)}} are associated with {{c1::<b>MDM2</b> amplification::Genetics}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-01 at 5.07.56 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-01 at 5.08.42 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Basics::Genetics"
<b>Lauge-Hansen</b> classification&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>ankle fractures</b><br><br><b>Supination-Exernal Rotation (SER)</b><div><br>SER I: {{c1::<b>AITFL</b> sprain}}</div><div>SER II: {{c1::SER <b>I</b> + <b>Weber B fibula</b> fracture (<u><b>Anteroinferior</b> to <b>Posterosuperior</b></u>)}}</div><div>SER III: {{c2::SER <b>II</b> +<b> PITFL avulsio</b>n or <b>posterior malleolus</b> fracture}}</div><div>SER IV: {{c2::SER <b>III</b> + <b>Deltoid</b> ligament injury or <b>medial malleolus</b> fracture}}</div>	"<img src=""f066-014-9780323611145.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.46.29 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;""><br><img src=""f066-015-9780323611145.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 768px;""><br><img src=""L-H-Supination-external-rotation-1024x577.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1024px;"">"	"SIMPLIFIED ALGORITHM:<br><br><img src=""115017fig06.jpeg""><br><br><img src=""115017fig07.jpeg"">"						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.40.26 AM.png"">"			"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Ankle"
<b>Lauge-Hansen</b> classification&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>ankle fractures</b><br><br><b>Supination-Adduction (SAD)</b><br><div><br><div>-<b>SAD I</b>: {{c1::AITFL injury or Weber A fibula fracture}}</div><div>-<b>SAD II</b>: {{c1::SAD I + Vertical medial malleolus fracture (anteromedial impaction)}}</div></div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""paste-83b8426b8e64f545f3af27af044dcf481124f1d3.jpg""><br><img src=""L-H-Supination-adduction-1024x577.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"	"SIMPLIFIED ALGORITHM:<br><br><img src=""115017fig06.jpeg""><br><br><img src=""115017fig07.jpeg"">"						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.47.48 AM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1047/ankle-fractures"">Orthobullets - Ankle Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Ankle"
<b>Lauge-Hansen</b> classification&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>ankle fractures</b><br><br><div><b>Pronation-External Rotation (PER)<br><br></b></div><div>-PER <b>I</b>: {{c1::<b>Deltoid</b> ligament injury or <b>medial malleolus</b> fracture}}</div><div>-PER <b>II</b>: {{c1::PER <b>I</b> + <b>AITFL</b> injury}}</div><div>-PER <b>III</b>: {{c2::PER <b>II</b> + <b>Fibula</b> fracture (<b>anterosuperior</b> to <b>posteroinferior</b>)}}</div><div>-PER <b>IV</b>: {{c2::PER <b>III</b> + <b>PITFL avulsion</b> or <b>posterior malleolus</b> fracture}}</div>	"<img src=""f066-018-9780323611145.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 753px;""><br><img src=""f066-019-9780323611145.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 571px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.45.25 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;""><br><img src=""L-H-Pronation-External-Rotation-1024x577.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style="""">"	"SIMPLIFIED ALGORITHM:<br><br><img src=""115017fig06.jpeg""><br><br><img src=""115017fig07.jpeg"">"						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.44.31 AM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1047/ankle-fractures"">Orthobullets - Ankle Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Ankle"
<b>Lauge-Hansen</b> classification&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>ankle fractures</b><br><br><div><div><b>Pronation-Abduction (PAB)<br><br></b></div><div>-PAB <b>I</b>: {{c1::Deltoid ligament injury or medial malleolus fracture}}</div><div>-PAB <b>II</b>: {{c1::PAB I + AITFL}}</div><div>-PAB <b>III</b>: {{c1::PAB II + Comminuted Weber C fibula fracture}}</div></div>	"<div><img src=""f066-017-9780323611145.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""></div><div><img src=""f066-016-9780323611145.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.45.54 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;""><br><div></div><div></div></div><img src=""L-H-Pronation-abduction-1024x577.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br>"	"SIMPLIFIED ALGORITHM:<br><br><img src=""115017fig06.jpeg""><br><br><img src=""115017fig07.jpeg"">"						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-13 at 10.42.15 AM.png"">"			"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Ankle"
<div>{{c5::<b>O'Driscoll</b>}} Classification of&nbsp;<b>Coronoid&nbsp;</b>Fractures - Descriptive of {{c6::<b>fracture location</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>number</b>&nbsp;of fracture&nbsp;<b>fragments</b>}}</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>Type 1:<b>&nbsp;{{c1::Tip}}</b></div><div>Type 2:&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Anteromedial facet}}</b></div><div>Type 3:&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Basal&nbsp;}}</b></div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Coronoid-fx-1024x577.jpg"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::PP::Elbow::Trauma::ProximalUlna"
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Danis-Weber </span>Classification of&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold; background-color: inherit;"">distal</span><b style="""">&nbsp;</b><span style=""background-color: inherit;""><b style="""">fibula </b>fractures<br></span><br></div><div></div><div><div><div><span style=""background-color: inherit; color: inherit;"">Weber A</span>: {{c1::Infrasyndesmotic}}</div><div><span style=""background-color: inherit; color: inherit;"">Weber B</span>: {{c1::Transsyndesmotic}}</div><div><span style=""background-color: inherit; color: inherit;"">Weber C</span>: {{c1::Suprasyndesmotic}}</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""paste-86a59bd351f535f79153847899d53638057f882a.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Ankle"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Goals of <b>stem placement</b>&nbsp;in <b>THA</b> are to: <br><br>1) restore&nbsp;</span>{{c1::medial offset}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br>2) restore </span>{{c1::leg length (read: vertical height)}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br>3) restore&nbsp;</span>{{c1::femoral anteversion (average 15 degrees)}}"	"<img src=""determining+stem+placement+in+tha.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;""><img src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;""><img src=""femoral+stem+highlights.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"
"In THA,&nbsp;<strong>Medial offset</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""> should be determined by&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">templating&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">(some patients require standard offset, others require high offset - aka greater medial offset)</span>}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The advantage of <b>high offset</b> is that it <b>lateralizes </b>the <b>center</b> of the <b>femoral stem</b> and therefore <b>places greater tension</b> on the <b>abductor mechanism</b>, giving <b>greater stability </b>to the<b> implant</b>. &nbsp;The <b>disadvantage</b> of <b>high offset</b> is that it can <b>place excessive tension</b> on the <b>abductors </b>and cause <b>trochanteric bursitis.&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""determining+stem+placement+in+tha.jpg"" style=""width: 828px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"" style=""width: 828px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""femoral+stem+highlights.jpg"" style=""width: 828px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"
The advantage of high medial offset in THA is that it {{c1::lateralizes}} the center of the femoral stem and therefore places {{c1::greater}} tension on the {{c1::abductor mechanism}}, giving greater stability to the implant.	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>disadvantage</b> of <b>high offset</b>&nbsp;in <b>THA&nbsp;</b>is that it can <b>place excessive tension</b> on the <b>abductors </b>and cause <b>trochanteric bursitis.&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""determining+stem+placement+in+tha.jpg"" style=""width: 828px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"" style=""width: 828px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""femoral+stem+highlights.jpg"" style=""width: 828px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The&nbsp;</span><b>disadvantage</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of&nbsp;</span><b>high offset</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;in&nbsp;</span><b>THA&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">is that it can&nbsp;</span><b>place&nbsp;</b>{{c1::excessive}} <b>tension</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;on the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::abductors}}<b>&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">and cause&nbsp;</span>{{c1::trochanteric bursitis}}<b>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</b>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The advantage of&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">high offset</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is that it&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">lateralizes&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">the&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">center</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">femoral stem</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and therefore&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">places greater tension</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;on the&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">abductor mechanism</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, giving&nbsp;</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">greater stability&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">to the</span><b style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;implant</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.&nbsp;</span><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""determining+stem+placement+in+tha.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""femoral+stem+highlights.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"
"<strong>Vertical height</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;in <b>THA&nbsp;</b>is determined by&nbsp;</span>where the {{c1::center of the femoral head}}&nbsp;sits"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Vertical height can be <b>increased </b>if the <b>stem doesn't fully sit properly</b> (referred to as a ""<b>potted stem</b>""). &nbsp;Vertical heigh can be <b>increased</b> if the <b>stem</b> is put into <b>valgus</b> (<b>tip</b> of the <b>stem touches</b> the <b>medial cortex </b>of the <b>femur</b>). Vertical height can be <b>increased via +4, +8 etc femoral head</b> (although putting on a <b>+4 femoral head increases</b> the <b>neck length +4</b>, so it <b>affects</b> <b>both</b> the <b>medial offset</b> and the <b>vertical height</b> as a calculation of <b>SOH-CAH-TOA</b>).&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""determining+stem+placement+in+tha.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""femoral+stem+highlights.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Vertical height </b>in&nbsp;</span><b>THA&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">can be&nbsp;</span><b>increased&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">if the&nbsp;</span><b>stem doesn't</b>&nbsp;<b>{{c1::fully sit properly}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;(referred to as a ""</span><b>{{c2::potted stem}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">"")</span>"	"<strong>Vertical height</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;in&nbsp;<b>THA&nbsp;</b>is determined by&nbsp;</span>where the center of the femoral head sits<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br><br>Vertical height can be <b>increased</b> if the <b>stem</b> is put into <b>valgus</b> (<b>tip</b> of the <b>stem touches</b> the <b>medial cortex </b>of the <b>femur</b>). "<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>In THA, Vertical height</b> can be&nbsp;</span><b>Increased </b>via<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c1::<b>+4, +8 etc femoral head</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;(although putting on a&nbsp;</span><b>+4 femoral head increases</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;the&nbsp;</span><b>neck length +4</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">, so it&nbsp;</span><b>affects</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;</span><b>both</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;the&nbsp;</span><b>medial offset</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and the&nbsp;</span><b>vertical height</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;as a calculation of&nbsp;</span><b>SOH-CAH-TOA</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">).&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>}}"	"<strong>Vertical height</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;in&nbsp;<b>THA&nbsp;</b>is determined by&nbsp;</span>where the center of the femoral head sits<br><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span><img src=""stem+implant.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1156px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""determining+stem+placement+in+tha.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""femoral+stem+highlights.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"
"<strong>Femoral Anteversion</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""> is about <b>15 degrees</b>, but the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::native anatomy}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the <b>femur</b> often dictates the <b>version</b> for a <b>press-fit stem</b> (for a <b>cemented stem</b>, or an <b>S-ROM stem</b>, the surgeon has <b>much more control</b> over the femoral version). &nbsp;Many surgeons use the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior cortex}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the <b>femur</b>, at the <b>femoral neck cut</b>, as their <b>guide</b> for <b>setting version</b>.</span>"	"<img src=""how+to+determine+stem+anteversion+for+total+hip+replacement.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::BasicConcepts::StemPlacement"

"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Press-fit </b>can occur at the:<br><br></span><em>1) <b>Metaphysis</b></em><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>-&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the standard for primary hip replacements}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span><em>2) <b>Meta-diaphysis</b></em><font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)""><b>&nbsp;</b>- when someone is&nbsp;</font>{{c1::very osteoporotic and the surgeon is not sure if they can rely purely on the softer metaphyseal bone for rigid fixation}}<font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)""><br></font><em>3) <b>Diaphysis -&nbsp;</b></em><b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">the standard for revision hip replacements, when&nbsp;</span>{{c1::the metaphyseal bone is gone}}</b>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-08 at 6.40.34 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1270px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::Implants::PressFitStem"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>technique </b>to prepare the <b>femoral canal</b> for the<b> stem implant </b>in <b>THA&nbsp;</b>utilizes&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::broaching alone}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;for the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::metaphyseal}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;fitting </b>stems, and utilizes<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c1::reaming}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<b>meta-diaphysial </b>and <b>diaphysial</b>}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>fitting</b> stems.&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""pressfit+stem+prep.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 382px;""><img src=""pressfit+types.jpg"" style=""width: 609px;"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Hip::Implants::PressFitStem"

<div><b>Polyethylene (PE)</b> is best made by {{c1::direct-compression molding of powder to insert (best wear properties)&nbsp;}}</div>	<div>Crosslinking PE (UHMWPE) improves wear resistance (especially adhesive wear) but reduces mechanical properties (e.g., fracture toughness, tensile strength)&nbsp;</div>		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-01-25 at 10.24.11 PM.png"">"								"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Basics"
<div><b>Crosslinking PE (UHMWPE)</b> improves {{c1::wear resistance (especially adhesive wear)}} but reduces {{c1::mechanical properties (e.g., fracture toughness, tensile strength)&nbsp;}}</div>	"<div>Sterilization of PE is done by irradiation in art gas; irradiation generates free radicals which facilitate cross-linking of PE &amp; improve wear; however, too much free radicals (i.e., irradiation in presence of air) is bad because they cause oxidative degradation of PE<br><div><br>Remelting (heat PE past melting point) &amp; annealing (heat PE close to melting point) remove excess free  radicals after irradiation</div>
<ul>


<li>Annealing increases while remelting decreases crystal formation of UHMWPE</li></ul><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 4.19.06 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Basics"
<div><b>Ceramic-on-ceramic bearing</b> couple provides <b>least</b> {{c1::volumetric}} wear, however, it is at <b>risk for catastrophic failure</b> of {{c1::acetabular liner (fracture of ceramic liner with fragments in joint)&nbsp;}}</div>	"<div>Characteristic&nbsp;<b>stripe wear pattern</b>&nbsp;from&nbsp;<b>lift-off separation of femoral head</b>&nbsp;coming into&nbsp;<b>contact&nbsp;</b>with&nbsp;<b>acetabular rim</b></div>
<div><b>Risk factors</b>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>stripe wear&nbsp;</b>&amp; thus&nbsp;<b>liner fracture</b>: vertical cup, morbid obesity</div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Basics"
<div><b>Risk factors</b> for <b>stripe wear</b> &amp; thus <b>liner fracture </b>in <b>Ceramic THA Constructs</b>: {{c1::vertical cup}}, {{c1::morbid obesity&nbsp;}}</div>	"Characteristic&nbsp;<b>stripe wear pattern</b>&nbsp;from&nbsp;<b>lift-off separation of femoral head</b>&nbsp;coming into&nbsp;<b>contact&nbsp;</b>with&nbsp;<b>acetabular rim&nbsp;<br></b><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-10 at 9.31.09 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-10 at 9.32.27 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-10 at 9.32.53 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-10 at 9.33.07 AM.png"">"			"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Basics"

<div><b>Anterior approach</b> to the<b> hip </b>in <b>THA</b>&nbsp;{{c1::does not::does/does not}}&nbsp;show <b>superior gait mechanics</b> compared to <b>posterior or anterolateral&nbsp;</b></div>											"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Hip::Primary_THA"
<div><b>Posterior approach</b> to the <b>hip</b> in <b>THA</b> is associated with <b>increased </b>{{c1::hip adduction moment::Gait}} and <b>{{c1::longer::longer/shorter}} step length&nbsp;</b></div>											"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Hip::Primary_THA"
<div>{{c1::Monoblock}} <b>cups</b> have <b>liner embedded</b> w/in <b>acetabular component</b> - need to <b>exchange entire acetabular component</b> if <b>revision indicated</b>.&nbsp;</div>	"If revising monoblock cup due to instability, consider constrained liner or dual mobility<br><br><img src=""a+titanium+shell+and+polyethylene+liner+for+the++acetabular+implant.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Hip::Primary_THA"
<div><b>Morse taper construct assembly</b> requires {{c1::4000N}} of <b>force over a <i>dry</i> taper&nbsp;</b></div>	"<div>For femoral stems, early design was 14/16 but currently most surgeons prefer 12/14 taper&nbsp;</div><div>Factors that increase risk of corrosion: wet taper, taper damage, mixed alloy components, high offset femoral stem, longer-length femoral head&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""rr.5.2.108-fig29.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Hip::Primary_THA"
<div><b>Hip osteoarthritis</b>: {{c1::increased}} <b>water </b>content, {{c1::decreased}} <b>proteoglycan</b> content&nbsp;</div>	"<div><div>IL-I, IL-6, TNF-u increase matrix metalloprotease (MMP) activity —&gt; cartilage degeneration&nbsp;<br><br></div><div>Osteophyte formation: Indian hedgehog (Ihh) mediates activation of chondrocyte differentiation —&gt; osteophyte formation (pathologic activation of endochondral ossification)&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""bioche_mical.jpg""></div></div>"			"<img src=""chart.jpg.jpg"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Hip::Primary_THA"
<div><b>Hip osteoarthritis</b>:&nbsp;<br><br><b>{{c1::IL-I, IL-6, TNF-a}}</b> increase {{c1::matrix metalloprotease (<b>MMP</b>)}} activity —&gt;<b> {{c2::cartilage degeneration&nbsp;}}</b><br></div>	"<div>Osteophyte formation: Indian hedgehog (Ihh) mediates activation of chondrocyte differentiation —&gt; osteophyte formation (pathologic activation of endochondral ossification)&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""f030-002-9780323554640.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><img src=""bioche_mical.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 986px;""><br></div>"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-23 at 3.12.00 AM.png"">"								"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Hip::Primary_THA"

<div><b>Changing&nbsp;</b>{{c1::<b>tibial</b>}}<b>&nbsp;slope</b>&nbsp;in TKA affects <b>{{c2::flexion gap&nbsp;}}</b></div>	"Increasing slope increasing flexion gap<br><br>Example: <b>tight flexion, full extension</b> —&gt; <b>cut proximal tibia</b> with <b>increased tibial slope&nbsp;</b><br><br><img src=""tka+bone+cuts+extension+and+flexion+gap.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;"">"		<div>A <b>Loose Flexion gap</b> can allow the <b>Femoral Component</b> to ride <b>above</b> the <b>Tibial Cam Post</b> mechanism, resulting in <b>Dislocation</b></div>								"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Primary_TKA"

Advantages of <b>All-poly tibia</b> component vs <b>modular metal-backed</b> components for TKA<br><br>Lower {{c1::cost}}<br>Lower risk of {{c1::osteolysis}}<br>Equivalent or better {{c1::clinical results and long-term survivorship&nbsp;}}	"<img src=""An-example-of-an-all-polyethylene-tibial-component-posterior-stabilized-design-A.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Primary_TKA"
Intraoperatively during <b>TKA</b> the <b>Patella</b> is found to <b>Sublux Laterally</b> with <b>tracking</b> despite <b>perfect-appearing alignment</b> and<b> rotation</b> of the <b>femoral, tibial</b>, and <b>patellar</b> components. <div> Q angle is increased with IR of femoral or tibial component, medializing femoral or tibial component &amp; lateral placement of patellar prosthesis&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-17 at 9.10.10 AM.png"" class=""resizer""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Primary_TKA"
What <b>patellar condition</b> is associated with History of<b> high tibial osteotomy</b> (HTO)?<br><br>{{c1::Patella baja (Insall-Salvati ratio &lt;0.8)}}	"<img src=""HTO-images-500x281.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-09 at 9.33.16 PM.png"">"								"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Primary_TKA"
How should you perform <b>TKR</b> in <b>patella baja</b>? <br><br>{{c1::Place patella component superiorly &amp; lower joint line (cut <u>less femur</u>, cut <u>more tibia</u>)}}	"<img src=""HTO-images-500x281.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 500px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Primary_TKA"
<div><b>Unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA)</b> has <b>better </b>{{c1::knee biomechanics}} &amp; <b>earlier </b>{{c1::rehabilitation}} compared to <b>TKR</b></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-26 at 7.46.48 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-26 at 7.47.11 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::UKA"
Good indication for <b>UKA</b> is {{c1::<b>SPONK</b>}} - shows a<b> {{c2::90}}% survival</b> rate at <b>10 years</b>	"Spontaneous Osteonecrosis of the Knee<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-26 at 7.46.48 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-26 at 7.47.11 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::UKA"
<div><b>Patellar clunk syndrome</b> is seen in {{c1::PS}} Type<b> TKR</b></div>	"scar tissue gets caught in cam (intercondylar notch) as knee is flexed; scar tissue then gets displaced as knee is extended, causing catching or clunking sensation.&nbsp;<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-12 at 2.21.53 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-05 at 12.32.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><br></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Patellar_Clunk"
What is&nbsp;<b>Patellar clunk syndrome?<br><br></b>{{c1::<b>PS TKR -&nbsp;</b>Scar tissue gets caught in cam (intercondylar notch) as knee is flexed; scar tissue then gets displaced as knee is extended, causing catching or clunking sensation.&nbsp;}}	"<div><b>Synovial proliferation</b> on <b>undersurface</b> of <b>quad tendon</b> <i>adjacent</i> to <b>patella component&nbsp;</b><br><br></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-12 at 2.21.53 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-05 at 12.32.29 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><br>"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-16 at 10.42.49 AM.png"">"								"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Patellar_Clunk"
What is treatment for <b>Symptomatic Patellar clunk syndrome?<br></b><br>{{c1::Arthroscopic vs open debridement}}	"Nonoperative Management RARELY Successful<br><br><img src=""Clunking-Knee-after-Knee-Replacement.jpg"" class=""resizer""><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-12 at 2.21.53 PM.png"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-05 at 12.32.29 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Patellar_Clunk"
What are <b>risk factors</b> for <b>Patellar clunk syndrome</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::Older generation TKAs w/ wider boxes}}<br>{{c1::Undersized patellar component}}<br>{{c1::Over-resection of patella}}<br>{{c1::Low placement of patellar component&nbsp;}}</div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-12 at 2.21.53 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-05 at 12.32.29 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Patellar_Clunk"
<div>For <b>tibial metaphyseal defect</b> leading to <b>revision TKA</b>, {{c1::tantalum trabecular metal cones}} are <b>best</b> at <b>filling defect&nbsp;</b></div>	"<img src=""banner_knees_TMAugments.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Revision_TKA"
<div>Per FDA, addition of <b>abx to bone cement</b> is only indicated in {{c1::revision}} <b>TKA</b> (<b>NOT</b> indicated in {{c1::primary}} <b>TKA</b>)&nbsp;</div>											"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Revision_TKA"
"<div><b>MSIS major criteria</b> for <b>Prosthetic Joint Infection</b>:&nbsp;<br><br></div>
<div>1) {{c1::draining sinus&nbsp;}}</div>
<div>2) {{c1::two positive Cxs of same organism&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<img src=""musculoskeletal+infection+society+diagnostic+criteria+of+prosthetic+joint+infection.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Revision_TKA"
<div><b>Anteromedial wound defects</b> of the <b>knee</b> requiring <b>revision TKA</b> should be treated with {{c1::medial gastroc flap (medial sural artery)&nbsp;}}</div>	"<b>Medial gastroc </b>has more <b>rotational excursion</b> than <b>lateral </b>and is <b>larger&nbsp;</b><br><br><img src=""paste-5c9b3ef661da8b06cf10b678d75650623032c088.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Revision_TKA"
<div><b>Extensor mechanisms failure</b> in <b>revision TKA</b> treatment options:<br><br>{{c1::EM recon w/ allograft (CI in setting of infection)}}<br>{{c1::Fusion (if adequate bone stock)}}<br>{{c1::Amp (if inadequate bone stock)&nbsp;}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-a9e67b5bd2e3e41e2ca67b1da4a7515df7427c50.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Revision_TKA"
<div>For <b>diagnosing PJI</b>, {{c1::synovial alpha-defensin}} and {{c1::leukocyte esterase reagent strips}} are <b>most predictive</b></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-08 at 1.30.45 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Knee::Revision_TKA"
<div>{{c1::CT::Imaging?}} is best at estimating <b>extent</b> of <b>osteolysis&nbsp;</b></div>	"<img src=""4822b5fdc6b22410a443f3072e86d0_big_gallery.jpeg"" class=""resizer"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.48.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.49.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.49.55 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 4.18.52 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Periprosthetic::AsepticLooseningOsteolysis"
<div><b>Osteolysis</b> is mediated by {{c1::macrophages::Cell Type}}</div>	"<div>Macrophages release local factors TNF-a —&gt; activation of osteoclasts &amp; bone resorption&nbsp;<br><br><b style="""">RANKL, RANK</b>, and <b style="""">VEGF</b> are <b style="""">upregulated</b> in <b style="""">any process</b> that involves <b style="""">increased osteoclast</b> activity.<br></div>"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.48.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.49.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.49.55 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 4.18.52 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Periprosthetic::AsepticLooseningOsteolysis"
In <b>Osteolysis</b>, {{c2::<b>Macrophages</b>}} release <b>{{c2::local factors &amp; TNF-a}}</b>, which leads to <b>activation</b> of <b>{{c1::osteoclasts}}</b> &amp; <b>{{c1::bone resorption&nbsp;}}</b>	"<b>RANKL, RANK</b>, and&nbsp;<b>VEGF</b>&nbsp;are&nbsp;<b>upregulated</b>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<b>any process</b>&nbsp;that involves&nbsp;<b>increased osteoclast</b>&nbsp;activity.<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.48.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.49.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 1.49.55 PM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 4.18.52 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Periprosthetic::AsepticLooseningOsteolysis"
"<b>Periprosthetic Acetabular fracture Treatment</b><br><br><div> If <b>stable</b>: {{c1::protected weight bearing&nbsp;}}</div>
<div> If <b>unstable</b>: {{c1::acetabular revision +/- ORIF&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<img src=""lk figure 1a_crop.ashx"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Periprosthetic::Fracture"
"<div><b>Treatment </b>of <b>Periprosthetic Femur Fracture:<br><br></b></div>
<div> Vancouver <b>B1</b>: {{c1::<b>ORIF</b> fracture with <b>cerclage</b> cables/wires &amp; <b>locking plates&nbsp;</b>}}</div>
<div> Vancouver <b>B2</b>: {{c1::<b>ORIF </b>fracture, then <b>revise</b> using<b> <u>Fully porous coated cementless</u> stem</b>; make sure <u>stem  <b>bypasses</b> fracture</u> by <b>2 cortical diameters</b>}}<br>Vancouver <b>B3</b>: {{c2::<b>Revision</b> with <b>proximal femoral replacement</b>&nbsp;}}</div>
<div> Vancouver <b>C</b>: {{c2::<b>ORIF</b> with<b> locking plate</b> extending at least <b>2 cortical diameters above tip</b> of <b>femoral prosthesis</b>&nbsp;}}</div>"	"<b>2 cortical diameters</b> distance <b>prevents bending moment</b> through <b>cortical hole</b><br><br><img src=""paste-ecc27750c53813160acbdf24a5a1dfc2b3a1e24c.jpg""><b>&nbsp;</b>"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-13 at 4.26.49 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Periprosthetic::Fracture"
<b>Hawkins </b>Classification of&nbsp;<b>talar neck </b>fractures<br><br>Hawkins I: {{c1::Non-displaced talar neck fracture}}<div>Hawkins II: {{c1::Talar neck fracture + <b>subtalar</b> dislocation}}</div><div>Hawkins III: {{c2::Hawkins II +<b> tibiotalar</b> dislocation}}</div><div>Hawkins IV: {{c2::Hawkins III + <b>talonavicular</b> dislocation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""f89-40-9780323672177.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Talus"
"<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Ruedi </span>and <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Allgower </span>Classification<span style=""font-weight: 700;""> of&nbsp;</span><span style=""background-color: inherit;""><b>Pilon </b>fractures</span><span style=""background-color: rgb(209, 207, 206);""></span><div><br>Type I: {{c1::Non-displaced}}</div><div><div>Type II: {{c1::Displaced&nbsp;<span style=""background-color: inherit;"">fracture</span>&nbsp;with no comminution}}</div><div>Type III: {{c1::Comminution of the articular surface}}</div></div>"	"A <b>Pilon</b> Fracture is a Fracture of the <b>Distal end</b> of the <b>Tibia</b>, most commonly associated with <b>Comminution, Intra-Articular Extension</b>, and <b>Significant Soft Tissue</b> injury.<br><br><img src=""ruedi-allgower classification of tibial pilon fractures.jpg"">"			"Type I:<br><img src=""type i ruedi allgower ap.jpg""><br><br>Type II:<br><img src=""type ii ruedi allgower ap.jpg""><br><br>Type III:<br><img src=""type iii ruedi allgower ap.jpg"">"							"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Pilon"
"<span style=""background-color: rgb(223, 234, 251);""><u><b>Paprosky </b>Classification of <b>Acetabular Bone Loss</b></u><br><br></span><div>Type <b>I</b>: {{c1::Minimal deformity, <b>intact rim</b>}}</div>
<div>Type <b>IIA</b>: {{c2::<b>Superior</b> bone<b> lysis</b> with <u><b>intact superior </b>rim</u>}}</div>
<div>Type <b>IIB</b>: {{c2::<b>Absent superior rim</b>, <b>superolateral</b> migration}}</div>
<div>Type <b>IIC</b>: {{c2::Localized <u><b>destruction</b> of <b>medial wall</b></u>}}</div>
<div>Type <b>IIIA</b>: {{c3::Bone loss from <b>10am-2pm</b> around <b>rim</b>, <b>superolateral cup</b> migration}}</div>
<div>Type <b>IIIB</b>: {{c3::Bone loss from <b>9am-5pm</b> around <b>rim</b>, <b>superomedial cup</b> migration}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-06 at 2.57.58 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-06 at 2.59.07 AM.png"">"	"Paprosky I:<br><img src=""paprosky 1 acetabulum.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 351px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIA:<br><img src=""paprosky 2a acetabulum.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 293px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIB:<br><img src=""paprosky iib acetabulum.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 229px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIC:<br><img src=""paprosky 2c acetabulum.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 319px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIIA:&nbsp;<br><img src=""paprosky iiia acetabulum.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 343px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIIB:<br><img src=""paprosky 3b acetabulum.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::RevisionTechniques::Revision"
<div><b>Acetabular revision</b> with <b>adequate bone stock</b> (small defect): use {{c1::porous-coated hemisphere cup&nbsp;}}</div>	"<img src=""porous hemispherical cups.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"			"Paprosky I:<br><img src=""paprosky 1 acetabulum.jpg""><br><br>Paprosky IIA:<br><img src=""paprosky 2a acetabulum.jpg""><br><br>Paprosky IIB:<br><img src=""paprosky iib acetabulum.jpg""><br><br>Paprosky IIC:<br><img src=""paprosky 2c acetabulum.jpg""><br><br>Paprosky IIIA:&nbsp;<br><img src=""paprosky iiia acetabulum.jpg""><br><br>Paprosky IIIB:<br><img src=""paprosky 3b acetabulum.jpg"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::RevisionTechniques::Revision"

<div><b>Paprosky</b> classification of <b>acetabular bone loss</b>: type {{c1::Ill}} is the <b>worst</b> &amp; is associated with <b>superior cup migration&nbsp;</b></div>	<div>IllA: superolateral cup migration&nbsp;</div><div>IIIB: superomedial cup migration&nbsp;</div>	"Paprosky I:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""paprosky 1 acetabulum.jpg"" style=""width: 351px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIA:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""paprosky 2a acetabulum.jpg"" style=""width: 293px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIB:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""paprosky iib acetabulum.jpg"" style=""width: 229px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIC:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""paprosky 2c acetabulum.jpg"" style=""width: 319px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIIA:&nbsp;<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""paprosky iiia acetabulum.jpg"" style=""width: 343px;""><br><br>Paprosky IIIB:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""paprosky 3b acetabulum.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::RevisionTechniques::Revision"

What <b>structure</b> is <b>at risk </b>during the <b>Direct Lateral </b>approach to the<b> hip</b> with <b>dissection</b>&nbsp;of the<b> gluteus medius </b>over<b> 3 cm above</b> the superior border of the&nbsp;<b>greater trochanter</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Superior Gluteal n. and its branches}}	"Direct lateral approach has lowest rate of prosthetic dislocation<br><img src=""31_nr52_appr_direct_lateral_1a.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 620px;""><br><img src=""31_nr52_appr_direct_lateral_2a.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 620px;""><br><img src=""31_nr52_appr_direct_lateral_3a.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 620px;"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 11.47.54 AM.png"" class=""resizer"">"									"#Ortho::Netters::Thigh_Hip::Misc"
What is the <b>lead</b> of a <b>screw</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Distance advanced with 1 revolution}}	"<img src=""f53-19-9780323672177.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Materials"
<div>What is the <b>screw working distance</b>?<br><br>{{c1::The length of bone traversed by the screw}}</div>											"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Materials"
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Bending strength</b> of a <b>screw</b> is proportional to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::inner (minor) diameter^3}}"	"<img src=""screw.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 828px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Materials"
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Screw pullout strength</b> is proportional to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::outer (major) diameter^2}}"	"Maximized by: Large outer diameter difference &amp; Fine Pitch<br><br><b>Pedicle screw pullout</b>&nbsp;most affected by&nbsp;quality of bone&nbsp;(degree of osteoporosis)<br><img src=""screw.jpg"">"	"<img src=""f53-19-9780323672177.jpg"">"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Materials"
"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">What is the <b>plate working length/distance?</b><br><br></span>{{c1::The length between the 2 screws closest to the fracture on each end of the fracture}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span>"	"<b>Decreasing</b> the working distance<b> increases the stiffness</b> of the fixation construct, you want a large working length when bridge plating<br><br><img src=""EMVSiZdX0AI-047.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 540px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-09-27 at 5.43.01 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Materials"

"<div><b>Indications</b> for <b>locking plate</b> technology:<br><br>{{c1::<b>Indirect fracture </b>reduction}}<br>{{c1::<b>Diaphyseal/metaphyseal</b> fractures in <b>osteoporotic</b> bone}}<br>{{c2::<b>Bridging severely comminuted</b> fractures}}<br>{{c2::Plating of fractures where <b style="""">anatomical constraints prevent <u>plating</u></b> on the <b style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">tension side</b> of the bone (e.g. <b><u>short segment fixation</u></b>)}}</div>"	"<img src=""gr1-cf8528a78dd682f2c355966f2d133999f6bb2648.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 534px;"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-06 at 12.52.41 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1427px;"">"								"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Materials"

<b>{{c2::</b><b>Rhabdomyosarcoma</b><b>}}</b> is associated with a <b>{{c1::</b><b>t(2;13), PAX-FKHR</b><b>}}</b> translocation&nbsp;	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.26.48 PM.png"" style=""width: 1240px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Basics::Genetics"

Appearance of <b>Fat</b>&nbsp;on <b>MRI:</b><br><br><b>T1</b>-Weighted<b>: </b>{{c1::Bright}}<br><b>T2</b>-Weighted: {{c1::Gray}}	"<img src=""english-class-mri-technique-fig12-example-t1-msk-met.jpg""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 4.46.22 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Imaging"
Appearance of&nbsp;<b>Acute Blood Colection</b>&nbsp;on&nbsp;<b>MRI:</b><br><br><b>T1</b>-Weighted<b>:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Gray}}<br><b>T2</b>-Weighted: {{c1::Dark}}	"<img src=""131665_orig.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1051px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 4.46.22 PM.png"" style=""""><br>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::BasicScience::Imaging"

<u><b>AJCC</b> Staging System for <b>Primary Malignant Tumors </b>of<b> Bone</b><br></u><br>IA: {{c1::<b>Low</b> Grade, Size <b>&lt;8 cm</b>}}<br>IB: {{c1::<b>Low</b> Grade, Size <b>&gt;8 cm</b>}}<br>IIA: {{c1::<b>High</b> Grade, Size <b>&lt;8 cm</b>}}<br>IIB: {{c1::<b>High</b> Grade, Size <b>&gt;8 cm</b>}}<br>III: {{c2::Any tumor grade, <b>skip metastases</b> (<b>discontinuous</b> tumors in the <b>primary bone site</b>)}}<br>IV: {{c2::Any tumor grade/size, <b>distant metastases</b>}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 2.49.34 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 2.50.03 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Basics::Staging"
<div>A(n) {{c1::Osteosarcoma}} is a <b>spindle cell neoplasm</b> that <b>produces osteoid</b></div>									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
What is the typical treatment regimen for <b>Osteosarcoma</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::Neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks →&nbsp; wide surgical resection → adjuvant chemotherapy for 6-12 months&nbsp;}}</div>	Improved overall survival if adjuvant chemotherapy is resumed within 18-21 days after surgery <br><br>98% histologic tumor necrosis after neoadjuvant chemotherapy is good prognostic indicator.&nbsp;<br><br>*Chemo NOT indicated for parosteal								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
Standard <b>3-drug</b> treatment for <b>osteosarcoma</b>:<br><br>{{c1::Doxorubicin<br>Cisplatin<br>High-dose MTX&nbsp;}}	Chemotherapy both <b>kills the micrometastase</b>s that are present in <b>80%–90%</b> of the patients <b>at presentation</b> and <b>sterilizes </b>the <b>reactive zone </b>around the <b>tumor</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
<b>Osteosarcoma metastasizes</b> most <b>commonly</b> to the {{c1::lung}} and <b>next </b>most commonly to {{c1::bone}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
<div><b>Osteosarcoma</b> generally presents as <b>Enneking stage</b> {{c1::IIB (high-grade, extracompartmental)&nbsp;}}</div>	"<div>Stage IA: Low Grade, Intracompartmental&nbsp;</div>
<div>Stage IB: Low Grade, Extracompartmental</div>
<div>Stage IIA: High Grade, Intracompartmental</div>
<div>Stage IIB: High Grade, Extracompartmental</div>
<div>Stage Ill: Metastases&nbsp;</div>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
<div>{{c1::Intramedullary}}<b>&nbsp;osteosarcoma&nbsp;</b>is also called “<b>classic</b>” osteosarcoma and is the <b>most common type</b> of osteosarcoma.</div>	"Presentation: Pain, in the <b>proximal humerus, proximal femur</b>, and<b> pelvis<br></b><br>Radiographs demonstrate a lesion in which there is <b>bone destruction AND bone formation</b>.&nbsp;On occasion, the lesion is purely sclerotic or lytic.<br><br>Most commonly presents as <b>Stage IIB Enneking</b><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.49.09 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 652px;""><div></div><div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.50.23 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
<div>{{c1::Parosteal (low-grade surface)}} <b>osteosarcoma</b> presents as a <b>painless mass</b> that occurs on the<b> surface </b>of the <b>metaphysis</b> of <b>long bones</b>&nbsp;in patients most commonly aged <b>30-40</b></div>	"Most common sites are the <b>posterior aspects</b> of the <b>distal femur</b>, <b>proximal tibia</b>, and <b>proximal humerus</b>.<br><br>Characteristic radiographic appearance: a <b>heavily ossified</b>, <b>lobulated</b> mass ""<b>stuck</b> on<b> bone</b>,"" with&nbsp;<b><i>no</i>&nbsp;intramedullary extension</b><br><br><b>Resection </b>with a <b>wide margin</b> is <b><u>curative</u></b><br><br><img src=""Case A - posterior femur - xray - Parsons_moved.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 407px;"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.50.23 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
<div>{{c1::Periosteal (intermediate-grade surface)}} <b>osteosarcoma</b> is a <b>rare surface</b> form of <b>osteosarcoma</b> that occurs most often in the <b>diaphysis</b> of <b>long bones</b> (typically the <b>femur</b> or <b>tibia</b>)</div>	"Presentation: Pain<br><br>Radiographic appearance is fairly constant: a <b>sunburst-type lesion</b> rests on a <b>saucerized cortical depression</b><br><br>The prognosis for periosteal osteosarcoma is intermediate between those of very low-grade parosteal osteosarcoma&nbsp;and high-grade intramedullary osteosarcoma.<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.55.52 PM.png"" style=""width: 608px;"" class=""resizer"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.50.23 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
The <b>radiographic</b> features of {{c1::telangiectatic}} <b>osteosarcoma</b> are those of a <b>destructive, lytic, expansile lesion</b>. Occur in the <b>same locations </b>as <b>aneurysmal bone cysts</b>, and the radiographic appearances of the two <u>can be confused</u>.	"Presentation: <b>Pain</b><br>Histology: Prominent <b>blood-filled cysts</b> separated by <b>malignant hypercellular</b> and <b>anaplastic stroma</b><br>Treatment: <b>Same</b> as for <b>conventional osteosarcoma</b><br><br><img src=""Case C - distal femur - xray ap - Parsons_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 548px;""><img src=""Case C - distal femur - mri sag - Parsons_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 249px;""><img src=""Histology A - Parsons_moved.png"" class=""resizer""><br>"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-04 at 4.50.23 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Eaton and Littler Classification</span>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>CMC arthritis</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: bold;"">thumb<br></span><br></div><div></div><div><div>Stage I: {{c1::<b><u>Widenin</u>g</b> of joint space, <b>&lt;1/3</b> subluxation}}<div>Stage II: {{c1::Osteophytes <b>&lt;2 mm</b>, <b>1/3</b> subluxation}}</div><div>Stage III: {{c2::Osteophytes <b>&gt;2 mm</b>, <b>significant</b> joint space narrowing, <b>&gt;1/3</b> subluxation}}</div><div>Stage IV: {{c2::<b>Erosion</b> of <b>Scaphotrapezial</b> joint}}</div></div></div>"	"<img src=""paste-13d99695fdb294698622487383f7f766ec3a640b.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 292.672px;"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6054/basilar-thumb-arthritis"">Orthobullets: Basilar Thumb Arthritis</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::Hand::Conditions::CarpometacarpalArthritis"
What is the <b>work-up</b> for <b>Osteosarcoma</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::X-rays of entire extremity}}<br>{{c1::MRI of entire extremity}}<br>{{c1::Whole body bone scan}}<br>{{c1::CT chest}}<br>{{c1::Biopsy}}</div>									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8014/intramedullary-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Intramedullary Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8017/telangiectatic-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8015/parosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Parosteal Osteosarcoma</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pathology/8016/periosteal-osteosarcoma"">Orthobullets: Periosteal Osteosarcoma</a>"		"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Osteosarcoma"
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Leddy and Packer Classification</span>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>Jersey fingers<br></b><br></div><div></div><div><div>Type I: {{c1::<b>FDP </b>retraction to the <b>Palm</b>}}</div><div>Type II: {{c1::Retraction to <b>PIPJ</b>}}</div><div>Type III: {{c2::Retraction to <b>DIPJ</b>}}</div><div>Type IV: {{c2::""<b>Double avulsion</b>"" - Osseous avulsion from the <u><b>distal phalanx </b>with <b>tendon avulsion</b></u> from the <b>osseous fragment</b>}}</div><div>Type V: {{c3::<b>Comminuted </b>bony avulsion}}<br></div></div>"	"<br><img src=""paste-c5d8c7f4740267b119bb29388ebc09d85b8f5597.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 908px;""><div></div><div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Hand::Conditions::FlexorTendonInjuries"
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Doyle's Classification&nbsp;</span>for&nbsp;<b>Mallet fingers</b><div><br></div></div><div></div><div><div>Type I: {{c1::<b>Closed</b> injury ± fracture}}</div><div>Type II: {{c2::<b>Open</b> injury}}</div><div>Type III: {{c2::Open injury with <b>loss</b> of<b> tendon substance</b>}}</div><div>Type IV: <b>Fracture</b></div><div>-IV A: {{c3::<b>Physeal</b> injury}}</div><div>-IV B: {{c3::<b>20-30% articular surface</b> involvement}}</div><div>-IV C: {{c3::<b>&gt;50%</b> articular surface involvement}}<br></div></div>"	"<img src=""paste-941dd8042f3d654eaa5f071eda47ba7f81246b92.jpg""><div></div><div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::Hand::Conditions::ExtensorTendonInjuries"
<div>Several methods exist to <b>predict</b> the <b>risk of pathologic fracture</b>. These include:<br><br>{{c1::The presence of <u>significant functional pain</u>}}<br>{{c1::&gt; 50% destruction of <u>cortical</u> bone}}<br>{{c1::Formal staging systems (Harington's criteria, Mirels' criteria)}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 5.24.27 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Basics::Prophylactic_Fixation"
<div><b>Prophylactic fixation</b> is <b>preferred</b> to fixation of <b>actual</b> pathological fracture due to:<br><br>{{c1::Shorter operative time}}<br>{{c1::Decreased morbidity}}<br>{{c1::Quicker recovery}}</div>				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 5.27.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 5.28.06 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Basics::Prophylactic_Fixation"
