"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;A good <b>landmark</b> for<b> tibial rotation</b> in <b>TKA</b> is to align the <b>anterior aspect </b>of the <b>tibial component </b>with the<b>&nbsp;</b></span>{{c1::<b>medial 1/3</b> of the<b> patellar tendon</b>}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.</span>"	If the <b>tibial</b> component is<b> internally rotated</b>, the <b>tibia</b> bone is now <b>relatively externally</b> rotated <b>compared</b> to the <b>femur</b>, which will <b>rotate </b>the tibial <b>tubercle laterally</b>, and thus<b> increase </b>the <b>Q angle</b> and <b>increase </b>risk for <b>dislocation</b>.										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<b style="""">Cutting</b> the <b style="""">Distal Femur</b> in <b style="""">TKA</b> affects 3 things: <br><br>1)&nbsp;{{c1::Mechanical Alignment}}<br>2)&nbsp;{{c1::Extension gap}}<br>3)&nbsp;{{c1::Joint Line Height}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The goal is to place the <b>TKA</b> in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::neutral}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>mechanical alignment</b></span>"	"Adjusting with the jig for 6 degrees valgus and for 3 degrees of internal rotation posterior condyles<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>knee</b> is typically in <b>neutral mechanical alignment </b>when the ""<b>knee angle</b>"" (tibio-femoral angle) is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">°&nbsp;</span>{{c1::valgus::Varus/Valgus?}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>difference</b> between the <b>anatomic axis</b>&nbsp;of the <b>femur&nbsp;</b>and the <b>mechanical axis</b> is about&nbsp;</span>{{c1::6}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">°, and that is commonly what the <b>intramedullary guide</b> is set to.</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The exact measurements should be calculated preoperatively as part of the templating.</span><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
The <b>hole</b> for the <b>intramedullary femoral guide</b>&nbsp;in <b>TKA</b>&nbsp;should be <b>drilled</b> just <b>above</b> the {{c1::PCL}} and aimed <b>down</b> the&nbsp;{{c1::medullary canal}}	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/343010732/figure/fig1/AS:11431281182246299@1692345834156/Schematic-diagram-the-point-10mm-anterior-to-the-origin-of-the-posterior-cruciate.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">If the <b>TKA extension gap</b> is <b>trapezoidal</b>, this indicates&nbsp;</span>{{c1::soft tissue imbalance}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;that requires <b>adjustment.&nbsp;</b></span>"	"Should form nice <b>rectangle</b><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>DEPTH</b> of the <b>distal femur</b> for the&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>femoral implant of every company</b> (and therefore the <b>target depth</b> for ALL&nbsp;<b>distal femoral cuts</b>)&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::9}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;mm&nbsp;</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"What are the situations where surgeons may <b>increase</b> the<b> depth</b> of the<b> femoral component</b> from <b>9 mm</b> in <b>TKA</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b>Significant flexion contracture</b> - Resecting <b>more distal femur</b> will <b>enlarge</b> the <b>extension gap</b> (without affecting the flexion gap)}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span>{{c2::<b>Want</b>&nbsp;to <b>raise the joint line</b>}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"What are the situations where surgeons may <b>decrease</b> the<b> depth</b> of the<b> femoral component</b> from <b>9 mm</b> in <b>TKA</b>?<br><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span>{{c2::<b>Want</b>&nbsp;to <b>lower </b>the<b> joint line</b>&nbsp;- signicant bone loss or pre-existing patella baja}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.09.46 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.10.53 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In <b>TKA</b>, the <b>Anterior Femoral Cut</b> is thru the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::trochlear groove}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and the <b>depth</b> of this cut affects the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::patellofemoral}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;joint</span>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.34.26 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In&nbsp;<b>TKA</b>, the&nbsp;<b>Posterior Femoral Cut</b>&nbsp;is thru the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::posterior condyle}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<b>depth</b>&nbsp;of this cut affects the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">flexion gap</span>}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.34.26 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In <b>TKA</b>, <b>Anterior</b> and <b>Posterior Femoral Cuts</b> are <b>parallel</b> and together they <b>determine </b>the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::rotation}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;of the <b>femoral implant</b>.</span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.34.26 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"In <b>TKA</b>, t<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">he <b>Femoral&nbsp;</b></span><strong>Implant Size</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""> must be determined with a <b>sizing guide</b>, and is based off the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::A-P Diameter::Measurement}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.33.43 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In the <b>native</b> knee, the <b>posterior femoral condyles</b> are <b>not equal size</b> and therefore a line across them is in&nbsp;</span>{{c1::3}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">° of&nbsp;</span>{{c1::valgus::Varus or Valgus?}}<font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)"">.</font>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">(to match the native tibial plateau angle of 3° varus)<br><br></span><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.38.54 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.21 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.26 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.47 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br><br></span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Internal rotation</b> of either the <b>femoral</b> or <b>tibial </b>component&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">of <b>1-4°</b>&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">in&nbsp;</span><b>TKA&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">causes&nbsp;</span>{{c1::some lateral patellar tilt/tracking}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.38.54 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.21 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.26 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.47 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br><br></span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<b style="""">Internal rotation</b> of either the <b style="""">femoral</b> or <b style="""">tibial </b>component&nbsp;of <b>5-8°</b>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<b>TKA&nbsp;</b>causes&nbsp;{{c1::<span style=""background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">patellar subluxation and pain</span>}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.38.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.21 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.46 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.26 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.47 PM.png""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br><br></span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Internal rotation</b> of either the <b>femoral</b> or <b>tibial </b>component&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">of <b>&gt;8°</b>&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">in&nbsp;</span><b>TKA&nbsp;</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">causes&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">dislocation and failure</span>}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.38.54 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.21 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.26 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.47 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br><br></span>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Not only does the <b>Flexion Gap</b> need to be <b>rectangular</b> (indication of <b>rotation</b>), but it also needs to be the same size as the</span> {{c1::Extension Gap (9 mm)}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.</span>"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Therefore, we are trying to take about 9 mm of bone off the posterior femoral condyles.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br></span><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.38.54 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.21 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.39.46 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.26 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.40.47 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"What does&nbsp;<strong>Posterior Referencing </strong>mean?<br><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><br></span>{{c1::The 4-in-1 femoral cutting jig is rigid in its position from the posterior femoral condyles.}}"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">This distance is <b>strictly 9 mm</b>, so you will<b> cut 9 mm off</b> the <b>posterior femoral</b> condyles <b>regardless</b> of the <b>jig size</b> that you use.<br><br>A <b>smaller</b> jig will take <b>more bone off the anterior cortex cut</b>, and 9 mm off the posterior cortex cut.<br>A <b>bigger</b> jig will take <b>less bone</b> off the <b>anterior cortex cut</b>, and 9 mm off the posterior cortex cut.<br><br>So the feet of the jig are set up against the posterior femoral condyles, and you mark this spot with two pins,  then put the 4-in-1 cutting guide (for the determined implant size) onto these two pins and start cutting.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br></span><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 7.16.32 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 6.51.31 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>benefit</b> of&nbsp;</span><strong>Posterior Referencing</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;is that you <b>recreate</b> the <b>normal</b>&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Posterior Condyle Offset}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 7.08.52 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 7.16.32 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In TKA, the <b>posterior condylar offset</b> is <b>important </b>because its directly related to the <b>arc of motion</b> <b>before</b>&nbsp;</span>{{c1::impingement}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;occurs</span>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 7.08.52 PM.png"" style=""width: 1419px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 4.37.58 PM.png"" style=""width: 1419px;"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"In TKA <b>Posterior Referencing</b>, if the <b style="""">femoral component</b> is measured <b style="""">“too big</b>” then the <b style="""">anterior cut</b> will be&nbsp;{{c1::too shallow}}, causing the&nbsp;{{c1::patellofemoral}}<b>&nbsp;joint</b> to become&nbsp;{{c2::<b>too tight in flexion</b> (knee <b>stiffness</b> in <b>flexion</b>)}}"	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>Not enough bone is taken</b> and so it's<b> replaced with a lot of metal</b>, which will “</span><strong>overstuff</strong><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">” the <b>patellofemoral joint</b>.<br></span><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 4.45.36 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;"">&nbsp;"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"In TKA&nbsp;<b>Posterior Referencing</b>, if the <b style="""">femoral component</b> is measured ""<b>too small</b>"",&nbsp;the<b>&nbsp;anterior cut</b>&nbsp;will be&nbsp;<b>too&nbsp;</b><b>{{c2::deep}}</b>, and will cause&nbsp;{{c2::“<strong>notching</strong>”}}, which may <b>increase risk</b> for<b>&nbsp;</b><b>{{c1::periprosthetic fracture}}.</b>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 4.45.36 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In <b>TKA Anterior Referencing</b>, if the <b>femur</b> is <b>big </b>relative to the size of the 4-in-1 guide, you will end up removing <b>too much bone posteriorly</b>, which will <b>decrease</b> the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Posterior Condyle Offset}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;and may reduce&nbsp;</span>{{c1::range of motion}}"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.03.42 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In <b>TKA Anterior Referencing</b>, if the <b>femur</b> is <b>small&nbsp;</b>relative to the size of the 4-in-1 guide, you will end up removing <b>too&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c2::little}}</b><span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);""><b>&nbsp;</b>bone<b> <u>posteriorly</u></b>, and the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<b>Flexion</b> Gap}}&nbsp;<font color=""rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.988235294117647)"">will be <b>small</b>&nbsp;relative to the&nbsp;</font>{{c1::<b>Extension </b>gap}}.<br>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.03.42 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
<div>Across most device companies, the<b> standard thickness</b> of the <b>Patellar Button</b> is {{c1::9}} mm.&nbsp;Therefore, the&nbsp;<b>standard patellar cut</b> should be {{c1::9::(Same)}} mm.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>	"Measure the&nbsp;<b>depth&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>native patella</b>,&nbsp;<b>subtract 9 mm</b>, and then set the&nbsp;<b>patellar cutting guide</b>&nbsp;to<b>&nbsp;that number</b>&nbsp;(if the&nbsp;<b>average patellar depth is 20 mm</b>, the patellar cutting guide is set to&nbsp;<b>11-12 mm</b>, although&nbsp;<b>many surgeons set it to 14 mm</b>&nbsp;to avoid&nbsp;<b>cutting the patella too thin</b>).<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.11.22 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
<div>It's important to&nbsp;<b>avoid</b>&nbsp;cutting the&nbsp;<b>patella too thin</b>&nbsp;because there is an&nbsp;<b>increased risk&nbsp;</b>of&nbsp;<b>fracture</b>&nbsp;and <b>higher rate of AVN</b> when the patella is cut to&nbsp;<b>&lt;&nbsp;{{c2::12 mm}}</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>native patella</b>.</div>	"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">The <b>standard prosthetic design</b> has <b>3-pegs</b> because there is a <b>lower risk of fracture</b> compared to the <b>single peg</b> design.<br></span><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.11.22 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Bone_Cuts"
If the <b>medial</b> or <b>lateral compartment </b>is<b> looser</b> in <b>TKA</b>, this side will experience <b>less {{c1::tension}} </b>and may lead to {{c2::an <b>unstable TKA</b>}} and/or {{c2::<b>asymmetric <u>wear</u></b> and <b><u>early failure</u></b>}}.&nbsp;	"Gap balance measured with a&nbsp;<b>spacer block</b><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.18.16 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>In TKA, <b>trapezoidal flexion</b> and <b>extension gaps</b> occur <b>despite perfect bone cuts</b> because of {{c1::soft tissue imbalance}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.23.02 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<b>Ranawat Valgus Class I</b><br><br><b>Knee Angle</b> (Femoral-Tibial Angle): {{c1::&lt;10}}<sup>o</sup><br><b>MCL </b>Status: {{c1::Intact}}	"Alignment is <b>correctable with stress</b><br><br>Accounts for <b>&gt;80%</b> of Valgus Knees<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.28.59 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 1418px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<b>Ranawat Valgus Class II</b><br><br><b>Knee Angle</b> (Femoral-Tibial Angle): {{c1::10-20}}<sup>o</sup><br><b>MCL </b>Status: {{c1::<u>Attenuated</u> but has a <u>firm endpoint</u>}}	"Accounts for <b>15%</b> of Valgus knees<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.28.59 PM.png"" style=""""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<b>Ranawat Valgus Class III</b><br><br><b>Knee Angle</b> (Femoral-Tibial Angle): {{c1::&gt;20}}<sup>o</sup><br><b>MCL </b>Status: {{c1::<u>Absent</u> or <u>Severely Attenuated</u>}}	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.28.59 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>If the <b>MCL</b> is <b>intact</b>, then a {{c1::primary}} <b>TKA poly insert </b>can be used.&nbsp; <br>If the <b>MCL </b>is <b>elongated,</b> a {{c1::constrained}}<b>&nbsp;poly</b> may be necessary to give <b>sufficient <u>coronal</u> stability</b>.</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.31.02 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">&nbsp;<img alt=""Cemented and Cementless Knee Replacement - Complete Orthopedics"" src=""https://www.cortho.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/1T5A0291.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>There is a risk of <b>recurrent&nbsp;{{c1::Valgus}}&nbsp;</b>deformity after <b>primary TKA</b> when the <b>MCL</b> is <b>deficient</b> and a(n)&nbsp;<b>{{c2::primary}} insert</b> is used&nbsp;</div>	"(even when&nbsp;<b>satisfactory ligament balancing</b>&nbsp;occurs at the&nbsp;<b>time of surgery</b>)<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.33.05 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>In <b>TKA</b>, if the <b>MCL</b> is <b>completely absent</b>, a <b>{{c1::hinge prosthesis}}</b> should be considered as <b>excessive stress </b>to a <b>constrained insert</b> may cause {{c2::<b>significant wear,</b> <b>early loosening,</b> and <b>post fracture</b>::3 things}}.&nbsp;</div>	(even when&nbsp;<b>satisfactory ligament balancing</b>&nbsp;occurs at the&nbsp;<b>time of surgery</b>)<br><br>Although <b>hinge prostheses</b> also have a<b> higher </b>rate of <b>aseptic loosening </b>secondary to <b>increased constraint</b>										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>When performing <b>lateral releases</b> in <b>TKA</b>, the <b>{{c1::peroneal nerve}}</b> is at risk between the <b>{{c2::IT band}} </b>and <b>{{c2::Popliteus}}</b> at the <b>level </b>of the<b> tibial cut</b>.</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.37.52 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>In the case of a <b>hypoplastic LFC</b> in TKA (seen with <b>Valgus </b>knees), the <b>posterior referencing system</b> may need to dial in {{c1::5}}° or more to&nbsp;<b>prevent</b>&nbsp;{{c1::internal rotation}} of the <b>femoral component.</b></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.38.38 PM.png"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-10 at 10.59.36 AM.png""><br><img src=""epicondylar axis.jpg"">"								"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">In TKA, if there is &gt;&nbsp;</span>{{c1::5}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">&nbsp;<b>mm</b> of <b>deficient bone</b> on the <b>posterior </b>or<b> distal femoral cut</b>, <b>augments</b> should be considered because a <b>cement mantle</b> this <b>large </b>will lead to&nbsp;</span>{{c1::early loosening}}<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">.</span>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 5.38.38 PM.png"" style=""""><br>"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::GapBalance"
<div>The <b>patella engages</b> the <b>trochlear groove</b> in <b>20°&nbsp;flexion</b>, as the <b>knee </b>continues to <b>flex</b> the <b>entire patella engages</b> and the <b>patella translates&nbsp;</b>{{c1::laterally}}&nbsp;and <b>tilts&nbsp;</b>{{c1::medially}}.</div>	"<img alt=""Recurrent Patellar Dislocation - Orthosport Victoria"" src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/342059623/figure/fig3/AS:905061433610242@1592794869727/Measurements-of-patellar-tilt-angle-and-patellar-displacement-a-Preoperative-b.ppm"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Patella_Tracking"
<div><b>Patella</b> is at <b>greatest risk</b> of <b>dislocating</b> in {{c1::<b>30°&nbsp;flexion</b> (as it <b>begins</b> to <b>engage</b>)::Degrees flexion/extension}}, and with further <b>flexion</b>, {{c2::<b>bony constraint</b> (<b>anterior flange</b> of <b>LFC</b>)}} <u>prevents</u><b> lateral instability</b></div>	"<img alt=""Structure and Function of the Knee | Musculoskeletal Key"" src=""https://musculoskeletalkey.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/B9780323089449000101_f010-006ad-9780323089449.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Patella_Tracking"
<div>Normally, the <b>patella</b> engages the <b>trochlear groove at 15°&nbsp;flexion</b>, enters the <b>intercondylar notch at X°</b>, but in the case of <b><u>Patella Baja</u></b> (<b>elevated joint line</b>) the patella <b>enters</b> the<b> intercondylar notch earlier</b> in {{c1::flexion}} and <b>impinges</b> on the {{c1::polyethylene insert}} causing <b>pain, osteolysis</b>, and <b>limits flexion</b>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</div>											"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Patella_Tracking"
<div>What will happen when <b>trialing</b> a <b>tight flexion gap</b> in <b>TKA</b>?<br><br>{{c1::The poly will lift off the tray or get spit out}}</div>	"Tray lift-off:<br><img src=""tibial_tray_lift_off_2.jpg""><br><br>Vs Normal tray:<br><img src=""tibial_tray_lift_off.jpg""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 6.09.49 PM.png"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::TKA_Kinematics"
What will happen when <b>trialing</b> a <b>tight extension gap</b> in <b>TKA</b>?<br><br>{{c1::The knee will <u>not fully extend</u> during a straight leg rise}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 6.09.49 PM.png"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::TKA_Kinematics"
<div>What causes a <b>firm endpoint </b>in <b>knee flexion</b>? <br><br>{{c1::The <u>posterior tibia</u> impingeing on the <u>femur</u> at roughly <u>140° flexion</u>}}</div>	"(In obese people this endpoint can occur earlier in the arc of motion due to entrapment of fat rolls)<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 6.14.04 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::TKA_Kinematics"
<div>The <b>joint line</b> of the<b> knee</b> is approximately: <br><br>{{c1::10}} mm <b>above</b> the <b>fibular head</b><br>{{c1::25}} mm <b>below</b> the <b>lateral epicondyle</b><br>{{c1::35}} mm <b>below</b> the <b>medial epicondyle</b></div>	With the <b>leg </b>in <b>extension</b> the <b>joint line</b> should typically <b>sit </b>at the<b> inferior pole</b> of the <b>patella</b>.										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::TKA_Kinematics"
<b>{{c1::Adamantinomas}}</b>&nbsp;are <b>rare</b><b>,&nbsp;low-grade malignant&nbsp;</b><b>tumors </b>of <u>unknown etiology</u> that are almost always located in the {{c2::<b>diaphysis </b>of the <b>mid-tibia</b>}}.	"Usually presents in patients who are between <b>20 and 40 years old</b> with <b>regional pain</b> and a <b>palpable mass</b>.<br><br>Diagnosis is made with a <b>biopsy</b> showing&nbsp;<b>nests of epithelial-like cells</b>&nbsp;arranged in <b>palisading or&nbsp;glandular </b>pattern, in a&nbsp;<b>background </b>of&nbsp;<b>fibrous stroma</b>.<br><br>Treatment is usually&nbsp;<b>wide-margin surgical resection</b>.<br><br><img src=""Case A - tibia - xray a - parsons.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 155px;""><img src=""q22-2b1.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 449px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Adamantinoma"
<b>{{c1::Chondrosarcomas}}</b> are <b>malignant primary bone tumors</b> composed of <b>chondrocytes</b> with <b>variable degrees of malignancy </b>that are <b>most commonly found </b>in the <b>{{c2::pelvis}} </b>and <b>{{c2::proximal femur}}</b>.&nbsp;	"Patients typically present <b>after the age of 40</b>, with a <b>progressively painful mass</b>.<br><br>Diagnosis is made with biopsy showing&nbsp;<b>hypercellular stroma</b> consisting of characteristic ""<b>blue-balls</b>"" of a cartilage lesion which permeate the bone trabeculae.<br><br>Treatment is usually <b>wide surgical resection </b>- <b>Grade 2/3 </b>or Grade <b>1</b> in the <b>Pelvis.</b>"	"<img src=""Case E - prox femur - xray - Parsons_moved.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 388px;""><img src=""Case E - prox femur - MRI - Parsons_moved.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 388px;""><img src=""chondrosarcoma.high power.histology.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 726px;"">"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::CartilageTumors::Chondrosarcoma"

What is the general <b>treatment </b>for <b>adamantinomas</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Wide-margin surgical resection}}	"<img src=""{CD216DA7-4B9B-414F-B14C-26A6BF82C767}.png""><br>Adamantinomas are&nbsp;<b>rare</b><b>,&nbsp;low-grade malignant&nbsp;</b><b>tumors&nbsp;</b>of&nbsp;<u>unknown etiology</u>&nbsp;that are almost always located in the <b>diaphysis&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>mid-tibia</b><br><br>Usually presents in patients who are between&nbsp;<b>20 and 40 years old</b>&nbsp;with&nbsp;<b>regional pain</b>&nbsp;and a&nbsp;<b>palpable mass</b>.<br><br>Diagnosis is made with a&nbsp;<b>biopsy</b>&nbsp;showing&nbsp;<b>nests of epithelial-like cells</b>&nbsp;arranged in&nbsp;<b>palisading or&nbsp;glandular&nbsp;</b>pattern, in a&nbsp;<b>background&nbsp;</b>of&nbsp;<b>fibrous stroma</b>.<br><br>Treatment is usually&nbsp;<b>wide-margin surgical resection</b>.<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Case A - tibia - xray a - parsons.jpg"" style=""width: 155px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""q22-2b1.jpg"" style=""width: 449px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::BoneTumors::Adamantinoma"
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Snyder </span>Classification of&nbsp;<b>SLAP lesions</b><div><br></div></div><div></div><div><div>Type I : {{c1::<b>Fraying</b> of the <b>superior labrum</b> with an<b> intact bicep anchor</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Type II: {{c1::<b>Detachment</b> of the <b>superior labrum</b> and <b>biceps anchor</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Type III: {{c2::<b>Bucket-handle</b> tear of the <b>superior labrum</b> with an <b><u>intact</u> bicep anchor</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Type IV: {{c2::<b>Bucket-handle</b> tear of the <b>superior labrum</b> with <b><u>extension</u></b> into <b>bicep anchor</b>}}<br></div></div>"	"<br><img src=""11999_2016_4826_Fig1_HTML.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 685px;""><div></div><div></div>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3053/slap-lesion"">Orthobullets: SLAP Lesions</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::Sports::ShoulderInstability_Labrum"
"<div><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Sirveaux</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 255); font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;</span>classification&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>scapular notching</b><br><br></div><div></div><div>Grade I: {{c1::Notching to <b><u>Scapular Pillar</u></b>}}<div>Grade II: {{c1::Notching to the <b>inferior screw</b> of the <b>baseplate</b>}}</div><div>Grade III: {{c2::Notching <b><u>beyond</u></b> the <b>inferior screw</b> of the baseplate}}</div><div>Grade IV: {{c2::Notching to the <b>central peg</b> of the baseplate}}</div></div>"	"<br><img src=""f12-24-9780323672177.jpg""><br><div>Grade 0: No notch</div><div>Grade 1: Small notch</div><div>Grade 2: Notch with condensation (stable)</div><div>Grade 3: Evolutive notch (erosion of inferior screw)</div><div>Grade 4: First glenoid loosening.</div><div></div><div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::AdultReconstruction::ReverseShoulder"
"<b>{{c2::Lipomas}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>&nbsp;</b>are common <b>benign tumors</b> of <b><u>mature</u> fat</b> which may be&nbsp;</span>{{c1::<b>subcutaneous, extramuscular, </b>or<b> intramuscular</b>::Locations (3)}}"											"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
"{{c1::S<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">uperficial::Superficial or deep?</span>}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;<b>lipomas</b> are common in the <b>upper back, thighs, buttocks, shoulders</b> and <b>arms</b></span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-17 at 7.19.01 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 938px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
"<b>{{c1::D<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">eep::Superfical or deep?</span>}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;<b>lipomas</b> are <b>affixed</b> to surrounding <b>muscle</b>, in the <b>thighs, shoulders</b> and <b>arms</b></span>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-17 at 7.19.01 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 938px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
Common <b>variants</b> of <b>lipoma</b> include: (5)<br><br>{{c1::Spindle cell lipoma<br>pleomorphic lipoma<br>Angiolipoma (painful)<br>Intramuscular lipoma<br>Hibernoma:: which is painful?}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-17 at 7.20.19 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 938px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
<div><b>Mineralization (i.e calcifications)</b>&nbsp;of <b>lipomas</b> on <b>X-ray</b> should raise concern for {{c1::synovial cell sarcoma}}</div>	May see calcifications or presence of bone within the lesion										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
What is the characteristic <b>appearance</b> of <b>lipomas</b> on <b>MRI</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Well-demarcated lesion<br>Homogenous, signal intensity <u>matches adipose</u> tissue on&nbsp;all image sequencing}}	"see below for examples<br><br><b>High signal </b>intensity&nbsp;on <b>T1-</b>weighted images<br><img src=""lipoma t1 axial_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 500px;""><br><img src=""lipoma_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 480px;""><br><br><b>High</b> signal intensity&nbsp;on <b>T2-weighted</b> images, <b>entirely suppressed by STIR</b> or <b>fat saturated </b>sequences<br><br><b>Low </b>signal intensity&nbsp;on <b>STIR&nbsp;image</b><br><img src=""lipoma t2_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 500px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
What is seen on histology of spindle cell lipoma?<br><br>{{c1::Mixture of <u>mature fat cells</u> and <u>spindle cells</u><br><u>Mucoid matrix</u> with varying number of <u>birefringent collagen fibers</u>}}	"<img src=""spindle-cell-lipoma.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"
What is seen on <b>histology</b> of <b>pleomorphic</b> lipoma?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Lipocytes, spindle cells</u>, and scattered <u>atypical giant</u> cells}}											"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Lipomas"

<div>{{c2::<b>Pigmented villonodular synovitis</b> (PVNS)}} is due to<b>&nbsp;overexpression</b> of {{c1::<b>Colony-stimulating factor-1</b> (CSF-1)}}</div>	Aka “Tenosynovial giant cell tumor”			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.30.52 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.10 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.33 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.32.18 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.32.35 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.02 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.19 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.36 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::PVNS"
<b><u>Symptomatic</u> PVNS</b> is treated with {{c1::marginal resection (synovectomy)}} +/- {{c1::radiation}}	"Pexidartinib (CSF-1 Antagonist) recently approved, may have use in non-operative candidates<br><img src=""Xray lateral_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 331px;""><img src=""2b_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 435px;""><img src=""q4-1d1_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 486px;""><img src=""pvns ankle mri t2.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.30.52 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.10 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.33 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.50 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.32.18 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.32.35 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.02 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.19 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.36 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;"">"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::PVNS"
{{c1::Pigmented Villonodular Synovitis}} is a <b>locally aggressive neoplastic synovial</b> disease (not a true neoplasm) characterized by <b>joint effusions</b>, <b>expansion of the synovium</b>, and <b>bony erosions</b>.	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Xray lateral_moved.jpg"" style=""width: 331px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""2b_moved.jpg"" style=""width: 435px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""q4-1d1_moved.jpg"" style=""width: 486px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""pvns ankle mri t2.jpg"" style=""width: 346px;"">"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.30.52 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.10 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.33 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.31.50 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.32.18 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.32.35 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.02 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.19 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-18 at 3.33.36 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;"">"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::PVNS"
{{c1::Intramuscular Myxomas}} are <b>benign soft tissue tumors</b> that present as <b>slow-growing deeply seated</b> masses <u>confined</u> within the <b>skeletal muscle</b>.	"<img src=""mri.intramuscular myxoma.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 398px;"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.59.22 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.59.54 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.00.19 AM.png""><br></div>"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Intramuscular_Myxoma"
<b>{{c1::Mazabraud's}}</b> syndrome is&nbsp;characterized by <b>multiple&nbsp;{{c2::intramuscular myxomas::neoplasm?}}</b>&nbsp;associated with <b>monostotic</b> or <b>polyostotic fibrous dysplasia</b>		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.59.22 AM.png"" style=""width: 911px;"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.59.54 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.00.19 AM.png"" style=""width: 911px;"">"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Intramuscular_Myxoma"
On <b>MRI, Myxomas</b> will show a {{c1::Dark}} <b>T1</b> signal and {{c1::Bright}} <b>T2</b> Signal	"<img src=""mri.intramuscular myxoma.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.59.22 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.59.54 AM.png""><div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.00.19 AM.png""><div></div><div></div><br></div>"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Intramuscular_Myxoma"
{{c1::Tumoral Calcinosis}} is a <b>rare, hereditary metabolic dysfunction</b> of <b>phosphate regulation</b> associated with development of <b>massive periarticular calcinosis</b> in the <b>extra-capsular soft tissues</b>.&nbsp;	"Patients most commonly present with <b>palpable lesions</b> around the <b>hip</b> and<b> shoulder.<br><br></b><img src=""tumoral calcinosis lateral_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 500px;""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.28.58 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><b><br></b><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.29.27 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.29.57 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 9.30.11 AM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Misc::Tumoral_Calcinosis"
<div><b>{{c1::Enchondromas}} </b>are <b>benign cartilage tumors</b> found in the <b>{{c2::medullary cavity}}</b>&nbsp;of bone&nbsp;</div>	"Popcorn stippling on radiographs<br><br><img src=""case b - prox humerus - xray - parsons.png"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::CartilageTumors::Enchondroma"
{{c1::Neurilemmoma}}, also known as {{c1::Schwannoma}}, are <b>benign, encapsulated nerve sheath tumors</b> composed of <b>Schwann</b> cells that occur on the <b>surface</b> of <b>peripheral nerves</b>.	"Characteristic ""<b>string sign</b>""<br><br><img src=""string sign.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 216px;"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.30.45 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.12 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.32 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br>"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Neurilemmoma"
<b>Immunostaining</b> of <b>Neurilemmomas (Schwannomas)</b> is positive for {{c1::S-100}}	"Characteristic ""string sign""<br><br><img src=""string sign.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 216px;"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.30.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.12 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.32 PM.png"">"									"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Neurilemmoma"
On <b>MRI</b>, <b>Neurilemmomas</b> are {{c1::low}} intensity on <b>T1</b>, {{c1::high}} intensity on <b>T2</b>, and {{c1::diffuse}} <b>enhancement</b> with <b>gadolinium</b>	"Characteristic string sign<br><br><img src=""string sign.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.30.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.12 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.32 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Neurilemmoma"
On <b>histology</b> of {{c2::<b>Neurilemmomas (Schwannomas)</b>}}, you can see <b>{{c1::Verocay}} bodies,</b> which are pathognomonic	"C<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">omposed of <b>two rows</b> of <b>aligned nuclei</b> in a <b>palisading</b> formation<br><br></span><img src=""verocay_diagram.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 904px;""><img src=""verocay_histo.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 876px;""><br><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span>"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.30.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.12 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-20 at 8.31.32 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::SoftTissue::Neurilemmoma"

What are the <b>components</b> of <b>Mirel's Critera</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Site (1 = Upper limb, 2 = Lower limb, 3 = Peritrochanteric)<br>Pain (1 = Mild, 2 = Moderate, 3 = Functional)<br>Lesion (1= Blastic, 2 = Mixed, 3 = Lytic)<br>Size (1 = &lt;1/3, 2 = 1/3 - 2/3, 3 = &gt;2/3)}}	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-05 at 5.24.27 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::Basics::Prophylactic_Fixation"

The correct <b>location</b> for the <b>trochanteric entry point</b>&nbsp;for an <b>Anterograde IMN&nbsp;</b>is {{c1::just next to the <b>tip</b> of the <b>greater trochanter</b>}} in the <b><u>AP view</u></b>. It is important that the entry be {{c2::<b>exactly <u>centered</u></b>}} on the<b> axial view</b>, in order to <b>prevent&nbsp;</b>{{c3::<b>eccentric reaming</b>}}.	"In <b>unreamed</b> nailing, an <b>incorrect entry</b> point may lead to <b>blow out</b> of either the <b>posterio</b>r, or <b>anterior wall</b> of the <b>greater trochanter</b>.<br><br><img src=""32_a011_i020.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 620px;"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.35.59 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.36.31 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.35.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.36.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.37.15 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.37.38 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.38.14 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.42.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-10-25 at 2.42.36 PM.png"">"						"#Ortho::OITEReview::Trauma::Femur::AntegradeNail"

What is the most common site of <b>metastasis</b> from&nbsp;<b>primary chondrosarcoma</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Lungs}}	"<b>Chondrosarcomas</b>&nbsp;are&nbsp;<b>malignant primary bone tumors</b>&nbsp;composed of&nbsp;<b>chondrocytes</b>&nbsp;with&nbsp;<b>variable degrees of malignancy&nbsp;</b>that are&nbsp;<b>most commonly found&nbsp;</b>in the&nbsp;<b>pelvis&nbsp;</b>and&nbsp;<b>proximal femur</b>.&nbsp;<br><br>Patients typically present&nbsp;<b>after the age of 40</b>, with a&nbsp;<b>progressively painful mass</b>.<br><br>Diagnosis is made with biopsy showing&nbsp;<b>hypercellular stroma</b>&nbsp;consisting of characteristic ""<b>blue-balls</b>"" of a cartilage lesion which permeate the bone trabeculae.<br><br>Treatment is usually&nbsp;<b>wide surgical resection&nbsp;</b>-&nbsp;<b>Grade 2/3&nbsp;</b>or Grade&nbsp;<b>1</b>&nbsp;in the&nbsp;<b>Pelvis.<br></b><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Case E - prox femur - xray - Parsons_moved.png"" style=""width: 388px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Case E - prox femur - MRI - Parsons_moved.png"" style=""width: 388px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""chondrosarcoma.high power.histology.jpg"" style=""width: 726px;""><br><div><div><div></div><div></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Oncology::CartilageTumors::Chondrosarcoma"

What are the <b>ligament restraints</b> of the <b>Coracohumeral Ligament </b>(<b>CHL</b>)?<br><br>{{c1::Resists <u>posterior</u> translation when <u>flexed, adducted, and Internally Rotated</u> }}	"<img src=""screen_shot_2017-04-06_at_6.03.43_pm.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 938px;""><br>"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-23 at 4.18.33 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Shoulder::Glenohumeral_Ligaments"
The <b>{{c1::Anterior}}</b> band of the <b>IGHL</b> attaches to <b>{{c1::Anterior}} Labrum</b> and forms a <b>weak link</b> that predisposes to <b>{{c2::Bankart lesions}}</b>	"<img src=""hqdefault-1f4f9601d66ed616236518a05817975d91adeb2a.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 480px;""><br><img src=""Bankart-bony-lesion-XR1.jpeg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 555px;"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Shoulder::Glenohumeral_Ligaments"

<div><b>Release</b> of the&nbsp;<b>Coracoacromial ligament</b> during <b>arthroscopy</b> leads to {{c1::anterior/inferior}} translation of the <b>glenohumeral joint&nbsp;</b></div>	"<img src=""gr3_lrg.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Shoulder::Glenohumeral_Ligaments"
<div>The <b>rotator cable</b> is an extension of the<b> {{c1::Coracohumeral Ligament}}</b>; has <b>thickened fibers</b> at insertion of <b>{{c2::Infraspinatus}} </b>&amp; <b>{{c2::Supraspinatus}}</b> (perpendicular to)&nbsp;</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(5, 5, 5);"">The rotator cable is a <b>thickened area</b> of the <b>rotator cuff </b>that provides a <b>path</b> for <b>force dispersion</b> which helps to <b>prevent tension overload</b> within the<b> rotator crescent</b> (the area of <b>tendon surrounded</b> by the<b> rotator cable</b>). The rotator cable <b>creates</b> a <b>functional complex</b> with the <b>supraspinatus</b> and <b>infraspinatus tendons</b>.</span><br><br><img src=""118472414_3388982117827087_194475678721787417_n.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 938px;"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-01-25 at 3.10.14 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Shoulder::Glenohumeral_Ligaments"
<div>During <b>arthroscopic release</b> of the <b>rotator interval</b>, the <b>landmark</b> for <b>complete release</b> is visualization of the {{c1::CA ligament}} <b>superficially&nbsp;</b></div>	"<img src=""gr3_lrg-100355733b1ae9262e683b0d4d7d0ee3c4ead490.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"										"#Ortho::OITEReview::Shoulder::Glenohumeral_Ligaments"
"<div><b>{{c1::Parsonage-Turner syndrome}}</b> is also known as <b>{{c2::idiopathic brachial neuritis}}&nbsp;</b>or <b>{{c2::neuralgic
amyotrophy}}</b></div>"	<div><b>Intense shoulder / upper extremity pain</b>, <b>multifocal weakness</b> (patchy paresis), <b>fatty atrophy</b> on <b>MRI</b>, <b>EMG with denervation</b> &amp; <b>reinnervation potentials<br><br></b></div><div>Treatment: <b>observation&nbsp;</b></div>			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.40.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.40.31 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.41.08 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.41.39 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.42.07 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.42.34 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.43.18 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.43.58 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.44.34 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-11-24 at 3.44.50 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::OITEReview::Shoulder::ParsonageTurner"
"<div><b>Thoracic outlet syndrome</b> causes of symptoms:</div>

"{{c1::Pericytes (Mesenchymal Cells)}} are<b> stem cells</b> that give rise to the majority
of <b>new tissue</b> required to <u><b>bridge</b> a <b>fracture</b></u>.&nbsp;"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>At <b>rest</b>, pericytes
form part of the <b>boundar</b>y of <b>blood vessels </b>in <b>bone.</b><font color=""#0080ac""><br></font>When
a <b>vessel </b>is <b>damaged</b> as a result of <b>fractur</b>e, pericytes are
<b>activated</b> and begin to <b>proliferate</b>.<font color=""#0080ac""><br></font>Once <b>activated</b>, pericytes<b>
differentiate </b>into <b>osteoblasts or chondrocytes</b> depending on
the <b>local microenvironment</b>.<font color=""#0080ac""><br></font>The m<b>ost significant source
</b>of pericytes for <b>fracture healing</b> is the <b>vasculature</b> of the
<b>periosteum</b> and <b>endosteum</b>.<span style=""color: rgb(0, 128, 172);"">&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-05 at 5.27.02 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::Misc_Books::SkeletalTrauma::4_FractureHealing"
Once&nbsp;<b>activated</b>&nbsp;during fracture healing, <b>Pericytes (Mesenchymal Stem cells) differentiate&nbsp;</b>into&nbsp;<b>{{c1::osteoblasts}}&nbsp;</b>or&nbsp;<b>{{c1::chondrocytes}}</b>&nbsp;depending on the&nbsp;<b>{{c2::local microenvironment (Strain and O<sub>2</sub>)}}</b>	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-05 at 5.27.02 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><b><br><br>Pericytes</b> are<b>&nbsp;stem cells</b>&nbsp;that give rise to the majority of&nbsp;<b>new tissue</b>&nbsp;required to&nbsp;<u><b>bridge</b>&nbsp;a&nbsp;<b>fracture</b></u>.&nbsp;<br>At <b>rest</b>, pericytes
form part of the <b>boundar</b>y of <b>blood vessels </b>in <b>bone.</b><font color=""#0080ac""><br></font>When
a <b>vessel </b>is <b>damaged</b> as a result of <b>fracture</b>, pericytes are
<b>activated</b> and begin to <b>proliferate</b>.<font color=""#0080ac""><br></font>Once <b>activated</b>, pericytes<b>
differentiate </b>into <b>osteoblasts or chondrocytes</b> depending on
the <b>local microenvironment</b>.<font color=""#0080ac""><br></font>The m<b>ost significant source
</b>of pericytes for <b>fracture healing</b> is the <b>vasculature</b> of the
<b>periosteum</b> and <b>endosteum</b>.<span style=""color: rgb(0, 128, 172);"">&nbsp;</span></div>

<div><b>{{c1::SOX-9}} </b>is a key <b>transcription facto</b>r involved in the<b> differentiation</b> of cells towards the <b>{{c2::cartilage}}&nbsp;lineage</b></div>	"SOX-9 <b style="""">binds</b> to a <b style="""">critical consensus sequence</b> in the collagen 2 (<b style="""">Col2</b>) <b style="""">promoter</b> to <b style="""">activate</b> its transcription. <br><b style="""">Formation </b>of the <b style="""">cartilage template</b> involves a <b style="""">multi-step process</b> in which <b style="""">prechondrogenic mesenchymal cells</b> form <b style="""">condensations</b> <i style="""">prior</i> to differentiating into <b style="""">matrix-producing chondroblasts</b>. <br><br><b style="""">Retinoids</b>, particularly retinoic acid, are among the numerous <b style="""">signaling molecules</b> that have been <b style="""">implicated</b> in this process. <br>Efforts aimed at understanding the mechanisms by which expression of retinoic acid receptor attenuates chondroblast differentiation led to the discovery of the transcriptional activity of SOX-9.<br><br><img src=""F8.large.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::BiologicTissues::Cartilage"

What constitutes <b>Kellgren-Lawrence Grade 2 OA</b> of the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Possible <u>Mild</u> joint space narrowing, <u>Definite</u> osteophyte formation}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.40.35 PM.png"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"										"#ortho::PP::Knee::GeneralAnatomy"
What constitutes <b>Kellgren-Lawrence Grade 3 OA</b> of the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Moderate joint space narrowing, moderate multiple osteophytes, some sclerosis}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.40.35 PM.png"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"										"#ortho::PP::Knee::GeneralAnatomy"
What constitutes <b>Kellgren-Lawrence Grade 4 OA</b> of the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Severe joint space narrowing, Large Osteophytes, Severe Sclerosis, deformity of bone contour}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.40.35 PM.png"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"										"#ortho::PP::Knee::GeneralAnatomy"
The <b>diaphysis</b> of long bones is composed of <b>thick</b> {{c1::cortical}} <b>bone</b> surrounding a <b>central canal </b>of {{c1::cancellous}} <b>bone</b>, with an <b>outer region covered</b> by {{c1::periosteum}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"	"Cortical Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 450px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img src=""cancellous.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img src=""woven bone.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 403px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 215px;"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
The <b>metaphysis</b> of long bones is composed of <b>thin</b> {{c1::cortical}} bone <b>surrounding loose</b> {{c1::cancellous}} <b>bone</b>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"	"Cortical Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 450px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img src=""cancellous.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img src=""woven bone.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 403px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 215px;"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
<div>The <b>Epiphysis</b>&nbsp;of long bones contains the {{c1::physis}} and the {{c1::subchondral}} <b>region <u>under</u></b> the {{c1::articular}} cartilage</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"	"Cortical Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 450px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img src=""cancellous.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img src=""woven bone.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 403px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 215px;"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
<div><b>Flat</b> bones have a <b>varied</b> structure of either <b>purely </b>{{c1::cortical}} <b>bone</b> or {{c1::cortical}} <b>bone</b> with a <b>thin, central</b> {{c1::trabecular}} <b>region</b><br></div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"	"Cortical Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""cancellous.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""woven bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" style=""width: 215px;"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
<b>Cortical</b> bone makes up {{c1::80}}% of the skeleton	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"	"Cortical Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""cancellous.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""woven bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" style=""width: 215px;"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"

<div><br></div>

<div><b>Cancellous&nbsp;</b>bone is characterized by&nbsp;{{c1::fast}}&nbsp;<b>turnover rate</b>&nbsp;and {{c1::low}}&nbsp;<b>Young's modulus</b><br></div>	More elastic<br><br>High turnover allows to remodel according to stress across bone	"Cortical Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""cancellous.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""woven bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" style=""width: 215px;"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
Compared to lamellar bone, <b>Woven bone</b> has:<br><br>{{c1::More}} osteocytes per unit of volume<br>{{c1::Higher}} rate of turnover	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"	"Cortical Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""cancellous.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""woven bone.jpg"" style=""width: 350px;""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img class=""resizer"" src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"" style=""width: 215px;"">"									"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
Is <b>Lamellar </b>or&nbsp;<b>Woven bone</b> stress-oriented?<br><br>{{c1::Lamellar}}&nbsp;	"woven is immature or pathologic bone, random and not stress oriented<br>lamellar is secondary bone created by remodeling woven bone<br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.48.17 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.07 PM.png"" class=""resizer""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 4.49.27 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"			"Cortical Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone.jpg""><br><br>Cancellous Bone:<br><img src=""cancellous.jpg""><br><br>Woven Bone:<br><img src=""woven bone.jpg""><br><br>Lamellar Bone:<br><img src=""lamellar bone histo.jpg"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Types"
All <b>bone cells</b> <i><u>except</u></i> <b>{{c1::Osteoclasts}}</b> originate from <b>{{c2::Mesenchymal Stem}}</b> Cells	"<div>Originate from&nbsp;<b>myeloid hematopoietic</b> cells from <b>monocyte/macrophage cell lineage</b><br><div><b>Monocyte progenitors fuse</b> together to form <b>mature multinuclear</b> cells<br></div></div><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.19.43 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.12 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.37 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.10 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.42 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br>"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
<b>Osteoblasts</b> contain {{c1::increased}} amounts of <b>Endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus</b>, and <b>Mitochondria</b>&nbsp;compared to other cells	"Allows for <b>synthesis</b> and <b>secretion</b> of <b>bone matrix</b><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.19.43 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.12 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.37 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.10 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.42 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
"<div><b>Osteoblasts</b> <u>form bone</u>&nbsp;by producing <b>non-mineralized matrix</b>, secreting:</div>

<div><b>Stable beta-catenin</b>&nbsp;plays a <b>major role</b> in <b>inducing </b>cells to form {{c1::osteoblasts}} with resulting {{c1::intramembranous}} bone formation</div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.19.43 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.12 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.37 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.10 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.42 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"

<div><b>Osteoblastic regulation</b> of {{c2::<b>hematopoietic</b>}} cells and {{c2::<b>immune</b>}} response occurs through the <b>{{c1::Jagged1-Notch}}&nbsp;pathway</b></div>	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.19.43 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.12 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.37 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.10 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;""><img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.42 PM.png"" style=""width: 953px;"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
<div>{{c1::<b>PTH</b>}} induces <b>Jagged1</b> on <b>Osteoblasts</b>, which <b>stimulates Notch receptors</b> on the <b>membrane</b> of <b>{{c2::hematopoietic stem}}&nbsp;cells</b> which results in <b>cell proliferation</b><br></div>				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.19.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.12 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.10 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.42 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
"Steps in <b>Osteoclast Bone Resorption Cycle</b>:<br><ol>
<li>{{c1::<b>Migration</b> to <b>resorption site</b>}}</li>
<li>{{c1::Bone <b>attachment</b>}}</li>
<li>{{c1::<b>Polarization</b> (formation of membrane <b>domains</b>)}}</li>
<li><b>Dissolution </b>of&nbsp;{{c2::<b>hydroxyapatite</b>}}</li>
<li><b>Degradation</b> of {{c2::organic <b>matrix</b>}}</li>
<li><b>Removal</b> of&nbsp;{{c2::<b>degradation products</b>}}&nbsp;from&nbsp;{{c2::<b>resorption lacuna</b>}}</li>
<li>{{c3::<b>Apoptosis </b>of the <b>osteoclasts</b>}}&nbsp;or&nbsp;{{c3::<b>return</b> to the <b>non-resorbing</b> stage}}</li></ol>"	"<img src=""osteoclast.jpg"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.19.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.12 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.20.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.10 PM.png""><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 5.22.42 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
<b>Osteoclastic bone resorption</b> occurs at the {{c1::ruffled border}}	"<img src=""osteoclast.jpeg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><img src=""69_05.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 400px;""><br>"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 6.38.03 PM.png"" style=""width: 911px;""><br>"							https://www.orthobullets.com/basic-science/9002/bone-cells		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
<div><b>{{c1::Howship's lacunae}}</b> are the <b>site </b>of <b>bone resorption</b> where the&nbsp;<b>{{c2::ruffled border}}</b> meets <b>{{c2::bone surface}}</b></div>	"<img src=""osteoclast.jpeg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;""><br><img src=""69_05.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 400px;""><br>"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 6.38.03 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
<div>{{c1::Tartrate resistant acid phosphate (<b>TRAP</b>)}} is secreted by <b>osteoclasts</b>&nbsp;during bone <b>resorption</b> to <b>lower</b> the {{c2::<b>pH</b> (utilizing <b>carbonic anhydrase</b>)}} and <b>increase </b>the {{c2::<b>solubility</b> of <b>hydroxyapatite</b> crystals}}</div>	"<b>Deficiency</b> of <b>carbonic anhydrase</b> <u>prevents</u> <b>bone resorption</b><br><br><img src=""osteoclast.jpeg"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br><img src=""69_05.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br>"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 6.38.03 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"
<div>{{c1::<b>Cathepsin K</b>}} is one major <b>proteolytic enzyme</b> that <b>digests&nbsp;</b>{{c2::<b>organic matrix</b>}} at the&nbsp;<b>ruffled border<br></b></div>	"<img src=""osteoclast.jpeg"" class=""resizer"" style=""""><br><img src=""69_05.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style="""">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-07 at 6.38.03 PM.png"">"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Bone::Cells"

"<div>What are <b>4 surgical techniques</b> to <b>enhance fixation f</b>or the management of an <b>ankle fracture </b>in a <b>diabetic </b>patient?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Multiple <b>Quadricortical Syndesmotic screws</b> (even in the <b>absence </b>of syndesmotic injury)}}</div>

<div>{{c3::Augment with <b>intramedullary fibula K-wires</b>}}</div>
<div>{{c4::<b>Stiffer, more rigid fibular plates</b> (instead of 1/3 tubular plates) <b>compression plates, small fragment locking plates</b>}}</div>"	Will achieve the <b>most reliable anatomic reduction</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1047/ankle-fractures"">Orthobullets - Ankle Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Ankle::Ankle_Fx"

"<div>What is the effect of <b>reaming </b>on<b> union rates </b>in <b>Closed</b><b> Tibial shaft Fxs treated </b>with<b> IMN</b>?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Reamed may have <u>Higher Union Rates</u> and <u>Lower time to Union</u> than Unreamed (controversial)}}<br></div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1045/tibial-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Shaft Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::TibialShaft::ShaftFxs"
"<div>What are the <b>3 main indications </b>for <b>ORIF </b>of <b>Tibial</b> <b>Shaft</b> Fractures?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div><b>Proximal tibia </b>fractures with&nbsp;{{c1::<b>inadequate proximal</b> fixation from <b>IM nailing</b>}}</div>
<div><b>Distal tibia </b>fractures with&nbsp;{{c1::<b>inadequate distal</b> fixation from <b>IM nail</b>}}</div>
<div><b>Tibia fractures </b>in the <b>setting </b>of adjacent {{c2::<b>implant/hardware </b>(i.e. prior TKA)}}</div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1045/tibial-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Shaft Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::TibialShaft::ShaftFxs"
Compared to <b>IM nailing</b> of <b>Tibial shaft</b> fractures, a benefit of&nbsp;<b>ORIF</b>&nbsp;is that it shows possibly <b>less</b> {{c1::angular deformity}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1045/tibial-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Shaft Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::TibialShaft::ShaftFxs"
"<div>What are the indications for the use of <b>BMP-2 </b>augmentation in <b>Tibia Fractures</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>Prior studies</b> have demonstrated <u>some</u> use in&nbsp;{{c1::open tibial shaft fractures}}<br></div>"	controversial usage but in theory will show faster union rates, earlier mobilization, lower rates of revision, less risk for infection								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1045/tibial-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Shaft Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::TibialShaft::ShaftFxs"
"<div>What are <b>5 theoretical benefits </b>of <b>BMP-2 </b>augmentation in <b>open tibial shaft </b>fractures?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div><b>Accelerate</b> {{c1::early fracture healing}}<br><b>
Decrease rate</b> of {{c1::hardware failure}}<br><b>
Decrease need</b> for subsequent {{c1::autologous bone-grafting}}<br><b>
Decrease need</b> for {{c1::secondary invasive procedures}}<br><b>
Decrease</b> {{c1::infection}} rate</div>"	(controversial, as recent studies have not fully supported these findings)								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1045/tibial-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Shaft Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::TibialShaft::ShaftFxs"
<div>A <b>relative</b> indication for <b>amputation</b> in a <b>tibial shaft fracture</b> is <b>warm ischemia</b> &gt; {{c1::6 hrs}}</div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">The most important factor herein is warm ischemic time, defined as&nbsp;</span><b>the time a tissue, organ, or body part remains at body temperature after its blood supply has been reduced or cut off but before it is cooled, further processed, or reconnected to a blood supply</b><span style=""color: rgb(77, 81, 86);"">.<br></span><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-14 at 12.01.29 PM.png"" class=""resizer"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1045/tibial-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Shaft Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::TibialShaft::ShaftFxs"

No local {{c1::infection}}</div>"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-25 at 3.11.33 PM.png"">"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1034/acetabular-fractures"">Orthobullets - Acetabulum Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::Pelvic::Acetabulum::TabFxs"

"<div>What <b>5 fracture characteristics </b>are <b>indications </b>for<b> ORIF </b>of <b>Acetabulum</b> Fxs?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div><b>Displacement </b>of<b> Roof </b>(&gt; {{c1::2 mm}})</div><div>{{c1::<b>Unstable}}&nbsp;</b>fracture<b> pattern </b>(e.g. {{c1::<b>Posterior Wall</b> fracture involving <b>&gt; 40-50%</b>}})</div><div><b>{{c2::Marginal impaction}}<br>Intra-articular&nbsp;</b><b>{{c2::L</b><b>oose bodies}}</b></div><div><b>Irreducible&nbsp;</b><b>{{c3::F</b><b>racture-dislocation}}</b></div>"	"<div>The term “<b>marginal impaction</b>” describes a severe form of<b> intraarticular hip fracture</b> in which the <b>affected articular fragment</b> and <b>subchondral bone</b> are <b>rotated</b> and <b>impacted against</b> the <b>underlying cancellous bone</b> along the <b>fracture margin<br><br></b><div><br><img src=""04_14_12451_01c_cmyk.gif"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 675px;""><br><b>Fracture-dislocation</b> with <b>posterior wall fragments</b> associated with <b>marginal impaction</b> (<i>arrow</i>). Note that <b>a</b><b>ffected articular fragment</b> and <b>subchondral bone (<i>blue</i>)</b> are <b>perpendicular</b> to <b>Femoral head </b>(FH) and <b>Acetabular margin</b>.</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-25 at 3.11.33 PM.png"">"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1034/acetabular-fractures"">Orthobullets - Acetabulum Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::Pelvic::Acetabulum::TabFxs"
"<div>What are <b>3 column fixation </b>strategies<b> </b>for <b>Acetabulum </b>Fxs?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Reconstruction bridging plate and screws<br>
Percutaneous column screws<br>
Cable fixation}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12891-019-2422-6/MediaObjects/12891_2019_2422_Fig1_HTML.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 685px;""><br><img src=""paste-6cf02a622215d0ce94f7e4b6a922e3503ae42067.jpg"" class=""resizer"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-25 at 3.11.33 PM.png"">"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1034/acetabular-fractures"">Orthobullets - Acetabulum Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::Pelvic::Acetabulum::TabFxs"

"<div>What are <b>3 indications </b>for <b>nonoperative </b>management of <b>Tibial Plateau Fxs</b>?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div><b>Minimally</b> displaced {{c1::split}} or {{c1::depressed}} fractures</div>
<div><b>Low energy</b> fracture <b>stable</b> to {{c1::varus/valgus}} alignment</div>
