"<div>What is <b>1 Tibial Plateau </b>fracture <b>pattern </b>amenable to <b>non-locked buttress plates?</b></div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div>{{c1::<u>Simple partial articular</u> fractures in <u>healthy bone</u>}}<br></div>"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/proximal-tibia/partial-articular-fracture-split/orif-plates-without-angular-stability"">AO: Tibial Plateau Fx ORIF - Plates without angular stability</a><br><br><u><b>Type B </b>Fracture = <b>Buttress</b> Plate</u><br><br><img src=""41_o12_i06_conventional_plating_b1.ashx"" style=""width: 620px;"" class=""resizer"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1044/tibial-plateau-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Plateau Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Knee::TibialPlateau"
<div><b>Cortical screws</b> are designed to be used in bone with <b>dense trabecular architecture</b>, so they <b>maximize</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Core Diameter}} at the <b>expense</b> of <b>limiting</b> the {{c1::Inner:Outer diameter Ratio&nbsp;}}</div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-16 at 6.01.13 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Misc_Books::SkeletalTrauma::9_InternalFixation"
"<div><b>Cancellous</b> screws are designed to be used in <b>bone with loose trabecular</b> architecture, requiring <b>design</b> to&nbsp;<b style="""">sacrifice&nbsp;</b>{{c1::<b>bending resistance</b>&nbsp;(Core Diameter)}}&nbsp;in order to&nbsp;<b>maximize </b>the<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c1::<b>pullout </b>strength resistance}}&nbsp;</div>"	"<div><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Bending strength</b>&nbsp;of a&nbsp;<b>screw</b>&nbsp;is proportional to <b>I</b></span><b>nner</b> (Core) <b>diameter^3<br></b><br><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>Screw pullout strength</b>&nbsp;is proportional to&nbsp;</span><b>Outer</b> (major)<b> diameter^2 </b>- Maximized by Large outer diameter difference &amp; Fine Pitch<br><br>In <b>cancellous</b> bone, the area that confers the <b>greatest resistance</b> to<b> pullout</b> is the <b>intramedullary portion</b> (because cortical bone is extremely thin at the metaphyseal and epiphyseal level). <br>The<b> intramedullary</b> portion consists of <b>loosely packed trabeculae</b> that m<b>ay or may not contact</b> the <b>screw threads</b> at the <b>outer diameter</b>. <br>Because of this, the <b>design</b> of the screw represents an attempt to <b>capture contact with as many trabeculae as possible</b>, understanding that <b>they may not be at the periphery or outer diameter</b> of the screw. <br>In this sense, a sacrifice is made by <b>marginalizing the inner diameter</b> of the screw to have<b> more trabecular contact area with the thread</b>. <br></div><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-16 at 6.01.13 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 911px;""><br><br>"										"#Ortho::Misc_Books::SkeletalTrauma::9_InternalFixation"

"What are the<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">&nbsp;advantages</span> of <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Reamed Femoral Nailing</span> over <b>U</b><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">nreamed </span>nailing?<br><br>{{c1::<b><u>Disrupts endosteal</u> blood</b> supply, but <u><b>stimulates soft tissue</b> and </u><b><u>periosteal</u> blood supply</b> to fracture (periosteal and soft tissue blood supply is predominate source after fracture)}}<br>{{c2::<b>Extrudes medullary contents</b> into fracture site (<b>Autologous bone grafting</b>)}}<br>{{c3::Allows for a <b>larger diameter nail</b> to be placed (larger nail is <b><u>Stiffer</u></b> and is related to the <u>diameter<sup>4</sup></u>)}}<br>{{c4::<b>Increases</b> the area of <b>isthmic contact</b> with <b>Nail</b>}}<br>{{c5::<b>NO increase</b> in <b>Infection</b> rates after reaming <b>Open </b>Fractures}}"	"<img src=""paste-510b1c6c30400a43c288a715f6b867f72d56a4c3.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1040/femoral-shaft-fractures"">AO: Femoral Shaft Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Shaft&Distal_Femur::ShaftFx"

"<div>What are the <b>techniques</b> to <b>reduce</b> an <b>Anterior Glenohumeral Dislocation</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Hippocratic}}</div>
<div>{{c1::Rockwood’s traction–countertraction}}</div>
<div>{{c1::Stimson}}</div>
<div>{{c1::Milch}}</div>

"<div>What <b>percentage</b> of <b>Calcaneus</b> fractures are <b>Intra-articular</b>?</div>

"<div>What are the <b>Three most common</b> associated <b>orthopedic</b> injuries with <b>calcaneus </b>fractures?</div>

"<div>What are <b>5 benefits</b> of the <b>sinus tarsi</b> approach for the <b>surgical</b> treatment of <b>calcaneus</b> fractures?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div><b>Reduces Wound Complications</b> associated with {{c1::<b>extensile lateral</b> incision}}</div>
<div>Allows <b>direct visualization</b> of the<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c1::<b>posterior facet</b>, <b>anterolateral fragment</b>, and<b> lateral wall</b>}}<br>
<b>Lower incidence</b> of {{c2::<b>sural </b>nerve}}&nbsp;<b>neuralgia</b><br>
<b>Same incision</b> can be utilized for {{c2::<b>secondary subtalar arthrodesis</b> or <b>peroneal tendon debridement</b>}}<br>
<b>Decreased surgical time</b><br></div>"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/calcaneous/approach/sinus-tarsi-approach-to-the-calcaneus"">AO: Sinus Tarsi Approach to the Calcaneus</a><br><a href=""https://www.vumedi.com/video/minimally-invasive-technique-for-calcaneus-fractures/"">VuMedi: Surgical Fixation of Intra-Articular Calcaneus Fractures Using a Sinus Tarsi Approach</a><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-22 at 1.10.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-22 at 1.11.04 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1051/calcaneus-fractures"">Orthobullets: Calcaneus Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Hindfoot::CalcaneusFx"
"<div>What are <b>4 benefits</b> of <b>arthroscopic-assisted reduction </b>and <b>internal fixation </b>of <b>Calcaneus</b> fractures?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div><b>Decreased</b> {{c1::soft-tissue dissection}}</div>
<div><b>Preservation</b> of {{c1::local blood supply}}</div>
<div><b>Removal</b> of {{c1::loose bone fragments}}</div>
<div><b>Improved visualization</b> of {{c1::articular surface}} and {{c1::cartilage lesions}}</div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1051/calcaneus-fractures"">Orthobullets: Calcaneus Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Hindfoot::CalcaneusFx"
"<div>What is <b>nonoperative</b> management of <b>post-traumatic subtalar arthritis</b>?</div>

"<div>What are <b>3 </b>manifestations of <b>Calcaneus malunion</b>?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Loss of height}}</div>
<div>{{c1::Widening}}</div>
<div>{{c1::Lateral impingement}}</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-23 at 11.27.04 AM.png"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-22 at 1.49.38 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-22 at 1.50.17 PM.png"">"					"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1051/calcaneus-fractures"">Orthobullets: Calcaneus Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Hindfoot::CalcaneusFx"
<div>For <b>Schatzker II </b>fractures, <b>Lateral Meniscal</b> Injury is associated with <b>{{c2::Joint Depression}}&nbsp;&gt; {{c1::10 mm}} </b>and<b>&nbsp;Joint {{c2::Widening}}&nbsp;&gt; {{c1::6 mm}}</b></div>	"<img src=""s1_3dap.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 326px;"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2021-12-22 at 2.09.06 PM.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 953px;"">"						"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1044/tibial-plateau-fractures"">Orthobullets - Tibial Plateau Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Knee::TibialPlateau"
<div><b>Distal Radius </b>fractures account for {{c1::17.5}}% of all <b>fractures </b>in <b>adults</b></div>	"<div>More common in&nbsp;females&nbsp;(2-3:1)<br><br><div><u>Bimodal distribution</u>:</div>

"<div>What are the <b>4 </b>important&nbsp;<b>Mechanical Functions</b> of the <b>Radial Column </b>of the <b>Distal Radius</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><div>Serves as a <b>buttress</b> to <b>resist&nbsp;</b>{{c1::radial carpal translation}}</div><div>Functions as a {{c1::<b>load-bearing platform</b>}} for <b>activities</b> performed with the <b>wrist</b> in {{c1::<b>ulnar</b>}}<b>&nbsp;deviation</b></div><div><b>Holds</b> the <b>carpus</b> out <b>to length&nbsp;</b>{{c2::<b>radially</b>}}, allowing a <b>more uniform distribution</b> of load <b>across</b> the<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c2::<b>scaphoid</b> and <b>lunate facets</b>}}</div><div>Serves as an <b>anchor</b> for the {{c2::<b>radioscaphocapitate</b>}}<b>&nbsp;ligament</b> that <b>prevents&nbsp;</b>{{c2::<b>ulnar</b>}}<b>&nbsp;translation</b> of the <b>carpus</b></div></div>"	"<img src=""2-Figure1-1-014fdcdb4c97edd76e79064135c708d5e52447ab.png"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 662px;""><br><img src=""23_a100_i080.ashx"" class=""resizer"" style="""">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1027/distal-radius-fractures"">Orthobullets: Distal Radius Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Forearm::DistalRadiusFx"

What is the&nbsp;<b>definition</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>calculation&nbsp;</b>of&nbsp;<b>Strain</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Relative measure of the <u>Deformation</u> of an object, Strain = Change in Length / Original Length}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/basic-science/9062/material-properties"">Orthobullets: Material Properties</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Materials::MaterialProperties"
What is the&nbsp;<b>definition</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>Elastic Deformation</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Reversible</u> changes in Shape to a material due to a Load<br>Material <u>Returns to Original</u> Shape when Load is <u>Removed</u>}}	"<img src=""elastic deformation.jpg"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/basic-science/9062/material-properties"">Orthobullets: Material Properties</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Materials::MaterialProperties"
What is the&nbsp;<b>definition</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>Plastic Deformation</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Irreversible</u> changes in Shape to a material due to a Load<br>Material <u>DOES NOT Return</u> to Original Shape when Load is <u>Removed</u>}}	"<img src=""elastic deformation.jpg"" style="""" class=""resizer"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/basic-science/9062/material-properties"">Orthobullets: Material Properties</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Materials::MaterialProperties"

"<div>Relative values of <b>Young's modulus</b> of <b>Elasticity</b> (Alloy, Ceramic, Cortical Bone, Stainless steel, Titanium)</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>1. {{c1::Ceramic (Al2O3)}}</div>
<div>2. {{c1::Alloy (Co-Cr-Mo)}}</div>
<div>3. {{c1::Stainless steel}}</div>
<div>4. {{c1::Titanium}}</div>
<div>5. {{c1::Cortical bone}}</div>"	"<div><b>Young's modulus</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>elasticity</b>&nbsp;= Measure of the&nbsp;<b>stiffness</b>&nbsp;(ability to&nbsp;<b>resist deformation</b>) of a material in the&nbsp;<b>elastic zone</b></div><div>Calculated by&nbsp;<b>measuring</b>&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>slope</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>stress/strain curve</b>&nbsp;in the&nbsp;<b>elastic zone</b><br><b>Higher&nbsp;</b>modulus of elasticity indicates a&nbsp;<b>stiffer&nbsp;</b>material</div><br><img src=""Basic Stress Strain Curve_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 350px;""><br>"	"<img src=""paste-d126e4677cfa7be625e27180964856bc04bfb841.jpg"">"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/basic-science/9062/material-properties"">Orthobullets: Material Properties</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::BasicScience::MSK_Science::Materials::MaterialProperties"

What are <b>4 </b>types of <b>ACL graft fixation </b>options?<br><br>{{c1::I<b>nterference Screws</b> (<b>aperture/compression</b> fixation)}} <br>{{c1::<b>Cortical Buttons</b> (<b>suspensory</b> fixation)}} <br>{{c2::<b>Screw</b> and <b>Washer Post</b> (<b>suspensory</b> fixation)}} <br>{{c2::<b>Staple</b> (<b>suspensory</b> fixation)}}	Can be used <b>alone</b> (i.e. <b>all-inside suspensory</b> fixation) or in <b>combination</b> (i.e. <b>interference screw</b> with <b>screw</b> and <b>washer post</b>)&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"

<div>What are the <b>6 types</b> of <b>exercises</b> to focus on during <b>early rehab</b> following<b> ACL recon</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b>Eccentric</b> Strengthening at 3 weeks}}<br>{{c1::<b>isometric hamstring contractions</b> at any angle}}&nbsp;<br>{{c2::<b>isometric quadriceps</b>, or simultaneous <b>quadriceps</b> and <b>hamstrings contraction</b> }}<br>{{c2::<b>Active knee motion</b> between <u><b>35 </b>degrees and <b>90</b> degrees</u> of <b>FLEXION</b> }}<br>{{c3::<b>Core </b>and <b>gluteal </b>strengthening incorporated <b>throughout</b> therapy }}<br>{{c3::Emphasize <b>closed chain</b> (<b>foot planted</b>) exercises (i.e. <b>squats</b> or <b>leg-press</b>)}}</div>	"<img src=""acl_rehab.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"
What are<b> exercises </b>that <b>female</b> athletes can do to <b>reduce risk </b>of <b>ACL rupture</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Neuromuscular</u> training/<u>plyometrics</u> (jump training)}}&nbsp;<br>{{c1::Land from Jumping in <u>less valgus</u> and <u>more knee flexion</u>}}&nbsp;<br>{{c1::increasing <u>hamstring strength</u> to <u>decrease quadriceps dominance</u> ratio}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-01-18 at 1.34.08 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"
What are the <b>2 </b>common<b> intra-operative ACL </b>reconstruction <b>complications</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Graft-tunnel mismatch <br>Posterior wall blowout}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(17, 17, 17); background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"">Graft-tunnel mismatch (GTMM) is&nbsp;</span><strong>a condition in which the ACL BTB autograft does not match the intra-articular and tunnel length<br></strong><img alt=""Management of graft-tunnel mismatch when the majority of the tibial ..."" src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/356887734/figure/fig4/AS:1098917638864907@1639013790931/Management-of-graft-tunnel-mismatch-when-the-majority-of-the-tibial-bone-block-is.ppm"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"

"Besides <b>tunnel malposition, </b>what are <b>5 causes </b>of <b>ACL graft failure</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b>Inadequate graft fixation</b> or <b>hardware failure</b> (can be caused by <b>graft-screw divergence &gt; 30<span style=""font-size: 13.3333px;""><sup>o</sup></span></b>)}}<br>{{c2::<b>Attritional graft failure</b> (graft <b>less</b> than <b>8 mm</b> in <b>width</b>)}}<br>{{c3::<b>Intra-articular</b> femoral <b>bone plug <u>dislodgement </u></b>}}<br>{{c4::<b>Missed diagnosis </b>of concomitant <b>ligamentous injuries</b> (in c<b>ombined ACL</b> and <b>PLC </b>injuries, <b>failure </b>to <b>treat</b> the <b>PLC</b> will <b>overload </b>graft and lead to <b>failure</b>)}}<br>{{c5::<b>Over-aggressive</b> or <b>improper rehab</b>}}"	"<img alt=""Acl graft fixation options"" src=""https://image.slidesharecdn.com/aclgraftfixationoptions2-130610151456-phpapp01/95/acl-graft-fixation-options-23-638.jpg?cb=1370877381""><br><img src=""acl_failures.jpg""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-01-16 at 10.23.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""acl_vertical_graft_moved.jpg"" class=""resizer"" style=""width: 938px;"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"
"<div>What is the<b> risk </b>of <b>Infection</b> and <b>septic arthritis </b>following <b>ACL recon </b>how do you <b>treat </b>it?</div>
<div><br>{{c1::Less than 1%; immediate arthroscopic I&amp;D&nbsp;}}</div>"	<div>Often can <b>retain graft</b> with <b>multiple I&amp;Ds</b> and <b>antibiotics</b> (<b>6 weeks</b> minimum)&nbsp;</div><div><b>More likely</b> to be <b>successful </b>with <b>S. epidermidis</b>, <b>less likely</b> with <b>S. aureus</b></div>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"

"<div>What is the <b>number 1 pre-operative</b> method to <b>prevent post-operative stiffness</b>&nbsp;following <b>ACL </b>reconstruction?</div>
<div><b></b><br></div>
<div>{{c1::<b><u>Wait</u> </b>until patient has <u>regained </u><b><u>full ROM</u> </b>before you operate <b>(""pre-hab"") </b>}}<b><br></b></div>"	<b>Wait&nbsp;</b>until&nbsp;<b>swelling (inflammatory phase)</b>&nbsp;has<b>&nbsp;gone down</b>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<b>reduce&nbsp;</b>the incidence of&nbsp;<b>arthrofibrosis</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3008/acl-tear"">Orthobullets: ACL Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::ACL"
"<div>What is a <b>risk factor </b>for <b>late post-operative</b> knee <b>osteoarthritis</b> following<b> ACL</b> reconstruction?</div>

"<div>What is <b>Femoroacetabular Impingement?</b></div>
<div><br>{{c1::The <u>abnormal contact</u> between the <u>femur and acetabulum</u> which may lead to <u>labral damage</u>, various degrees of <u>chondral injury,</u> and <u>progressive hip pain</u>.}}</div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3130/femoroacetabular-impingement"">Orthobullets: FAI</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::LowerExtremity::Hip_Sports::FAI"
What are <b>3 injuries</b> <b>associated </b>with <b>FAI?<br><br></b>{{c1::<u>Labral</u> degeneration and tears<br><u>Cartilage</u> damage and <u>Flap</u> tears<br>Secondary hip <u>Osteoarthritis</u>}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3130/femoroacetabular-impingement"">Orthobullets: FAI</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::LowerExtremity::Hip_Sports::FAI"

"<div>In <b>Strength Training</b>, what are <b>increases</b> in <b>strength</b> due to?</div>
<div><br></div>

"<div><b>Weight</b> Training Effects on <b>muscles:</b></div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>Increased</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Cross-Sectional Area}}<br>
<b>Increased</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Strength}}</div><div>
<b>Increased</b>&nbsp;number of {{c1::Mitochondria}}</div><div>
<b>Increased</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Capillary Density}}</div><div>
<b>Thickened</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Connective Tissue}}</div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
<div><b>Magnitude</b> of <b>core temperature</b> and <b>heart rate increase</b> accompanying work are&nbsp;<b>proportional</b> to the <b>magnitude</b> of {{c1::water debt}}&nbsp;at the <b>onset </b>of<b> exercise</b><br></div>	Best technique is to Replace enough <b>Water</b> to&nbsp;<b>Maintain Prepractice weight</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
<div><b>Fluid carbohydrate</b> and <b>electrolyte replacement</b> is best done with&nbsp;{{c1::low (&lt; 10%)}} <b>osmolarity&nbsp;fluids</b> of <b>carbohydrates </b>and <b>electrolytes</b>, which&nbsp;<b>enhances absorption</b> in the <b>gut</b></div>	Glucose Polymers Decrease Osmolarity								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
"<div>What is the <b>cause</b> of <b>Muscle Soreness</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Edema &amp; Inflammation&nbsp;in the Connective Tissue}}</div>"	Leads to&nbsp;<b>increased Intramuscular Pressure</b><br>Occurs primarily in&nbsp;<b>Type IIB fibers</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
"<div>What type of exercise causes the most <b>Muscle Soreness</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Unaccustomed <u>Eccentric</u> exercise}}</div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
In <b>Delayed-Onset Muscle Soreness</b>, there can be <b>elevated </b>{{c1::CK}} levels in the <b>serum</b>									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
<b>Muscle strain</b> occurs most<b> commonly</b> at&nbsp;the {{c1::Myotendinous Junction}}&nbsp;(often during {{c1::Eccentric}} <b>contraction</b>&nbsp;which produces <b>highest forces</b> in <b>skeletal muscle</b>)	Pathoanatomy in inflammation followed by fibrosis								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3118/exercise-science"">Orthobullets: Exercise Science</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Team::Physician::Exercise_Science"
"<div>During <b>PCL injury</b>, what is the most common <b>position </b>of the <b>knee </b>and <b>ankle?</b></div>

"<div>What is the <b>function </b>of the <b>PCL</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>PCL</b> is the <b>primary restraint</b> to {{c1::Posterior Tibial Translation}}<br>
Functions to<b> prevent</b> {{c1::Hyperflexion/Sliding}}<br>
<b>Isolated</b> injuries cause the <b>greatest instability</b> at {{c1::<b>90°</b> of <b>flexion</b>}}</div>"	"<div><img src=""paste-d83878b8ea2b0e4ef72da8df73d5f58cfe12e8f2.jpg""><br></div><img src=""pcl anatomy.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3009/pcl-injury"">Orthobullets: PCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::PCL"

PCL</b> is <b>{{c2::30}}% {{c2::Larger::Larger/Smaller?}}</b> than the <b>ACL</b><br></div>"	"<img src=""pcl anatomy.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3009/pcl-injury"">Orthobullets: PCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::PCL"
"<div>The&nbsp;<b>{{c2::Anterolateral}}</b>&nbsp;bundle of the<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;</span><b>PCL</b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<b>tight</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;in&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Flexion}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-weight: 700;""><br></span>The <b>{{c2::Posteromedial}}&nbsp;</b>bundle of the <b>PCL</b> is <b>tight</b> in <b>{{c1::Extension}}</b></div>"	"<img src=""pcl cadaver bundle anatomy.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3009/pcl-injury"">Orthobullets: PCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::PCL"

"<div>How do you perform a <b>Posterior Drawer</b> test?</div>

"<div>For <b>PCL </b>injury, what is the <b>biggest advantage </b>of performing the<b> Open (tibial inlay) Reconstruction?</b></div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::<u>Biomechanical Advantage</u> with a Decrease in the “Killer Turn"" with <u>Less Graft Attenuation and Failure</u>}}<br></div>"	&nbsp; The residual laxity after transtibial posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) reconstruction has been reported by several authors. The sharp angle where the graft exits the tibial tunnel, which is known as “killer turn”, is believed to be the main reason.&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/knee-and-sports/3009/pcl-injury"">Orthobullets: PCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Knee&Sports::Knee::Ligament_Injury::PCL"

"<div>What is the <b>Sensitivity </b>and<b> Specificity</b> of an<b> Ultrasound </b>compared to an <b>MRI </b>for<b> </b>suspected <b>rotator cuff</b> tears?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Similar sensitivity, specificity, and overall accuracy for diagnosis}}</div>"	<b>23%</b> of <b>asymptomatic</b> patients had a rotator cuff <b>tear</b> on <b>ultrasound</b> in <b>one series</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3043/rotator-cuff-tears"">Orthobullets: Rotator Cuff Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Impingment_RotatorCuff::Cuff_Tears"
"<div>Are <b>Articular</b>-sided (<b>PASTA</b> Lesions) or <b>Bursal</b>-sided<b> Rotator Cuff </b>tears treated <b>more aggressively</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Bursal-sided}}</div>"	Bursal is on the tension side!! &nbsp;&gt;25% tear on bursal side is operative vs &gt;50% for articular&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3043/rotator-cuff-tears"">Orthobullets: Rotator Cuff Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Impingment_RotatorCuff::Cuff_Tears"
"<div>What <b>modalities </b>are included in<b> Nonoperative </b>management of <b>rotator cuff</b> tears?</div>
<br>
<div>{{c1::Physical therapy, NSAIDS, Subacromial Corticosteroid injections}}</div>"	<div>Technique:</div><div><b>Avoidance</b> of <b>overhead</b> activities<br><b>PT</b> with <b>aggressive rotator cuff</b> and <b>scapular-stabilizer strengthening</b> over a <b>3-6 month</b> treatment course<br><b>Subacromial injections</b> if <b>impingement </b>thought to be <b>major cause</b> of <b>symptoms</b></div>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3043/rotator-cuff-tears"">Orthobullets: Rotator Cuff Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Impingment_RotatorCuff::Cuff_Tears"

"<div>What are the <b>indications </b>for a <b>rotator cuff repair</b>? (<b>Arthroscopic </b>or<b> Mini-Open</b>)</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::<b>Acute, full-thickness</b>}} tears<br>

<div><b>PASTA</b> with &gt; <b>7</b> mm of <b>exposed bony footprint</b> between the <b>articular surface</b> and <b>intact tendon</b> represents {{c5::<b>significant</b> (&gt;<b>50%</b>) cuff}}&nbsp;tear (<b>must</b> have at least <b>{{c5::25}}% healthy&nbsp;{{c5::bursal}}</b>-sided <b>tissue</b>)</div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3043/rotator-cuff-tears"">Orthobullets: Rotator Cuff Tears</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Impingment_RotatorCuff::Cuff_Tears"

<div><b>{{c1::Uncemented Extensively Porous-Coated Long-Stem}}&nbsp;</b>prosthesis&nbsp;(or <b>{{c1::porous-coated/grit blasted}}&nbsp;</b>combination) or <b>{{c2::Modular Tapered}}&nbsp;</b>stems</div>"	"<b>Extensively Porous-Coated Long-Stem:</b><br><img src=""extensively coated long-stem prosthesis.jpg""><br><br><b>XR Long-Stem</b> Prosthesis:<br><img src=""long stem radiograph.jpg""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-01-26 at 3.36.09 PM.png"">"	Single-taper stems have a reduction (taper) in medial-lateral dimension in the frontal plane but have a constant anteroposterior dimension. <div><div>What is <b>Spurling's </b>test?<br><br>{{c1::Simultaneous<u> Extension, Rotation</u> to <u>affected</u> side, <u>Lateral Bend</u>, and <u>Vertical Compression</u> reproduces symptoms in ipsilateral arm}}</div></div>	Test for Cervical Radiculopathy<br><br><b>Narrowing</b> of the <b>intervertebral foramina</b> causes <b>exacerbation</b> of symptoms								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2030/cervical-radiculopathy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Radiculopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Degenerative::Cervical::Radiculopathy"

What is the indication for <b>Cervical Disc Arthroplasty</b> for the treatment of Cervical <b>Radiculopathy</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Single Level</u> disease with <u>Minimal Arthrosis</u> of the <u>Facets</u> (controversial)}}	"<b>Cervical total disc arthroplasty</b>&nbsp;has been shown to be successful for treatment of&nbsp;<b>SELECT</b>&nbsp;patients with cervical&nbsp;<b>myelopathy&nbsp;</b>in whom&nbsp;<u><b>spinal cord compression</b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<b>localized</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>level</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>disc space</b>&nbsp;(<b>retrodiscal</b>)</u>.&nbsp;<br><br>This procedure is NOT appropriate for patients with&nbsp;<b>severe facet joint degenerative changes</b>&nbsp;at the&nbsp;<b>operative level</b>,&nbsp;<b>severe loss&nbsp;</b>of&nbsp;<b>disc space height</b>,&nbsp;<b>myelopathy</b>&nbsp;due to&nbsp;<b>congenital spinal canal narrowing</b>, and&nbsp;<b>cervical stenosis</b>&nbsp;due to&nbsp;<b>retrovertebral cord compression</b>&nbsp;(e.g.,&nbsp;<b>ossification</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>posterior longitudinal ligament</b>).&nbsp;<br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-08 at 11.43.45 AM.png"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-21 at 11.22.09 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-21 at 11.22.26 AM.png"">"					"

<div><div>What is the <b>treatment </b>for a <b>recurrent laryngeal </b>nerve <b>injury</b> following an <b>ACDF</b>?<br><br><b>Initial </b>treatment: {{c1::Observation}}<br>If <b>no improvement </b>over <b>6 weeks</b>: {{c1::ENT consult to <u>scope</u> patient and <u>inject teflon</u>}}</div></div>	"<span style=""color: rgb(0, 29, 53);"">Teflon injection is&nbsp;a medical procedure that involves injecting a paste of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), commonly known as Teflon, into the vocal cords.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(0, 29, 53);"">This procedure is typically used to treat vocal cord paralysis, a condition that causes hoarseness and difficulty speaking.&nbsp;</span>"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-27 at 2.56.13 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-02-27 at 2.56.32 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2030/cervical-radiculopathy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Radiculopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Degenerative::Cervical::Radiculopathy"

<div><div>What <b>lab value</b> is considered an <b>independent risk factor</b> of&nbsp;<b>Pediatric Septic Hip&nbsp;</b>Arthritis?<br><br>{{c1::CRP}}</div></div>	<b>May rise</b> as soon as <b>6-8 hours after</b> injury or infection<br><br>CRP <b>&gt; 2.0</b> (mg/dl) is an <b>independent risk factor</b> (not included in studies of the previous 4 criteria)<br>CRP <b>&gt; 2.0 </b>(mg/dl) in <b>combination </b>with <b>refusal to bear weight</b> yields a <b>74% probability</b> of septic arthritis								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4032/hip-septic-arthritis--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Pediatric Septic Hip Arthritis</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Infection::SepticHip"

<div>What <b>aspect </b>of the <b>aspiration results </b>is the most <b>sensitive</b> for&nbsp;<b>Pediatric Septic Hip&nbsp;</b>Arthritis?<br><br>{{c1::<u>PMN percentage</u> more sensitive than total WBC count}}</div>	"<div>85% PMNs correlates with an 88% sensitivity.<br><br>A Septic joint Aspirate will show:<br>High WBC count (&gt; 50,000/mm<sup style="""">3</sup>&nbsp;with &gt;75% PMNs)<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);""><br></span></div>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4032/hip-septic-arthritis--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Pediatric Septic Hip Arthritis</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Infection::SepticHip"
<div>What are the 3<b>&nbsp;key differentials</b> in diagnosis of&nbsp;<b>Pediatric Septic Hip&nbsp;</b>Arthritis?</div><div><br>{{c1::Transient Synovitis}}<br>{{c1::Osteomyelitis}}&nbsp;<br>{{c1::JRA or now known as JIA}}<br></div>	Also need to keep TRAUMA on Ddx<br>Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis lasting greater than 6 weeks in a patient younger than 16 years of age that typically presents with morning joint stiffness and ocular infections.&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4032/hip-septic-arthritis--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Pediatric Septic Hip Arthritis</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Infection::SepticHip"
<div>What is the <b>gold standard treatment</b> of&nbsp;<b>Pediatric Septic Hip&nbsp;</b>Arthritis?</div><div><br>{{c1::Urgent surgical I&amp;D followed by IV antibiotics}}<br></div>	Standard of care for septic hip joints								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4032/hip-septic-arthritis--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Pediatric Septic Hip Arthritis</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Infection::SepticHip"

<div><div>What <b>percent</b> of<b> pediatric patients</b> with <b>Osteomyelitis</b> have a<b> history </b>of <b>trauma</b>?<br><br>{{c1::30%}}</div></div>	"Mechanism: <b>Local Trauma</b> and <b>Bacteremia</b> lead to <b>increased susceptibility</b> to <b>bacterial seeding</b> of the <b>metaphysis<br><br></b><img src=""osteomyelitis_septic_arthritis.jpg""><b><br></b>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4031/osteomyelitis--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Osteomyelitis (Peds)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Infection::Osteomyelitis"

<div><div>What is the<b> incidence</b> of <b>DDH </b>in <b>Females</b> vs. <b>Males</b>?<br><br>More common in&nbsp;{{c1::Females}}&nbsp;({{c1::6:1::Ratio}})</div></div>	"due to&nbsp;<span style=""background-color: rgb(201, 233, 249);"">increased ligamentous laxit</span>y that transiently exists as the result of circulating maternal hormones and the estrogens produced by the fetal uterus"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4118/developmental-dysplasia-of-the-hip-ddh"">Orthobullets: DDH</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::Hip&Pelvis::DDH"

What are <b>4 physical exam</b> findings of<b> DDH</b> in a child of <b>walking age</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Pelvic Obliquity}}<br>{{c1::Lumbar Lordosis}}<br>{{c1::Trendelenburg Gait}}<br>{{c1::Toe-Walking}}	Lumbar Lordosis - in response to <u><b>hip contractures</b></u> resulting from <u><b>bilateral dislocations</b></u> in a child of walking age<div><br>Trendelenburg gait - Results from&nbsp;<u><b>Abductor Insufficiency</b></u></div><div><u><b><br></b></u>Toe-Walking - Attempt to <b>Compensate</b> for the&nbsp;<u><b>relative shortening</b></u>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<u><b>affected side</b></u></div>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4118/developmental-dysplasia-of-the-hip-ddh"">Orthobullets: DDH</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::Hip&Pelvis::DDH"

"<div><div>How is the ""<b>Safe Zone</b>"" of <b>Pavlik </b>Harness <b>Hip ABduction</b> determined?<br><br>{{c1::Zone located <u>between</u> the Angle of <u>Maximal Passive Hip ABductio</u>n and the Angle of <u>Hip ADduction</u> at which the <u>Femoral Head Displaces</u> from the Acetabulum when the <u>Hips are in 90° of Flexion</u>}}</div></div>"	"<img src=""Safe+Zone+20+to+30+degrees+from+maximum+abduction.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4118/developmental-dysplasia-of-the-hip-ddh"">Orthobullets: DDH</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::Hip&Pelvis::DDH"
What is <b>Pavlik disease</b>? How is it <b>Prevented</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b><u>Erosion</u></b> of the <b>Pelvis <u>Superior</u></b><u> to the <b>Acetabulum</b></u>}}&nbsp;and <b><u>Prevention</u></b> of the <b><u>Development</u></b> of the {{c1::<b><u>Posterior Wall</u></b> of the <b>Acetabulum</b>}}&nbsp;due to {{c1::Prolonged <u>Positioning of <b>Dislocated Hip</b></u> in <u><b>Flexion</b> and <b>ABduction</b></u>}}<br><br>{{c2::Important to <u>Discontinue</u> the harness if the Hip is <u>NOT Reduced</u> by <b>3-4 weeks</b>}}	"<img src=""Pavlik-harness.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4118/developmental-dysplasia-of-the-hip-ddh"">Orthobullets: DDH</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::Hip&Pelvis::DDH"
What is the <b>next best step</b> in the management of a <b>3-month</b>-old who <b>fails Pavlik harness</b> treatment?<br><br>{{c1::Consider <u>Converting to Semi-Rigid ABduction Brace</u> with <u>weekly ultrasounds</u> for an <u>additional 3-4 weeks</u> before considering further intervention}}	Typically wait until 6-18 months for closed reduction and spica casting								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4118/developmental-dysplasia-of-the-hip-ddh"">Orthobullets: DDH</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::Hip&Pelvis::DDH"

<b>Historically, methylprednisone</b> should be given for <b>acute spinal cord injuries</b> if the injury occurred <b>&lt;&nbsp;</b>{{c1::8 hours}}<b>&nbsp;prior</b> to presentation	"<b>HISTORICAL, NO LONGER RECOMMENDED</b><b style=""""><br><br>30mg/kg bolus</b> followed by a<b style=""""> 5.4 mg/kg drip</b> if the injury occurred<b style=""""> less than 8 hours</b> prior to presentation. <br><br>If the injury was sustained <b style="""">less than 3 hours</b> prior to presentation, the methylprednisolone drip was to <b style="""">continue for 23 hours</b>. <br>If the injury occurred from <b style="""">3-8 hours prior</b> to presentation, the steroid drip was to be <b style="""">continued for 48 hours</b>. <br><br><b style="""">Contraindications </b>to steroid therapy include <b style="""">injuries </b>that occur<b style=""""> greater than 8 hours</b> <b style="""">prior</b> to presentation, <b style="""">pregnancy</b>, <b style="""">gunshot </b>wounds, patients <b style="""">under</b> the age of <b style="""">13</b>, and <b style="""">brachial plexus</b> injuries."									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2006/spinal-cord-injuries"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Injuries</a>"	"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCord_Injuries::Cord_Injuries"
How <b>long</b> should&nbsp;<b>Methylprednisone</b> should be given for <b>acute spinal cord injuries</b>?<br><br>&lt; 3 hours prior to presentation:&nbsp;{{c1::24 hours}}<br>3-8 hours prior to presentation:&nbsp;{{c1::48 hours}}<br>&gt; 8 hours prior to presentation:&nbsp;{{c1::Should NOT be given}}	"<b style="""">30mg/kg bolus</b> followed by a<b style=""""> 5.4 mg/kg drip</b> if the injury occurred<b style=""""> less than 8 hours</b> prior to presentation. <br><br><b style="""">Contraindications </b>to steroid therapy include <b style="""">injuries </b>that occur<b style=""""> greater than 8 hours</b> <b style="""">prior</b> to presentation, <b style="""">pregnancy</b>, <b style="""">gunshot </b>wounds, patients <b style="""">under</b> the age of <b style="""">13</b>, and <b style="""">brachial plexus</b> injuries." What are the <b>Contraindications</b> to <b>Steroid</b>&nbsp;(<b>Methylprednisone</b>) therapy for&nbsp;<b>Acute Spinal Cord injuries</b>?<br><br><b>Injuries </b>that occur {{c2::<b>&gt; 8 hours</b>}} <b>prior</b> to presentation<br><b>{{c1::Pregnancy}}</b><br>{{c1::<b>Gunshot&nbsp;</b>wounds}}<br>{{c1::Patients&nbsp;<b>&lt;&nbsp;13 years </b>old}}<br>{{c1::<b>Brachial plexus</b>&nbsp;injuries}}	"<b style=""""><u>HISTORICAL, NO LONGER RECOMMENDED</u><br><br>30mg/kg bolus</b> followed by a<b style=""""> 5.4 mg/kg drip</b> if the injury occurred<b style=""""> less than 8 hours</b> prior to presentation. <br><br><b style="""">Contraindications </b>to steroid therapy include <b style="""">injuries </b>that occur<b style=""""> greater than 8 hours</b> <b style="""">prior</b> to presentation, <b style="""">pregnancy</b>, <b style="""">gunshot </b>wounds, patients <b style="""">under</b> the age of <b style="""">13</b>, and <b style="""">brachial plexus</b> injuries." <b>ASIA (American Spinal Injury Association) Classification</b><br><br><b>A:</b> {{c1::Complete injury, no motor, no sensory}}<div><b>B:</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Incomplete injury,&nbsp;No motor function but some remaining sensory}}</div><div><b>C:</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Incomplete injury,&nbsp;50% or more of muscles below injury are LESS than Grade 3/5}}</div><div><b>D:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Incomplete injury,&nbsp;50% or more of muscles below injury are GREATER than or equal to than Grade 3/5}}</div><div><b>E:</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Incomplete injury, motor and sensory function normal}}</div>											"#Ortho::PP::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCordInjuries"

"A <b>79</b>-year old man falls sustaining a <b>hyperextension</b> injury to his <b>neck</b>. On exam, he has <b>3/5 strength</b> in his <b>deltoids, elbow </b>and <b>wrist</b> <b>flexors </b>and <b>extensors</b>. He has <b>4/5 strength</b> in his <b>hip flexors, knee flexors, extensors, ankle dorsiflexors</b> and <b>plantarflexors</b>. <b>Sensation</b> is grossly&nbsp;<b>preserved</b>. Imaging is shown below. Diagnosis?<br><br>{{c1::Central Cord Syndrome}}<br><img src=""c-spine.jpg""><img src=""c-spine2.jpg""><img src=""cspine3.jpg"">"	Figures show a <b>Spondylotic Spine</b> with <b>Central Narrowing</b> and <b>CSF Effacement</b> that is <b>worse</b> at the <b>C4-5 level</b>. <b>Distal Femur Fracture AO Classification</b><br><br>A1:&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Avulsion}}</b><br>A2: <b>{{c1::Simple}}</b><br>A3: {{c1::<b>Wedge</b> or <b>Multifragmentary</b>}}<br>B1:&nbsp;{{c2::<b>Lateral</b> Sagittal}}<br>B2: {{c2::<b>Medial</b> Sagittal}}<br>B3: {{c2::<b>Frontal / Coronal</b>}}<br>C1:&nbsp;{{c3::<b>Simple</b> Articular}}<br>C2: {{c3::<b>Simple</b> Articular with a <b><u>Fragmentary Metaphyseal</u></b> component}}<br>C3: {{c3::<b>Multifragmentary</b> Articular}}	A: <u>Extra-Articular</u><br>B: <u>Partial Articular</u>, the fracture is involving <b>one part</b> of the <b>articular surface</b>, yet the <b>rest</b> of the <b>joint </b>is <b>still attached</b> to the <u><b>Metaphysis</b> and <b>Diaphysis</b></u><br>C: <u>Complete Articular</u>, the fracture is <b>distributing</b> the <b>joint surface</b> and <b>separated</b> from the <b>Diaphysis</b>							"<img src=""A_big_gallery.jpeg""><br><img src=""B_big_gallery.jpeg""><br><img src=""C_big_gallery.jpeg"">"			"#Ortho::PP::Femur::Trauma::Distal_Femur"

What is <b>Wartenberg's Sign</b>? What <b>muscles</b>&nbsp;are causing it?<br><br>{{c1::Persistent <u>Small Finger ABduction and Extension</u> during attempted ADduction d/t Weak 3rd <u>Palmar Interosseous</u>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>Small Finger Lumbrical</u> muscles}}	"Suggestive of <b>Ulnar</b> n. <b>Neuropathy</b> - most commonly <b>Cubital Tunnel</b> Syndrome<br><br>D/t unopposed action of the <b>Extensor Digiti Minimi</b><br><img src=""maxresdefault-a429841e704afdaffd5aa720dc0da81591a1ee0a.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Hand::GeneralAnatomy"
What is <b>Froment's Sign</b>? What is a&nbsp;<b>Hoffa fracture</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b>Intra-Articular&nbsp;</b><b>Distal</b><b>&nbsp;Femur fracture</b>&nbsp;in the&nbsp;<b>Coronal plane</b>}}	"38%&nbsp;incidence<br>Seen on the <b>Lateral view</b><br><u>Missed in up to 31%</u> of cases<br><br><b>80%</b>&nbsp;are&nbsp;<b>Lateral</b><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""maxresdefault-04423fa6ffc0f9378066a9189c952d8dc61a8cf8.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Femur::Trauma::Distal_Femur"
The <b>Scapula</b> is oriented {{c1::30}}<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;<b>Anteverted</b> compared to the <b>Coronal Plane</b>	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3032/glenohumeral-joint-anatomy-stabilizer-and-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Glenohumeral Joint Anatomy,  Stabilizer,  &amp; Biomechanics</a>"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::GeneralAnatomy"
On average, the <b>Glenoid</b> is {{c1::5}}<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;<b>Retroverted</b> relative to the <b>Scapular Axis</b>	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3032/glenohumeral-joint-anatomy-stabilizer-and-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Glenohumeral Joint Anatomy,  Stabilizer,  &amp; Biomechanics</a><br><br>Varies from&nbsp;<b>7° </b>of <b>Retroversion</b>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<b>10°</b> of <b>Anteversion<br></b><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 4.21.44 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 4.22.40 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::GeneralAnatomy"
What is <b>Ulnar Variance</b>? <br><br>{{c1::The LENGTH of the Ulna compared to the Length of the Radius at the Wrist}}	"Neutral:<br><img src=""neutral.jpg""><br><br>Positive:<br><img src=""positive.jpg""><br><br>Negative:<br><img src=""negative.jpg"">"			"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-06-09 at 4.25.23 PM.png"">"					"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6046/ulnar-variance"">Orthobullets: Ulnar Variance</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::Hand::GeneralAnatomy"
What is the<b> Slope</b> of the <b>Tibia</b> in the <b>Sagittal Plane</b>?<br><br><b>Normal </b>Anatomy: {{c1::10<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;Posterior}}<br><b>PS</b> Implant: {{c1::0<sup>o</sup>}}<br><b>CR</b> Implant: {{c1::3-5<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;Posterior}}	"<img src=""X-rays+of+ps-tka+compared+to+cr-tka.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Knee::Adult_Recon::TKA"
EVERY <b>Painful Arthroplasty</b> demands that {{c1::Infection}} be <b>ruled out</b>											"#Ortho::PP::Knee::Adult_Recon::TKA"
In general for Recon, you should <b>avoid Poly thickness</b> &lt; {{c1::8 mm}} due to risk of <b>Catastrophic Failure</b>.											"#Ortho::OITEReview::Hip_Knee::Basics"

Definitive <b>Treatment</b> of&nbsp;<b>Anterior Posterior Compression</b>&nbsp;(APC) injuries<br><br>APC I:&nbsp;{{c1::Non-Operative. <b>Protected weight-bearing</b>}}<br>APC II: {{c2::<b>Anterior Symphyseal Plate</b>}}&nbsp;or {{c2::<b>External Fixator</b> +/- <b>Posterior Fixation</b>}}<br>APC III: {{c3::<b>Anterior Symphyseal Multi-Hole plate</b>}}&nbsp;or {{c3::<b>Ex-Fix</b> and <b>Posterior Stabilization</b> with <b>SI Screws</b> or <b>Plate/Screws</b>}}	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""gr1-476ee4721b89850c684cc3678e48ba8bd3a9d0b6.jpg"">"		"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-11-03 at 9.14.49 AM.png"">"	"APC I:<br><img src=""apc i.jpg""><br><br>APC II:<br><img src=""apc ii xr.jpg""><img src=""apc ii ct.jpg""><br><br>APC III:<br><img src=""ser001img00001.jpg""><img src=""apc 3 ct.jpg"">"	"Anterior Symphyseal Plate:<br><img src=""61_n09_i440.ashx""><br><img src=""ppev2.jpg""><br><br>"				"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1030/pelvic-ring-fractures"">Orthobullets - Pelvic Ring Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::Pelvic::Pelvis::RingFxs"

<div><b>AO/OTA </b>Classification of<b> Distal Humerus </b>Fractures<br><br></div>Type A:&nbsp;{{c1::Extra-articular (<u>Supracondylar</u> fracture), 80% are <u>Extension-type</u>; <u>Epicondyle</u>}}<br>Type B: {{c1::Intraarticular - <u>Single Column</u> (<u>partial articular</u>-isolated condylar, <u>Coronal shear</u>, epicondyle with articular extension)}}<br>Type C: {{c1::Intraarticular- <u>Both columns fractured</u> and <u>no portion</u> of the <u>joint is contiguous</u> with the <u>shaft</u> (complete articular)}}	"Each type <b>further divided</b> by <b>degree </b>and <b>location</b> of fracture<b> comminution<br><br></b><img src=""ota distal humerus.jpg""><b><br></b>"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1017/distal-humerus-fractures"">Orthobullets: Distal Humerus Fractures</a>"							"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Humerus::DistalFx"

What are the&nbsp;<b>5 ligaments</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>interosseous membrane</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>forearm</b>?&nbsp;<br><br><b>{{c1::Central}}</b>&nbsp;band<div><b>{{c1::Accessory}}&nbsp;</b>band</div><div><b>{{c1::Distal oblique bundle}}</b></div><div><b>{{c1::Proximal oblique}}</b>&nbsp;cord</div><div><b>{{c1::Dorsal oblique accessory}}&nbsp;</b>cord</div>	"<img src=""paste-1934902ae009645b38033d5dadb9226056ebe888.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Forearm&Wrist::Anatomy"
What makes up the<b> Posteromedial Corner</b> of the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Posterior Oblique Ligament<br>SemiMembranosus<br>Posterior Horn of the Medial Meniscus}}	Provide 30% of valgus restraint in full extension and with greater flexion the MCL assumes more responsibility -&nbsp;60%&nbsp;in 5° flexion and 80% in 25° flexion.										"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
Since the <b>Native Tibia joint line</b>&nbsp;is in Slight <b>Varus</b> (~3<sup>o</sup>), we <b>resect more</b> from the {{c1::LATERAL}} <b>side </b>during the <b>Tibial Cuts</b>&nbsp;in <b>TKA</b>	"<img src=""tibial+cut+and+distal+femoral+cut+for+tka+alignment+in+tka.jpg"">"							"<span style=""color: rgba(26, 26, 26, 0.99);"">Theoretically over resecting lateral tibial bone causes some <b>varus laxity</b>.&nbsp; You can compensate by performing a <b>medial release</b> of soft tissue (such as taking down some of the <b>deep MC</b>L); or <b>adjust </b>the <b>bony cuts </b>on the <b>femoral side</b> by:<br>a) <b>under-resect</b> the <b>lateral distal femur</b> (<b>decrease</b> the <b>valgus angle slightly to 6°</b> based on the intramedullary femur guide...<b>&nbsp;instead</b> of cutting the femur at <b>9°</b>) to <b>reconcile</b> the <b>extension gap<br></b>b) <b>balance</b> the <b>flexion gap </b>by adding <b>3°</b> of <b>external rotation </b>(this technique was originally implemented to <b>compensate</b> for the <b>tibial cut</b>…and th<b>e improved patellar tracking</b> is just an added bonus)</span>"			"#Ortho::HipKneeBook::Knee::BasicConcepts::Native_Kinematics"
Normal <b>Finger Range</b> of <b>Motion</b><br><br><b>MCP</b>: {{c1::0}}° Extension to {{c1::85}}° of Flexion<br><b>PIP</b>: {{c1::0}}° Extension to {{c1::110}}° of Flexion<br><b>DIP</b>:{{c1::0}}° Extension to {{c1::65}}° of Flexion	"<img src=""finflex.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Intro::ClinicalEval::Exam"
Normal <b>Wrist Range</b> of <b>Motion<br></b><br>{{c1::60}}° <b>Flexion</b><br>{{c1::60}}° <b>Extension</b><br>{{c1::50}}° <b>Radioulnar Deviation</b> arc	"<img src=""wristflex.jpg""><img src=""wrist_dev.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Intro::ClinicalEval::Exam"
<div><div>What <b>percent </b>of <b>Medial Epicondyle</b> fractures are associated with an <b>Elbow Dislocation</b>?<br><br>~{{c1::50-60}}% of cases</div></div>	Most <b>spontaneously reduce</b> but fragment <b>remains incarcerated</b> in joint in ~<b> 15%</b> of cases								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4008/medial-epicondylar-fractures--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Medial Epicondyle Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Elbow::MedEpicondyle"
How do you obtain a&nbsp;<b>Distal Humeral Axial </b>view?<br><br>{{c1::Angling beam&nbsp;<u>25 degrees Anterior</u> to <u>Long Axis of Humerus</u>}}	"Useful in Detecting Medial Epicondyle Fractures<br><img src=""illus_a_-0bd0785a1f487fc7465990162aa3238fc8f60822.jpg""><br><img src=""illus_b-9d5356c3980504f6e2a94ef7e6231a3e2abf5520.jpg""><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""fracture_medial_epicondyle_humerus.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4008/medial-epicondylar-fractures--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Medial Epicondyle Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Elbow::MedEpicondyle"

What are the<b> Boundaries</b> of the <b>Radial Tunnel</b>?<br><br><b>Lateral</b>: {{c1::Brachioradialis, ECRL, ECRB}}<br><b>Medial</b>: {{c1::Biceps Tendon, Brachialis}}<br><b>Floor</b>: {{c1::Capsule of the Radiocapitellar Joint}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-05 at 8.08.41 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Netters::Forearm::Nerves"
<div><div>What is <b>Radial Tunnel Syndrome</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Compressive Neuropathy of the PIN at the level of Proximal Forearm (radial tunnel)}}</div></div>	Treatment is a prolonged course of conservative management with <b>NSAIDs</b>, <b>temporary splinting</b> and <b>CSIs</b> with r<b>adial tunnel decompression</b> reserved for <b>refractory</b> cases.								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6024/radial-tunnel-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Radial Tunnel Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Tunnel"
"How is the diagnosis of&nbsp;<b>Radial Tunnel Syndrome&nbsp;</b>made?<br><br>{{c1::Clinically with Pain ONLY (maximal tenderness<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span><u>3-5 cm distal to lateral epicondyle</u>)<span style=""color: rgb(83, 114, 166);"">&nbsp;</span>without ANY Motor or Sensory dysfunction}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6024/radial-tunnel-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Radial Tunnel Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Tunnel"

What is the Length of the&nbsp;<b>Radial Tunnel</b>?<br><br>{{c1::5 cm}}	<b>Boundaries</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>Radial Tunnel</b><br><br><b>Lateral</b>: Brachioradialis, ECRL, ECRB<br><b>Medial</b>: Biceps Tendon, Brachialis<br><b>Floor</b>: Capsule of the Radiocapitellar Joint								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6024/radial-tunnel-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Radial Tunnel Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Tunnel"
<div>What is the <b>course</b> of the <b>PIN</b> in the <b>Dorsal Forearm</b>?<br><br>1. {{c1::Passes between the <u>2 heads</u> of origin of the <u>Supinator</u> muscle}}&nbsp;<br>2. {{c1::Direct contact with the Radial Neck osteology}}&nbsp;</div><div>3. {{c1::Passes OVER <u>APL</u> muscle <u>Origin</u> to reach <u>Interosseous membrane</u>}}&nbsp;</div><div>4. {{c1::Traverses along the <u>Posterior Interosseous Membrane</u>}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""radial tunnel lateral.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6024/radial-tunnel-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Radial Tunnel Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Tunnel"
<div>What are the <b>sensory</b> functions of the <b>PIN</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Sensory fibers to Dorsal Wrist Capsule}}</div>	Provided by <b>Terminal branch</b> which is located on the <b>Floor</b> of the <b>4th Extensor </b>Compartment								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6024/radial-tunnel-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Radial Tunnel Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Tunnel"
What are the symptoms of <b>Radial Tunnel Syndrome</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Deep Aching pain</u> in Dorsoradial Proximal Forearm&nbsp;from <u>lateral elbow to wrist}},</u> increases during&nbsp;{{c1::<u>Forearm Rotation</u> and <u>Lifting</u> activities}}	Muscle Weakness because of&nbsp;PAIN&nbsp;and NOT muscle denervation								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6024/radial-tunnel-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Radial Tunnel Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Tunnel"

What is <b>Wartenberg's</b> Syndrome?<br><br>{{c1::Compressive Neuropathy of the&nbsp;Superficial Sensory Radial nerve&nbsp;at the distal forearm/wrist}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">Also called ""cheiralgia paresthetica""<br><br></span><img src=""Hoppenfield 5_moved.jpg""><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6025/wartenbergs-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Wartenberg Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Wartenberg"
How is <b>Wartenberg's</b> Syndrome diagnosed?<br><br>{{c1::Clinically with <u>Pain and Paresthesias</u> over the Dorsoradial Hand <u>WITHOUT any Motor</u> Deficits}}	"<img src=""h9991344_001.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6025/wartenbergs-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Wartenberg Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Wartenberg"
The <b>Pathoanatomy</b> of&nbsp;<b>Wartenberg's</b> Syndrome involves the <b>SRN</b> becoming<b> compressed</b> by <b>Scissoring Action</b> of the {{c1::Brachioradialis}}&nbsp;and&nbsp;{{c1::ECRL Tendons}}&nbsp;during&nbsp;<b>Forearm</b>&nbsp;{{c1::Pronation::Action}}	"Also by&nbsp;fascial bands&nbsp;at its exit site in the subcutaneous plane<br><img src=""scissor.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6025/wartenbergs-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Wartenberg Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Wartenberg"
The <b>Superficial Radial n.</b>&nbsp;Emerges from between&nbsp;the <b>Brachioradialis</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>ECRL</b>&nbsp;{{c1::9}} cm<b> Proximal </b>to the&nbsp;<i></i>{{c1::<b>Radial Styloid&nbsp;</b>}}	"<img alt=""WARTENBERG'S SYNDROME | Hand Surgery Resource"" src=""https://www.handsurgeryresource.net/sites/default/files/images/Wartenberg%20Syndrome%20Anatomy.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6025/wartenbergs-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Wartenberg Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Radial::Wartenberg"
What is <b>Gantzer's</b> Muscle?<br><br>{{c1::Accessory Head of the FPL, can cause compression of the AIN}}	"<img src=""slide1-edfa953cbe952d25ede92b342373ddceb85eb959.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6019/ain-compressive-neuropathy"">Orthobullets: AIN Compressive Neuropathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Median::AIN"
A Common, <b>non-compressive</b> cause of <b>AIN Syndrome</b> is {{c1::Transient Neuritis (Parsonage-Turner syndrome)}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6019/ain-compressive-neuropathy"">Orthobullets: AIN Compressive Neuropathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Median::AIN"
<b>AIN Path </b>in the Forearm<br><br>1. Arises from the <b>Median</b> nerve approximately <b>{{c1::4}}</b> cm <b>Distal</b> to the <b>Medial epicondyle</b> (and <b>{{c1::5-8}}&nbsp;cm Distal</b> to <b>Lateral epicondyle</b>) <br>2. Travels between {{c3::<b>FDS</b>}}&nbsp;and {{c3::<b>FDP</b>}}<b>&nbsp;initially</b>, then <b>between&nbsp;</b>{{c3::<b>FPL</b>}} and {{c3::<b>FDP</b>}}, then it lies on the <b>Anterior surface</b> of the <b>interosseous membrane</b> traveling with the <b>anterior interoseous artery</b> to <b>{{c1::Pronator quadratus}}&nbsp;</b><br>3. <b>Terminal branches</b> innervate the <b>{{c2::joint capsule}}</b> and the <b>{{c2::Intercarpal}}, {{c2::Radiocarpal}}</b> and <b>{{c2::Distal Radioulnar}}</b> joints	"<img src=""median_nerve_anatomy..jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6019/ain-compressive-neuropathy"">Orthobullets: AIN Compressive Neuropathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Median::AIN"
<div><div>What are <b>3 characteristics </b>differentiating <b>Pronator Syndrome </b>from <b>Carpal Tunnel </b>syndrome?<br><br><b>Aching Pain</b>&nbsp;over {{c1::Proximal Volar Forearm}}<br><b>Sensory Disturbances </b>over the&nbsp;{{c1::Distribution of <u>Palmar Cutaneous Branch</u> of the Median nerve&nbsp;(palm of hand)}}<br><b>LACK</b> of {{c1::Night}} <b>Symptoms</b></div></div>	<b>Palmar Cutaneous Branch</b> of Median n. arises <b>4 </b>to<b> 5 cm proximal</b> to <b>carpal tunnel (Flexor Crease)</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6020/pronator-syndrome"">Orthobullets: Pronator Syndrome</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Neuropathies::Median::Pronator"
The <b>Spiral Groove </b>of the Posterior&nbsp;<b>Humerus</b>&nbsp;lies approximately {{c1::13}} cm&nbsp;<b>Proximal</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Articular Surface</b>&nbsp;of the<b>&nbsp;Trochlea&nbsp;</b>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-07 at 12.13.48 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Netters::Arm::Osteology"
What are the <b>Cubital Fossa Borders</b> and <b>Contents</b>?<br><br><b>Borders</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Brachioradialis Laterally, Pronator Teres Medially, Distal Humerus Posteriorly}}<br><b>Contents</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Biceps Tendon Laterally, Brachial Artery, Median nerve Medially}}	"<img src=""1df4e1a5d79ffaf980a80ba64dc824_gallery.jpeg""><br><img src=""cubital_fossa-scaled.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::Netters::Arm::Misc"

In <b>Supracondylar Humerus</b> Fractures, what <b>Artery</b> tethers the blood supply and is <b>responsible</b> for <b>Vascular injury</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Supratrochlear Artery}}	"<b>Ulnar</b>-sided <b>branch </b>of the <b>Brachial artery</b><br><br><img src=""hqdefault-b18a04e7ebfb7c5945050199e44c41ed37e20d4a.jpg""><img src=""Brachialarterytethering.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4007/supracondylar-fracture--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Supracondylar Humerus Fractures (Peds)</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::Peds::UpperExtremity::SupracondylarHumerus"
In Pediatric <b>Lateral Condyle</b> fractures,&nbsp;what Radiographic <b>View&nbsp;</b>most accurately shows <b>fracture Displacement </b>and <b>Why</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Internal Oblique; Fracture is Posterolateral}}	"<div><b>Internal oblique</b> radiograph positioning: <b>Arm Extended, Forearm Pronated, Anterior surface </b>of <b>Elbow</b> at <b>45 degrees</b></div><br><img src=""internal_oblique_view.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""images-324c7a4c1b52dfa62cee3075d7e5a939a95e8916.jpg""><br>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4009/lateral-condyle-fracture--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Lateral Condyle Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Elbow::LatEpicondyle"

What are the <b>2 theories</b> for <b>Mechanism</b> of <b>Injury </b>in Pediatric <b>Lateral Condyle </b>Fractures?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Pull-off</u> theory -&nbsp;<u>avulsion</u> fracture of the lateral condyle that results from the <u>pull of the common extensor</u> musculature}}<br>{{c1::<u>Push-off</u> theory - Fall onto an <u>outstretched hand</u> causes i<u>mpaction of the radial head</u> into the lateral condyle causing fracture&nbsp;}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4009/lateral-condyle-fracture--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Lateral Condyle Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Elbow::LatEpicondyle"
Weiss et al Pediatric <b>Lateral Condyle Fracture Displacement</b> Classification<br><br>Grade I: {{c1::&lt; 2mm, indicating <u>intact cartilaginous hinge</u>}}<br>Grade II: {{c1::&gt; 2 mm &lt; 4 displacement, <u>intact articular cartilage on arthrogram</u>}}<br>Grade III: {{c1::&gt; 4 mm, <u>articular surface disrupted</u> on arthrogram}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-06 at 6.07.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""fxclass (jointpainexpert.net).jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4009/lateral-condyle-fracture--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Lateral Condyle Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Elbow::LatEpicondyle"

"<div>How do you perform a <b>Valgus Stress</b> test&nbsp;for <b>Elbow MUCL</b> Injury?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::<u>Flex Elbow</u> to 20 to 30<sup>o</sup> (Unlocks the Olecranon), <u>EXTernally Rotate</u> the <u>Humerus</u>, and apply <u>Valgus stress</u>}}<br></div>"	50% sensitive&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3079/medial-ulnar-collateral-ligament-injury"">Orthobullets: MUCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Elbow::Instability_Throwing::MUCL"
"<div>How do you perform a <b>Milking Maneuver</b>&nbsp;for <b>Elbow MUCL</b> Injury?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div>{{c1::Creates <u>Valgus stress</u> by <u>Pulling</u> on the patient's <u>Thumb</u> with the <u>Forearm Supinated</u> and <u>Elbow Flexed</u> at 90<sup>o</sup>}}<br></div>"	"Patient may be Supine or Seated/Standing<br><b style=""""><u>Positive test</u></b> is a subjective <u style=""""><b>Apprehension, Instability</b>, or <b>Pain</b></u> at the <u style=""""><b>MCL ORIGIN<br></b></u><br><img src=""a998d523-0948-4ae3-9bd0-5db8e56fec6f_milking.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3079/medial-ulnar-collateral-ligament-injury"">Orthobullets: MUCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Elbow::Instability_Throwing::MUCL"
"<div>How do you perform a <b>Moving Valgus Stress Test</b>&nbsp;for <b>Elbow MUCL</b> Injury?</div>
<div><br>{{c1::Place Elbow in same position as the ""Milking Maneuver"" and apply a <u>Valgus Stress</u> while the Elbow is ranged through the <u>full arc of Flexion and Extension</u>}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span></div>"	"Positive test is a <b>subjective Apprehension, Instability</b>, or <b>Pain</b> at the <b>MCL origin</b> between <b>70 </b>and <b>120<sup>o</sup></b><br>100% sensitive and 75% specific<br><u style=""""><br>Milking Test Position:<br></u><img src=""a998d523-0948-4ae3-9bd0-5db8e56fec6f_milking.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3079/medial-ulnar-collateral-ligament-injury"">Orthobullets: MUCL Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Elbow::Instability_Throwing::MUCL"

"<div>What are the <b>Components</b> of the <b>Compartments </b>of the <b>Foot</b>?</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>Medial</b>: {{c1::Abductor Hallucis, FHB, FHL tendon::3}}</div>
<div><b>Lateral</b>: {{c1::Abductor Digiti Minimi, Flexor Digiti Minimi::2}}</div>
<div><b>Superficial Central</b>: {{c2::Flexor Digitorum Brevis, Lumbricals (4), FDL tendons::3}}</div>

<div><b>Adductor</b>: {{c1::Adductor hallucis}}</div>"	"<div>Interosseous <b>(1-2)</b>:<b> Dorsal</b> interosseous muscle</div><div>Interosseous (2-3): Dorsal and plantar interosseous muscles</div><div>Interosseous (3-4): Dorsal and plantar interosseous muscles</div><div>Interosseous (4-5): Dorsal and plantar interosseous muscles<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-10 at 11.45.01 AM.png""><br></div>"										"#Ortho::Netters::Foot_Ankle::Muscles"

What is the <b>Lisfranc instability</b> test<br><br>{{c1::Grasp <u>MT Heads</u> and apply <u>Dorsal Force</u> to FOREFOOT while other hand palpates the <u>TMT joints</u><br><u>D</u><u>orsal Subluxation</u> suggests Instability}}	If&nbsp;<u><b>1st </b>and <b>2nd MTs</b></u>&nbsp;can be <b>displaced&nbsp;</b><u><b>Medially</b> and <b>Laterally</b></u>,&nbsp;<u><b>Global Instability</b></u>&nbsp;is present and <b>SURGERY REQUIRED</b><br><br>When <b>Plantar Ligaments</b> are<b> intact</b>, <b>Dorsal Subluxation</b> <u>does not occur</u> with <b>Stress</b> exam and injury may be treated <u><b>Nonoperatively<br></b></u>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/foot-and-ankle/7030/lisfranc-injury"">Orthobullets: Lisfranc Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::F&A::Trauma::Midfoot_Forefoot::Lisfranc"

What are the <b>5 Critical Radiographic Signs</b> that indicate presence of<b> Midfoot Instability</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b>Discontinuity</b> of a Line drawn from the <b>Medial base</b> of the <b>2nd MT</b> to the <b>Medial side</b> of the <b>Middle</b> Cuneiform (<b>AP</b>) }}<br>{{c1::<b>Widening</b> of the <b>Interval</b> between the <u><b>1st</b> and <b>2nd Ray (AP)</b></u>}}<br>{{c1::<b>Dorsal Displacement</b> of the <b>Proximal base</b> of the <b>1st </b>or <b>2nd MT (Lat)</b>}}<br>{{c2::<b>Medial side</b> of the <b>base</b> of the <b>4th MT</b> does <b>NOT</b> line up with <b>Medial </b>side of <b>Cuboid (oblique)&nbsp;</b>}}<br>{{c2::<b>Disruption</b> of the <b>Medial Column Line</b>&nbsp;(line <u><b>tangential</b></u> to the <b>Medial</b> aspect of the <b>Navicular</b> and the <b>Medial Cuneiform</b>)&nbsp;<b>(oblique)</b>}}	"<img src=""AP 2_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/foot-and-ankle/7030/lisfranc-injury"">Orthobullets: Lisfranc Injury</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::F&A::Trauma::Midfoot_Forefoot::Lisfranc"

<div>Type <b>A</b>: {{c1::Complete HOMOLATERAL dislocation}}</div>

<u><b>Attachments</b> of <b>Lateral </b>Ankle <b>Ligaments</b>:</u><br><br><b>ATFL</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Lateral Malleolus to <u>Neck</u> of <u>Talus</u>&nbsp;}}<br><b>CFL</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Lateral Malleolus to <u>Peroneal Tubercle</u> of Calcaneus}}<br><b>PTFL</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Lateral Malleolus to&nbsp;Talus (<u>Posterior Process</u>)}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-13 at 2.23.09 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Netters::Foot_Ankle::Osteology"

<b><u>Ottawa Ankle Rules</u></b> (Indications for Radiographs with an Ankle Injury)<br><br>{{c1::Inability to Bear Weight}}<br>{{c1::Medial or Lateral Malleolus Point Tenderness}}<br>{{c1::5th MT Base Tenderness}}<br>{{c1::Navicular Tenderness}}	"96-99% Sensitive in ruling OUT ankle fracture<br><br><img src=""ottawa.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/foot-and-ankle/7028/ankle-sprain"">Orthobullets: Ankle Sprain</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::F&A::Trauma::AnkleSprains::AnkleSprain"
What is the <b>Mechanism</b> of an <b>ATFL Low Ankle Sprain</b>? Physical <b>Exam</b>?<br><br><b>Mechanism</b>: {{c1::Plantarflexion + Inversion}}<br><b>PE</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Drawer Laxity in Plantarflexion}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/foot-and-ankle/7028/ankle-sprain"">Orthobullets: Ankle Sprain</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::F&A::Trauma::AnkleSprains::AnkleSprain"
What is the&nbsp;<b>Mechanism</b>&nbsp;of an&nbsp;<b>CFL Low Ankle Sprain</b>? Physical&nbsp;<b>Exam</b>?<br><br><b>Mechanism</b>: {{c1::Dorsiflexion + Inversion}}<br><b>PE</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Drawer Laxity in Dorsiflexion}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/foot-and-ankle/7028/ankle-sprain"">Orthobullets: Ankle Sprain</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::F&A::Trauma::AnkleSprains::AnkleSprain"
<b>Injury</b> to <b>SUPERFICIAL</b>&nbsp;<b>Deltoid </b>Ligament: <b>Limits</b> {{c1::Talar ABduction}}<br><b>Injury</b> to <b>DEEP Deltoid&nbsp;</b>Ligament: <b>Limits</b> {{c1::External Rotation}}	Initally treated <b>Conservatively</b>, but may require <b>Reconstruction</b> if patient continues to have instability&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/foot-and-ankle/7028/ankle-sprain"">Orthobullets: Ankle Sprain</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::F&A::Trauma::AnkleSprains::AnkleSprain"
What is the<b> %</b> of <b>AVN</b> associated with each <b>Grade</b> on the&nbsp;<b>Hawkins&nbsp;</b>Classification of <b>Talar Neck&nbsp;</b>fractures?<br><br>Hawkins I: {{c1::0-13}}%<div>Hawkins II: {{c1::20-50}}%</div><div>Hawkins III: {{c1::20-100}}%</div><div>Hawkins IV: {{c1::70-100}}%</div>	<b>Hawkins&nbsp;</b>Classification of&nbsp;<b>talar neck&nbsp;</b>fractures<br><br>Hawkins I: Non-displaced talar neck fracture<div>Hawkins II: Talar neck fracture +&nbsp;<b>subtalar</b>&nbsp;dislocation</div><div>Hawkins III: Hawkins II +<b>&nbsp;tibiotalar</b>&nbsp;dislocation</div><div>Hawkins IV: Hawkins III +&nbsp;<b>talonavicular</b>&nbsp;dislocation</div>			"HAWKINS I:<br><img src=""Xray - Lateral - Hawkins I (emedicine)_moved.jpg""><br><br>HAWKINS II:<br><img src=""r talar neck.jpg""><br><br>HAWKINS III:<br><img src=""talar neck fx dislocation lateral.jpg""><br><br>HAWKINS IV:<br><img src=""hawkins 4.jpg"">"							"#Ortho::PP::FootAndAnkle::Trauma::Talus"

What is the <b>Path</b> of the <b>Radial</b> artery in the <b>Forearm</b>?<br><br><b>Runs</b> BETWEEN {{c1::Brachioradialis}} and {{c1::FCR}} <br>Enters the <b>Dorsum</b> of the <b>Carpus</b> by passing BETWEEN {{c1::FCR}} and {{c1::APL/EPB}}&nbsp;<b>Tendons</b> (in the {{c1::Snuffbox}})<br>Gives off {{c1::Superficial Palmar Branch}}&nbsp;(<b>Communicates</b> with {{c1::Superficial Arch}})<br>Finally Passes BETWEEN {{c1::2 Heads of 1st Dorsal Interosseous}}&nbsp;to <b>form</b> the&nbsp;{{c1::Deep Palmar Arch}}	"<img src=""radial-artery-anatomy.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Intro::Anatomy::BloodSupply"
"What is the <b>Path</b> of the <b>Ulnar</b> artery?<br><br><div>Runs <b>UNDER</b> {{c1::FCU}}</div>
<div><b>Lateral </b>to {{c1::Ulnar nerve}} at the <b>Wrist</b></div>
<div><b>Enters</b> the <b>Hand</b> through {{c1::Guyon's canal}}</div>

"<div><b>Expansion Hood</b> of <b>Fingers</b></div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>Central Slip</b></div>
<div><b>Function</b>: {{c1::Extend PIP}}</div>
<div><b>Insertion</b>: {{c1::Base of Middle Phalanx}}</div>
<div><br></div>
<div><b>Lateral Band</b></div>

<b>Extrinsic Ligaments</b> of the <b>Wrist</b><br><br><b>Dorsal</b>: {{c1::Dorsal Intercarpal (DIC), Dorsal Radiocarpal (DRC)}}<br><br><b>Volar</b>: {{c1::Radioscaphocapitate (RSC), Long Radiolunate (LRL), Radioscapholunate (RSL), Short Radiolunate (SRL)}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-20 at 7.11.47 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Misc_Books::Millers::Anatomy::Wrist_Hand"
<b>Functions&nbsp;</b>of&nbsp;<b>Extrinsic Ligaments</b> of the <b>Wrist:</b><br><br>Dorsal<br><b>Dorsal Intercarpal (DIC) </b>- {{c1::Dorsal SUPPORT to Translation of Midcarpal Joint}}<br><b>Dorsal Radiocarpal (DRC)</b>&nbsp;- {{c1::Controls Ulnar Translation (AKA Radiotriquetral)}}<br><br>Volar<br><b>Radioscaphocapitate (RSC) </b>- {{c1::Supports Scaphoid WAIST}}<br><b>Long Radiolunate (LRL) </b>- {{c1::Strong TETHER to Lunate Dislocation}}<br><b>Radioscapholunate (RSL)</b>&nbsp;- {{c1::Ligament of Testut (Neurovascular Conduit)}}<br><b>Short Radiolunate (SRL)</b>&nbsp;- {{c1::Prevents Dorsal Lunate Dislocation}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-20 at 7.11.47 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Misc_Books::Millers::Anatomy::Wrist_Hand"
The <b>Scaphoid</b> {{c1::FLEXES}} with <b>{{c2::RADIAL}} Deviation</b> and {{c1::EXTENDS}} with <b>{{c2::ULNAR}} Deviation</b>											"#Ortho::Misc_Books::Millers::Anatomy::Wrist_Hand"

How do you perform a <b>Bunnel's</b> test? <b>Bunnel's</b> test Results<br><br><b>Intrinsic</b>&nbsp;tightness: {{c1::<b>PIP&nbsp;</b>can be&nbsp;<b>flexed easily&nbsp;</b>when&nbsp;<b>MCP</b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<b>FLEXED</b>&nbsp;but NOT when&nbsp;<b>MCP</b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<b>extended</b>}}<br><b>Extrinsic</b>&nbsp;tightness: {{c1::<b>PIP</b>&nbsp;can be<b>&nbsp;flexed easily&nbsp;</b>when&nbsp;<b>MCP</b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<b>EXTENDED</b>&nbsp;but NOT when&nbsp;<b>MCP&nbsp;</b>is&nbsp;<b>flexed</b>}}	"<b><br><img src=""intrin.jpg""></b>"										"#Ortho::Netters::Hand::Osteology"

What is the <b>Reimers Migration</b> Index? (CP)<br><br>{{c1::% of Femoral Head with NO Acetabular coverage}}	"% of Femoral Head LATERAL to Acetabular Margin on AP Pelvis X-Ray<br><br>&lt;33% = Hip at Risk<br>&gt;33% = Subluxated Hip<br><br>Most Accurate method to identify and monitor <u><i><b>Hip Stability</b></i></u><br><img src=""reimers.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4130/cerebral-palsy--hip-conditions"">Orthobullets: Cerebral Palsy Hip Conditions</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"

In the <b>Treatment </b>of<b> CP</b>, what are the<b>&nbsp;GOALS</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>Hip ADductor</b> and <b>Psoas Release </b>with <b>ABduction Bracing</b>?<br><br><b>Prevent </b>{{c1::Hip Subluxation and Dislocation}}<br><b>Maintain</b> {{c1::Comfortable Seating}}<br><b>Facilitate </b>{{c1::Care and Hygiene}}<br>&gt;{{c1::45}} <b>degrees</b> of <b>Hip</b> {{c1::ABduction}} AFTER <b>Releases</b>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.54.47 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.57.30 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.55.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.57.49 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4130/cerebral-palsy--hip-conditions"">Orthobullets: Cerebral Palsy Hip Conditions</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"
<b>Hip ADductor</b> and <b>Psoas Release </b>with <b>ABduction Bracing Technique</b><br><br>1. Begin with <b>Tenotomy </b>of the {{c1::ADductor Longus}}, Sequentially release {{c1::Gracilis}} and {{c1::ADductor Brevis}} as needed<br><br>2. <b>Release</b> the {{c1::Psoas tendon}} either at the <b>level </b>of the {{c1::Insertion}} (<b>NON-Ambulatory </b>patients) or <b>Proximally </b>at the {{c1::Pelvic Brim}} in the <b>Myotendonous</b> junction (<b>Ambulatory </b>patients)	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.54.47 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.57.30 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.55.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.57.49 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4130/cerebral-palsy--hip-conditions"">Orthobullets: Cerebral Palsy Hip Conditions</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"
What should you be CAREFUL of during&nbsp;<b>Hip ADductor</b> and <b>Psoas Release </b>with <b>ABduction Bracing</b>&nbsp;if an <u><b>ADductor Brevis</b> release</u> is required?<br><br>{{c1::Obturator n. - Neurectomy can cause an ABduction Contracture}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.54.47 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.57.30 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.55.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 7.57.49 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4130/cerebral-palsy--hip-conditions"">Orthobullets: Cerebral Palsy Hip Conditions</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"

"What <b style="""">OPERATIVE</b> option for <b style="""">CP</b> is&nbsp;best to treat <b>ALL Pathology</b> at <b>SINGLE</b> stage if patient has a <b>Severely Dysplastic CP Hip</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Proximal Femoral Osteotomy with Shelf-Producing (Dega) Osteotomy and Soft-Tissue Release}}"	"<div>

<div>
<div>
<div>The
<b>benefit </b>of VDRO comes from the
<b>bone shortening</b> that acts like a
<b>muscle release</b> or <b>lengthening</b>. <b>Decreasing femoral anteversion</b>,<b> neck-shaft angle</b>, or both have <b>little effect</b>
on the <b>forces</b>.</div>

"<div>What is the <b>Technique</b> for a <b>Castle Resection-Interposition </b>Arthroplasty?</div>
<br>
<div>{{c1::<u>Resect Proximal Femur</u> at the level of <u>Lesser Trochanter</u> (note the difference from a Girdlestone)<div><u>Oversew Vastus</u> over Cut <u>Proximal Femoral end</u></div>
<div>Oversew <u>ABductors, Psoas and Hip Capsule</u> OVER <u>Acetabulum</u></div>
<div>This <u>Interposes a Large Mass of Soft Tissue</u> between the <u>Acetabulum</u> and <u>Proximal Femur</u> }}</div></div>"	"<div>Indications:</div>
<div><b>Chronically Dislocated</b> hips, especially in the <b>adult CP</b> population</div>
<div><u><b>Unable </b>to <b>Walk</b></u>, Stand to Transfer (<b>GMFCS 5</b>)</div>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4084/cerebral-palsy--general"">Orthobullets: Cerebral Palsy - General</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"
"<div>What are the <b>Indications</b> for a <b>Castle Resection-Interposition </b>Arthroplasty?</div>

<div>{{c1::<b>Chronically Dislocated</b>&nbsp;hips, especially in the&nbsp;<b>adult CP</b>&nbsp;population<div><u><b>Unable&nbsp;</b>to&nbsp;<b>Walk</b></u>, Stand to Transfer (<b>GMFCS 5</b>)}}</div></div>"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4084/cerebral-palsy--general"">Orthobullets: Cerebral Palsy - General</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"
<div>What are the <b>Indications</b> for a&nbsp;<b>McHale Technique</b> in CP?<br><br>{{c1::Salvage technique for Symptomatic and Chronically Dislocated hips}}</div>	<b>Valgus Support Osteotomy</b><strong>&nbsp;</strong>(<b>Femoral Head Resection</b> + <b>Valgus Subtrochanteric Femoral </b>Osteotomy)										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"
"What is the Usual <b>Mechanism </b>of <b>Dislocation</b> in a <b>Spastic CP Hip</b>?<br><br>In&nbsp;<b>CP</b>, the&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Adductors</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>Iliopsoas</b>}}&nbsp;are&nbsp;<b style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">Spastic</b><u>&nbsp;and&nbsp;</u><b style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">Shortened</b>, and&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Glut Max</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>Medius</b>}}&nbsp;are&nbsp;<b style=""text-decoration-line: underline;"">Weak</b><br>The&nbsp;<u><b>Center</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;<b>Movement</b></u>&nbsp;is translated from the&nbsp;<u><b>Center</b></u> of the&nbsp;{{c1::<u>Femoral Head</u>}}&nbsp;distally to the&nbsp;level of the&nbsp;{{c1::<u>Lesser Troch</u>}}<br>The&nbsp;<b>Hip Joint Capsule</b>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<b><u>Elongated&nbsp;</u></b>{{c1::<u>Posterosuperiorly</u>}}, with&nbsp;<b>Gradual Dislocation</b>&nbsp;of the hip"	"<img class=""resizer"" src=""Screen Shot 2021-08-15 at 9.00.58 AM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Syndromes::CP::Hip"
"
<div>
