<div>
<div>What are the 3 Different <b>Branching Patterns</b> of the <b>LFCN</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Sartorius-Type}}<br>{{c1::Posterior-Type}}<br>{{c1::Fan-Type}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<b>Sartorius</b>-Type (in 36% of the specimens) - Characterized by a <b>Dominant Anterior </b>nerve Branch coursing along the <b>Lateral Border</b> of the <b>Sartorius</b> with NO, or only a THIN, Posterior branch<br><br><b>Posterior</b>-type (in 32%) - Characterized by a <b>Strong POSTERIOR </b>nerve branch<br><br><b>Fan</b>-type (in 32%), characterized by <b>Multiple Spreading Nerve branches</b> of <b>EQUAL </b>Thickness<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-27 at 6.18.03 PM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-08 at 3.17.18 PM.png"">"			"#Ortho::Netters::Pelvis::Nerves"
"What does the ""<b>Gull Sign</b>"" of a <b>Posterior Wall</b> Acetabular Fracture <b>Represent</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Impaction of SuperoMedial Roof}}"	"Seen on <b>ILIAC OBLIQUE </b>(vs Spur sign which is seen on obturator oblique)<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""gullsign.jpg""><div><img class=""resizer"" src=""1-s2.0-S1877132718300289-gr9.jpg""></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
What is the <b>Roof Arc Angle</b> (Acetabulum Fractures)?<br><br>{{c1::Angle between <u>Vertical Line through Femoral Head</u> and <u>Line Through Fracture</u>; Helps to <u>define fracture pattern stability</u>}}	"Considered <b>Stable </b>if the <b>Fracture Line Exits OUTSIDE</b> the <b>Weight-Bearing Dome</b> of the Acetabulum<br>Defined as <b>&gt; 45° on AP</b>, <b>Obturator</b> and <b>Iliac Oblique</b> views<br><br><b>NOT</b> applicable for <u><b>Associated Both Column or Posterior Wall</b></u> pattern because <u><b>no intact portion</b> of the <b>Acetabulum</b> to measure</u><br><img src=""roof_arc_measurements.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
How is <b>Joint Reaction Force</b> Defined?<br><br>{{c1::Force Generated <u>within a Joint in Response to Forces Acting on</u> the Joint}}&nbsp;	"In the <b>hip</b>, it is the result of the <b>need to&nbsp;balance</b> the <b>moment arms</b>&nbsp;of the <b>body weight</b> and <b>abductor tension</b> - Maintains a&nbsp;Level Pelvis<br><br><img src=""hip-mechanics.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
The <b>Instant Center </b>of<b>&nbsp;Rotation</b> is the {{c1::Point about which a Joint Rotates}} <br><br><b>Often Changes</b> During {{c1::Rotation}} due to {{c1::Joint Translation}}	<b>Center </b>of<b> Gravity</b> of <b>Human</b> is just&nbsp;<b>ANTERIOR</b> to <b>S2</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>Coefficient</b> of <b>Friction</b><br><br><b>Human</b> Joints: {{c1::.002 to .04}}<br><b>TJA</b> (Metal on PE): {{c1::.05 to .15}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>1 Newton</b> =&nbsp;{{c1::Force Required to give 1 kg Mass an Acceleration of 1 m/s2&nbsp;}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>Moment (Torque)</b> =&nbsp;<i></i>{{c1::Force(Perpendicular) X Distance&nbsp;}}	The tendency of a Force to Rotate a Body AROUND an Axis								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>Work</b> =&nbsp;{{c1::Force (Vector Parallel to Displacement) x Distance}}	When a force acts upon an object to create displacement&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>Acetabular</b>-Sided <b>Actions</b> that&nbsp;<b>DECREASE Joint Reaction Force</b> in THA:<br><br>{{c1::Moving Acetabular component <u>Medial, Inferior, and Anterior</u>}}	"<img src=""hip-mechanics.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>Femoral</b>-Sided <b>Actions</b> that&nbsp;<b>DECREASE Joint Reaction Force</b> in THA:<br><br>{{c1::Increasing Offset of Femoral Component }}<br>{{c1::Long Stem prostheses }}<br>{{c1::Lateralization of Greater Trochanter (by using Increased Offset Neck/Prosthesis)}}<br>{{c1::Varus Neck-Shaft Angulation (Increases&nbsp;Shear&nbsp;Across Joint)}}	"<img src=""hip-mechanics.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
<b>Gait</b>-Related&nbsp;<b>Actions</b> that&nbsp;<b>DECREASE HIP Joint Reaction Forces</b>:<br><br>{{c1::Shifting Body Weight over AFFECTED hip&nbsp;- Results in <u>Trendelenburg gait</u>}}<br>{{c1::Cane in CONTRALATERAL Hand}}<br>{{c1::Carrying load in IPSILATERAL Hand}}	"CANE - Reduces abductor muscle pull and decreases the moment arm between the center of gravity and the femoral head<br>CARRYING LOAD - Produces additional downward moment on same side of rotational point<br><br><img src=""hip-mechanics.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
How does using a <b>Cane</b> in the <b>CONTRALATERAL</b> Hand&nbsp;<b>DECREASE HIP Joint Reaction Forces?</b><br><br>{{c1::<u>Reduces ABductor Muscle Pull</u> and <u>Decreases the Moment Arm</u> between the <u>Center of Gravity</u> and the <u>Femoral Head</u>}}	"<img src=""hip-mechanics.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
How does <b>Carrying</b> a <b>Load</b> in the <b>IPSILATERAL</b> Hand&nbsp;<b>DECREASE HIP Joint Reaction Forces?</b><br><br>{{c1::Produces <u>Additional Downward Moment</u> on <u>Same</u> side of <u>Rotational point</u>}}	"<img src=""hip-mechanics.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/recon/9064/hip-biomechanics"">Orthobullets: Hip Biomechanics</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Recon::Hip::Anatomy_Biomechanics::Biomechanics"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Calcar femorale</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Vertically oriented Dense Bone in the Posteromedial Aspect of the Proximal Femur&nbsp;}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);""><br></span>"											"#Ortho::Netters::Thigh_Hip::Osteology"
What Nerve Root&nbsp;<b>Contributions</b> make up the <b>Standard Brachial Plexus</b>, and in what <b>%</b> of people is this <b>present</b>?<br><br>{{c1::C5, C6, C7, C8, T1 – 77% of patients}}	"<img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
What Nerve Root&nbsp;<b>Contributions</b> make up the <b>PREFIXED&nbsp;Brachial Plexus</b>, and in what <b>%</b> of people is this <b>present</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Contributions from C3 &amp; C4 – 22% of patients}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">A prefixed brachial plexus has been described as&nbsp;</span><b>having a contribution to the plexus from C4 without a significant contribution from T1</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">, while a postfixed brachial plexus has been described as having a T2 contribution without a significant contribution from C5.</span><br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg""><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00276-009-0619-3/MediaObjects/276_2009_619_Fig1_HTML.gif"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
What Nerve Root&nbsp;<b>Contributions</b> make up the <b>POSTFIXED&nbsp;Brachial Plexus</b>, and in what <b>%</b> of people is this <b>present</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Roots Caudal to T1 – 1% of patients}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">A prefixed brachial plexus has been described as&nbsp;</span><b>having a contribution to the plexus from C4 without a significant contribution from T1</b><span style=""color: rgb(32, 33, 36);"">, while a postfixed brachial plexus has been described as having a T2 contribution without a significant contribution from C5.</span><br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
What <b>nerves</b> of the Brachial Plexus <b>Branch DIRECTLY</b> from the <b>Roots</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Dorsal Scapular nerve}} (C{{c1::5}})<br>{{c1::Long Thoracic nerve}}&nbsp;(C{{c1::5, 6, 7}})	"<b>Dorsal Scapular</b> nerve (<b>C5</b>): through <b>Levator Scapula</b> to <b>supply Levator Scapula, Rhomboid Major &amp; Minor</b><br><b>Long Thoracic nerve</b> (<b>C5, 6, 7</b>): <b>Posterior</b> to <b>Plexus</b> onto <b>Thoracic Wall</b> to supply <b>Serratus Anterior</b><br><br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
What <b>nerves</b> of the Brachial Plexus <b>Branch DIRECTLY</b> from the <b>Superior</b>&nbsp;<b>TRUNK</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<b>Suprascapular nerve</b>}} (C{{c1::<b>5, 6</b>}})<br>{{c1::<b>Nerve</b>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<b>Subclavius</b>}}&nbsp;(C{{c1::<b>5, 6</b>}})	"<b>Suprascapular nerve</b> (<b>C5, 6</b>): through <b>Suprascapular Notch</b> to <b>Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, AC</b> and <b>Glenohumeral </b>joint<br><b>Nerve</b> to <b>Subclavius</b> (<b>C5, 6</b>)&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
What <b>nerves</b> of the Brachial Plexus <b>Branch DIRECTLY</b> from the <b>Posterior CORD</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Upper Subscapular nerve}}&nbsp;(<b>C</b>{{c1::5, 6}})<br>{{c1::Lower Subscapular nerve}}&nbsp;(<b>C</b>{{c1::5,6}})<br>{{c1::Thoracodorsal nerve}}&nbsp;(<b>C</b>{{c1::6, 7, 8}})	"<b>Upper Subscapular </b>nerve (<b>C5, 6</b>): <b>subscapularis</b><br><b>Lower Subscapular </b>nerve (<b>C5,6</b>): <b>subscapularis, teres major</b><br><b>Thoracodorsal </b>nerve (<b>C6, 7, 8</b>): <b>latissmus dorsi</b><br><br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
"What <b>nerve</b>&nbsp;of the Brachial Plexus <b>Branches DIRECTLY</b> from the <b>LATERAL CORD</b>?<br><br>{{c1::L<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">ateral Pectoral nerve&nbsp;</span>}}&nbsp;(<b>C</b>{{c1::5, 6, 7}})"	"<b>Lateral Pectoral</b> nerve (<b>C5, 6, 7</b>): <b>Pectoralis Major</b>, communication with <b>Medial Pectoral</b> nerve&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
What <b>nerves</b>&nbsp;of the Brachial Plexus <b>Branch DIRECTLY</b> from the <b>MEDIAL CORD</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Medial Pectoral nerve}} ({{c1::C8, T1}})<br>{{c1::Medial Brachial Cutaneous nerve}}&nbsp;({{c1::T1}})<br>{{c1::Medial Antebrachial cutaneous nerve}}&nbsp;({{c1::C8, T1}})	"<b>Medial Cord</b>: Anterior Division of Inferior trunk (C8, T1) Branches (6) – 2 terminal branches from each cord<br><br>Medial Pectoral nerve (C8, T1): pierces Pec Minor; Supplies Pec Minor and Major<br>Medial Brachial cutaneous nerve (T1)<br>Medial Antebrachial cutaneous nerve (C8, T1)<br><img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
<b>Brachial Plexus CORDS </b>making up <b>Upper Extremity Nerves</b>:<br><br><b>Axillary:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Posterior}}<b><br>Radial:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Posterior}}<b><br>Median:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Lateral &amp; Medial}}<b><br>Musculocutaneous:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Lateral}}<b><br>Ulnar:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Medial}}	"<img src=""Brachial Plexus with sensory 566_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/anatomy/10052/brachial-plexus"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy::Nerves::BrachialPlexus"
<div>What is the most <b>Sensitive</b> and <b>Specific</b> test for <b>Subscapularis</b> pathology?<br><br>{{c1::Internal Rotation Lag Sign}}</div>	"Stand <b>behind</b> patient, <b>Flex Elbow </b>to <b>90°</b>, hold <b>Shoulder </b>at <b>20°</b>&nbsp;<b>Elevation</b> and <b>20° Extension</b>. <b>Internally Rotate</b>&nbsp;Shoulder to near <b>Maximum</b> holding the <b>Wrist</b> by <b>Passively lifting</b> the <b>Dorsum</b> of the Hand <b>away </b>from the <b>Lumbar Spine</b> – then supporting the<b> Elbow</b>, tell patient to <b>Maintain</b> position and <b>Release</b> the <b>Wrist</b> while <u>looking for a Lag</u>.<br><br><iframe width=""560"" height=""315"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/3pzE4Uptx6o"" title=""YouTube video player"" frameborder=""0"" allow=""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
"How do you perform a <b>Lift Off </b>Test for <b>Subscapularis</b> Pathology?<i style=""""><br></i><i><br></i>{{c1::Hand brought around Back to region of Lumbar Spine, Palm facing Outward; test patient’s ability to Lift Hand Away from back (Internal Rotation). INABILITY to do this indicates <u>Subscapularis pathology</u>. Is <u>confounded by other</u> muscles.&nbsp;}}"	"<b>More Accurate</b> if the <u>Tested <b>Hand</b></u> can reach the <u>Contralateral Scapula</u>. <br><b>More Accurate</b> for <b>INFERIOR</b> portion of <b>Subscapularis<br></b><br><iframe width=""560"" height=""315"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/__jgMNMQIQU"" title=""YouTube video player"" frameborder=""0"" allow=""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
How do you perform a&nbsp;<b>Belly Press&nbsp;</b>Test for&nbsp;<b>Subscapularis</b>&nbsp;Pathology?<i><br></i><i><br></i>{{c1::Patient <u>Presses Abdomen</u> with Palm of hand,&nbsp;<u>Maintaining Shoulder in Internal Rotation</u>. If&nbsp;<u>Elbow Drops Back</u>&nbsp;(does not remain in front of trunk), the test is&nbsp;<u>Positive for Subscapularis</u>&nbsp;weakness}}	"<b>More Accurate</b>&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>SUPERIOR</b>&nbsp;portion of&nbsp;<b>Subscapularis<br></b><br><img src=""belly_press_..jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
Patients with <b>Subscapularis </b>pathology may show INCREASED <b>PASSIVE</b> {{c1::External Rotation}} of the <b>Shoulder</b>									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
How do you perform a <b>Jobe's </b>(<b>Empty Can</b>) Test for&nbsp;<b>Supraspinatus</b>&nbsp;Pathology?<br><br>{{c1::ABduct Arm to 90°, Angle Forward 30° (bringing it into the Scapular Plane), and Internally Rotate (Thumb pointing to Floor). Then Press Down on arm while patient attempts to Maintain Position testing for Weakness or Pain.}}	"<img src=""hqdefault-f8dd8305e22f0cb6f903ca2c4572fb8257002c6c.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
How do you perform a <b>Drop Sign</b>&nbsp;Test for&nbsp;<b>Supraspinatus</b>&nbsp;Pathology?<br><br>{{c1::Passively Elevate arm in Scapular Plane to 90°. Then ask the patient to Slowly Lower the arm. The test is Positive when Weakness or Pain causes them to DROP the arm to their Side.}}	<b>Most Specific</b> test for <b>FULL Thickness</b> Rotator Cuff tear (Specificity 98%)								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
How do you perform a <b>Hornblower's sign</b>&nbsp;Test for <b>Teres Minor</b>&nbsp;Pathology?<br><br>{{c1::Bring the Shoulder to 90 degrees of ABduction, 90 degrees of External Rotation, and ask the patient to HOLD this position. POSITIVE if the arm <u>FALLS into Internal Rotation</u>}}	"<img src=""2-Figure1-1-b0b3424e10175fa0a5e29eb216bfc84b812b2075.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
How do you perform an <b>External Rotation Lag&nbsp;sign</b>&nbsp;for <b>Infraspinatus</b>&nbsp;Pathology?<br><br>{{c1::Passively <u>Flex the Elbow to 90 degree</u>s, Holding Wrist to Rotate the Shoulder to Maximal External Rotation. Tell the patient to HOLD the Arm in that Externally Rotated position.}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">If the arm starts to <u>Drift into Internal Rotation</u>, it is <b>POSITIVE</b></span>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
"How do you perform an&nbsp;<b>Active Compression</b> test (<b>""O'Brien's</b> Test"")&nbsp;for <b>Labral</b> and <b>SLAP</b> injuries?<br><br>{{c1::Patient <u>Forward Flexes</u> the affected arm to <u>90</u> degrees while keeping the <u>Elbow Fully Extended</u>. The Arm is then <u>ADducted 10-15</u> degrees ACROSS the body. The patient then PRONATES the Forearm so the Thumb is pointing DOWN. The examiner applies <u>Downward force</u> to the Wrist while the arm is in this position while the Patient Resists. The patient then Supinates the Forearm so the Palm is Up and the examiner once again applies Force to the Wrist while the Patient Resists.}}"	"<b>Positive</b> for SLAP tear when there is Pain ""<b>Deep</b>"" in the <b>Glenohumeral Joint</b> while the Forearm is <b>PRONATED</b> but <b>NOT </b>when the Forearm is <b>Supinated</b>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
On <b>Shoulder Exam</b>, what are <b>7 bony prominences</b> to palpate?<br><br>{{c1::Cervical Spinous processes<br>Sternoclavicular joint<br>Clavicle<br>Acromioclavicular joint<br>Acromion<br>Coracoid process<br>Scapular spine}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 2.33.38 PM.png""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 2.33.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 2.34.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 2.34.23 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-12-04 at 2.34.39 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
What are <b>4 aspects</b> of <b>Cervical Spine Range </b>of <b>Motion</b> to test for?<br><br>{{c1::Flexion<br>Extension<br>Lateral Flexion<br>Rotation}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/shoulder-and-elbow/3037/shoulder-exam"">Orthobullets: Shoulder Exam</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::ShoulderElbow::Shoulder::Anatomy_Eval::Exam"
What is the most Common <b>BONY Abnormality</b> that develops in patients with&nbsp;<b>Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Glenohumeral Dysplasia - Increased <u>Glenoid Retroversion</u>, <u>Humeral Head Flattening</u>, <u>Posterior Humeral Head Subluxation</u>}}	Develops in<b> 70%</b> of infants with <b>obstetric brachial plexopathy</b><br>Caused by <b>Internal Rotation contracture</b> (<b>Loss</b> of <b>External Rotation</b>)								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
"What <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Cervical Nerve Roots </span>are involved in <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Erb's Palsy</span>?<br><br>{{c1::C5 &amp; C6}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
In <b>Erb's</b> Palsy, the <b>C5 Deficiency</b> affects which <b>Peripheral Nerves</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Axillary nerve deficiency<br>Suprascapular nerve deficiency<br>Musculocutaneous nerve deficiency}}	<b>Axilllary </b>nerve deficiency - <b>Deltoid, Teres Minor</b> weakness<br><b>Suprascapular</b> nerve deficiency - <b>Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus</b> weakness<br><b>Musculocutaneous</b> nerve deficiency - <b>Biceps</b> and <b>Brachialis</b> weakness								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
In <b>Erb's</b> Palsy, the <b>C6 Deficiency</b> affects which <b>Peripheral Nerves</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Radial nerve deficiency - Brachioradialis, Supinator weakness}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
What are <b>5 Poor Prognostic variables</b> for <b>Obstretric Brachial Plexopathies</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Lack of <u>Biceps</u> function by <u>3 months</u>}}<br>{{c1::Preganglionic injuries}}&nbsp;(WORST Prognosis)<br>{{c1::Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhydrosis)}}<br>{{c1::C7}}&nbsp;involvement<br>{{c1::Klumpke's}}&nbsp;Palsy	<b>Horner's</b> syndrome -&nbsp;<b>less than 10%</b> recover<b>&nbsp;Spontaneous</b>&nbsp;Motor function								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
<b>Klumpke's “Claw Hand” </b><br><br>Wrist in <b>{{c2::Extreme Extension}}</b> because of the {{c1::<b>Unopposed Wrist Extensors</b>}}<br>{{c2::<b>Hyperextension</b> of <b>MCP</b>}}&nbsp;due to {{c1::LOSS of Hand <b>Intrinsics</b>}}<br>{{c2::<b>Flexion</b> of <b>IP joints</b>}} due to {{c1::LOSS of Hand<b> Intrinsics</b>}}	"<img src=""klumpke.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
"What is the <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Indication </span>for Serial<span style=""font-weight: 700;""> Nighttime Elbow Extension Splinting </span>in<span style=""font-weight: 700;""> Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</span>?<br><br>{{c1::Elbow Flexion Contracture &lt;40 degrees}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
<div><div><b>Allman/Neer</b>&nbsp;Classification of&nbsp;<b>lateral third clavicle</b>&nbsp;fractures</div><br>Type I: {{c1::Fracture&nbsp;<b>lateral</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>CC ligaments</b>}}</div><div>Type IIA: {{c2::Fracture&nbsp;<b>MEDIAL</b>&nbsp;to the CC ligaments}}</div><div>IIB1: {{c2::Fracture&nbsp;<b>BETWEEN</b>&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>CC&nbsp;</b>ligaments,&nbsp;<b>Conoid torn</b>}}</div><div>IIB2: {{c2::Fracture&nbsp;<b>LATERAL</b>&nbsp;to the C<b>C</b>&nbsp;ligaments,&nbsp;<b>Conoid and Trapezoid Torn</b>}}</div><div>Type Ill: {{c2::Fracture extends&nbsp;<b>INTO&nbsp;</b>the<b>&nbsp;AC</b>&nbsp;joint}}</div><div>Type IV: {{c2::<b>Physeal</b>&nbsp;fracture}}</div><div>Type V: {{c2::<b>Comminuted</b>&nbsp;fracture}}</div>	"<img src=""neer_distal_clavicle-145630ebe331246639b.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::Trauma::Clavicle"
<div><div>What is the <b>most favorable prognostic variable</b> for <b>Recovery</b> in <b>Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Early Twitch Biceps activity}}</div></div>	"<img src=""screen_shot_2014-05-25_at_8.51.35_pm.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"
What are the Risk factors for <b>Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Large for Gestational Age (Macrosomia)}}<br>{{c1::Multiparous pregnancy}}<br>{{c1::Difficult Presentation}}<br>{{c1::Shoulder Dystocia}}<br>{{c1::Forceps Delivery}}<br>{{c1::Breech Position}}<br>{{c1::Prolonged Labor}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4117/obstetric-brachial-plexopathy-erbs-klumpkes-palsy"">Orthobullets: Obstetric Brachial Plexopathy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Conditions::UpperExtremity::Plexopathy"

How do you perform a <b>Speed Test</b> for <b>Proximal Biceps</b> Pathology?<br><br>{{c1::Shoulder Forward Flexed to 90°, Elbow Extended, Forearm Supinated; pain with Resisted Elevation&nbsp;}}	"<iframe width=""560"" height=""315"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/gbG_O9Gv8aQ"" title=""YouTube video player"" frameborder=""0"" allow=""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe>"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::Sports::ProximalBiceps"
How do you perform a <b>Yergason Test</b> for <b>Proximal Biceps</b> Pathology?<br><br>{{c1::Arm by the patient's Side, Elbow Flexed to 90°; Pain with Resisted Forearm Supination and External Rotation}}	"<iframe width=""560"" height=""315"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/_Cjahul5yuI"" title=""YouTube video player"" frameborder=""0"" allow=""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe>"										"#Ortho::PP::ShoulderGirdle::Sports::ProximalBiceps"

What is the Definition of&nbsp;<b><u>Preganglionic</u></b>&nbsp;<b>Traumatic Brachial Plexus</b> injuries?<br><br>{{c1::Avulsion Proximal to Dorsal Root Ganglion}}	"<u>Involves CNS</u> which does NOT Regenerate – <u>Little Potential Recovery of motor function</u> (POOR prognosis)&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-08-04 at 3.41.59 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1008/brachial-plexus-injuries"">Orthobullets: Brachial Plexus Injuries</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Shoulder::BrachialPlexus"

"What are the Phases of&nbsp;<b>Parsonage-Turner Syndrome?<br></b><br><div><b>Phase I</b>: {{c1::Sudden Onset of Severe, Unrelenting Shoulder pain}}</div>

<div><b><i>Parona's Space</i></b><i> is a&nbsp;</i><b><i>Potential</i></b><i>&nbsp;Space Between the&nbsp;</i>{{c1::<b><i>FDP</i></b>}}<i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;</i>{{c1::<b><i>PQ </i></b>}}<b><i>Tendons</i></b></div>	"<b>Infection</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>deep hand</b>&nbsp;connecting the&nbsp;<b>Thumb</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>Small Finger</b>&nbsp;through&nbsp;<b>Parona's</b>&nbsp;space is known as a&nbsp;<b>Horseshoe Abscess<br><br></b><br><img src=""forearm-space-of-parona.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-04-28 at 7.54.29 PM.png""><b><br></b>"										"#Ortho::PP::Hand::GeneralAnatomy"

The <b>Total CSF Volume</b> between <b>Brain, Spinal cord</b>, and <b>Thecal Sac</b> is ~{{c1::150 mL}}<br><br><b>CSF Formation</b> occurs at <b>Rate</b> of&nbsp;~{{c1::500mL}} per <b>Day</b>	Thus the <b>Total Amount </b>of <b>CSF</b> is Turned Over&nbsp;<b>3-4 times</b> per day&nbsp;								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2004/spinal-cord-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::SpinalCord"

The <b>NOTOCORD</b> Forms {{c1::VENTRAL}} to <b>Neural Tube</b> and&nbsp;becomes the:<br><br>{{c1::Vertebral Bodies}}<br>{{c1::Intervertebral Discs}}	"<b>Nucleus Pulposus</b> from <b>Cells</b> of <b>Notocord</b><br><b>Annulus</b> from <b>Sclerotomal Cells</b> associated with <b>Resegmentation&nbsp;</b><br><br><img src=""gr1-356b725673fd13e948c30474823276666854e4ff.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2004/spinal-cord-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::SpinalCord"
The normal <b>Spinal Canal Diameter</b> is {{c1::17 mm}}, and<b> &lt;</b>{{c1::13 mm}} indicates possible <b>Cord Compression</b>									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
The <b>C1-C2 (Atlantoaxial) </b>Articulation is a <b>Diarthrodal</b> joint that provides:<br><br><b>{{c1::50}}</b> (of <b>{{c1::100}}</b>) degrees of <b>{{c2::Cervical Rotation&nbsp;}}</b><br><b>{{c1::10}}</b>&nbsp;(of <b>{{c1::110}}</b>) degrees of&nbsp;<b>{{c2::</b><b>Flexion/Extension&nbsp;</b><b>}}</b><br><b>{{c1::0}}</b>&nbsp;(of <b>{{c1::68}}</b>) degrees of<b>&nbsp;</b><b>{{c2::</b><b>Lateral Bend&nbsp;</b><b>}}</b>	"<img src=""atlantoaxial2.jpg""><br><img src=""cervical kinematics_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
The <b>C2-C3 </b>joint participates in <b>Subaxial (C2-C7) Motion</b>, which provides:<br><br>{{c1::50}} degrees of <b>Flexion/Extension</b> of Cervical Spine<br>{{c1::50}}&nbsp;degrees of <b>Rotation</b> of Cervical Spine<br>{{c1::60}}&nbsp;degrees of<b> Lateral Bend</b>	"<img src=""cervical kinematics_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
<b>C2</b> is supplied by a <b>Vascular Watershed</b> that exists between the<b> Apex</b> and the<b> Base</b> of the <b>Odontoid:</b><br><br><b>Apex</b> is supplied by {{c1::Branches of Internal Carotid artery}}<br><b>Base</b> is supplied from {{c1::Branches of Vertebral artery}}	"The <b>Limited Blood Supply</b> in this <b>Watershed</b> area is thought to <b>affect Healing</b> of <b>Type II Odontoid</b> fractures.&nbsp;<div><br><img src=""paste-1efddaca7a02604f53e52930ec1305f9907d6b5a.jpg""><br><br><img src=""blood supply 3_moved.jpg""><br><img src=""vert_odontoid_arcade_moved.jpg""></div>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
What are the <b>Components </b>of the <b>Occipital-C1-C2 Ligamentous</b> Complex?<br><br><div>{{c1::Odontoid Process}}<br>{{c1::Transverse}} Ligament</div><div>{{c1::Apical}} Ligaments</div><div>{{c1::Alar}} Ligaments</div>	"<b>Transverse</b> ligament - Limits <b>Anterior Translation</b> of the <b>Atlas</b><br><b>Apical </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><b>Alar </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><br><img src=""combined_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
What are the Restraints<b>&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>Transverse</b>&nbsp;ligament?&nbsp;(<b>Occipital-C1-C2 Ligamentous</b> Complex)<br><br><div>{{c1::Limits&nbsp;<b>Anterior Translation</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>Atlas</b>}}</div>	"<b>Transverse</b> ligament - Limits <b>Anterior Translation</b> of the <b>Atlas</b><br><b>Apical </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><b>Alar </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><br><img src=""combined_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
What are the Restraints<b>&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>Apical&nbsp;</b>Ligaments?&nbsp;(<b>Occipital-C1-C2 Ligamentous</b> Complex)<br><br><div>{{c1::Limit&nbsp;<b>Rotation</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>Upper Cervical</b>&nbsp;Spine}}</div>	"<b>Transverse</b> ligament - Limits <b>Anterior Translation</b> of the <b>Atlas</b><br><b>Apical </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><b>Alar </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><br><img src=""combined_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
What are the Restraints<b>&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>Alar</b><b>&nbsp;</b>Ligaments?&nbsp;(<b>Occipital-C1-C2 Ligamentous</b> Complex)<br><br><div>{{c1::Limit&nbsp;<b>Rotation</b>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>Upper Cervical</b>&nbsp;Spine}}</div>	"<b>Transverse</b> ligament - Limits <b>Anterior Translation</b> of the <b>Atlas</b><br><b>Apical </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><b>Alar </b>Ligaments - Limit <b>Rotation</b> of the <b>Upper Cervical</b> Spine<br><img src=""posterior.jpg""><br><br><img src=""combined_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
<div>In the&nbsp;<b>Subaxial Spine</b>, <b>C</b>{{c1::1}} to <b>C</b>{{c1::7}} have a <b>Transverse Foramen</b></div>	"Transverse foramen smaller in C7 and in majority of patients the vertebral artery doesn’t run through it so can place pedicle screw more safely<br><img src=""transverse-foramen.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
"<div>In the&nbsp;<b>Subaxial Spine</b>, <b>C</b>{{c1::2}} to <b>C</b>{{c1::6}} have<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;<b>Bifid Spinous Processes</b></span></div>"	"<img src=""Characteristic-Features-of-a-Cervical-Vertebrae.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
"<div>In the&nbsp;<b>Subaxial Spine</b>, <b>C</b>{{c1::6}} <span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">contains a <b>Palpable Carotid Tubercle</b> which is a <b>Valuble Landmark</b> for the&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Anterior}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>&nbsp;Approach</b> to <b>Cervical</b> Spine</span></div>"	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/339677995/figure/fig1/AS:885112434601985@1588038657592/Location-of-the-carotid-Chassaignacs-tubercle-A-The-anterior-projection-of-the.ppm"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
<div>In the&nbsp;<b>Subaxial Spine</b>, <b>C</b>{{c1::7}} has a Nonbifid Spinous process</div>	"Despite having a <b>Transverse Foramen</b>, the <b>Vertebral</b> artery <b>does NOT Travel</b> Through it in the <b>Majority</b> of patients<br><br>Known as the <b>VERTEBRAL PROMINENS</b><br><img src=""Gray-square.001_gallery.jpeg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
The <b>Superior Articular Facets</b> of the <b>Subaxial Cervical spine (C3-C7)</b> are oriented in a <b>{{c1::PosteroMedial}}</b> direction at <b>C{{c2::3}}&nbsp;</b>and <b>{{c1::PosteroLateral}}</b> direction at <b>C{{c2::7}}</b>, with a <b>Variable Transition</b> between these levels	"<img src=""cervical_kinemat.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
In the <b>Cervical Spine</b>,<b> C</b>{{c1::1 (Atlas)}} has <b>NO Vertebral Body</b> and <b>NO Spinous Process</b>	"<img src=""Dens_anatomy.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
In the <b>Cervical Spine</b>,<b> C1 (Atlas)</b>&nbsp;develops from {{c1::3}}&nbsp;<b>Ossification</b> centers: <b>1</b> from each {{c1::<u>Lateral Mass</u> (Posterior Neural Arches)}} and&nbsp;<b>1</b> for {{c1::Anterior Arch}}	"<b>Lateral Masses Fuse</b> to <b>Body</b> at <b>age 7<br>Anterior</b> arch does <b>NOT</b> appear until <b>1 year</b> of age&nbsp;<br><img src=""atlas ossification.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
In the <b>Cervical Spine</b>,<b>&nbsp;</b>the <b>Occiput</b>-<b>C1</b>&nbsp;Articulation makes up {{c1::50}}% of <b>Flexion</b> and <b>Extension</b>	"<b>2 S</b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><b>uperior Concave Facets</b> that Articulate with the <b>Occipital Condyles</b></span><br><br><img src=""bq5CqOyrmm9juIz3bR7rlw.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
The <b>Axis (C2)</b>&nbsp;<b>Develops</b>&nbsp;from {{c1::5}} <b>Ossification Centers</b>	"<b>Subdental (Basilar) Synchondrosis</b> is an Initial <b>Cartilagenous Junction</b> between the <b>Dens</b> and <b>Vertebral body </b>that does <b>NOT Fuse</b> until <b>~6 years</b> of age<br><br>The <b>Secondary Ossification Center</b> appears at ~ <b>age 3</b> and <b>Fuses</b> to the <b>Dens</b> at age <b>~12 years</b><br><br><img src=""ossification center c2.jpg""><br><img src=""basilar_moved.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2069/cervical-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Cervical Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Cervical"
The <b>Normal Thoracic Kyphosis</b> Averages {{c1::35}}°&nbsp;<br><br>Normal&nbsp;<b>Range</b> is {{c1::20}}° to {{c1::50}}°	"<img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Katherine-Prenovost/publication/6055989/figure/fig2/AS:302633693794306@1449164903542/The-Cobb-angle-of-thoracic-kyphosis-calculated-from-a-lateral-radiograph.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"
"What is the <b>Name</b> of the <b>Long, Prominent Spinous Process</b> found at<b> C7</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Vertebral Prominens}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);""><br></span>"	"<img src=""600px-Vertebra-prominens-grays-illustration.jpeg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"
<b>Costal Facets</b> are&nbsp;present on ALL <b>Vertebral Bodies</b> and <b>Transverse Processes</b> from {{c1::T1}} to {{c1::T9}}	"<b>Articulation</b> between <b>Ribs</b> and <b>Vertebral Segments</b><br><br><b>Articulation</b> with <b>Ribs</b> leads to <b>Increased Rigidity</b> of <b>Thoracic Spine </b>(MOST <b>Rigid </b>in <b>Axial Skeleton</b>)<br><br><img src=""DA8C28FF1.jpg"">&nbsp;<img src=""https://o.quizlet.com/U5jMg.P3sFXZ9X2xDwktQg_b.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"

<b>Thoracic Pedicle length</b><br><br><b>T1</b>: {{c1::20 mm}}<br><b>T4</b>: {{c1::14 mm (shortest pedicle)}}<br><b>T10</b>: {{c1::20 mm}}	<b>Pedicle Length DECREASES</b> from <b>T1</b> to <b>T4</b> and then <b>INCREASES</b> again as you move<b> Distal</b> in the <b>Thoracic Spine</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"
The <b>Transverse Pedicle Angle</b> Varies from<b> {{c1::10}}</b><b><sup>o</sup></b><b>&nbsp;({{c2::Mid-Thoracic Spine</b><b>::Location</b><b>}})</b> to <b>{{c1::30}}<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;({{c2::L5::Location}})</b>	"<img src=""transverse pedicle angle.jpg""><br><img src=""https://www.researchgate.net/publication/349365012/figure/fig1/AS:992065605341195@1613538280232/Measurements-of-each-parameters-a-Pedicle-height-b-pedicle-width-c-pedicle-axis.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"
"T<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">he <b>Pedicle Wall</b> is&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Twice}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 35, 35);"">&nbsp;as <b>Thick Medially</b> as <b>Laterally</b></span>"	"Bounce off medially<br><img src=""Features-of-the-Vertebral-Arch-Superior-View-of-a-Lumbar-Vertebrae1.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"
The <b>Sagittal Pedicle Angle</b> is {{c1::15-17}}° {{c1::<b>Cephalad</b>}} for <b>Majority</b> of <b>Thoracic</b> Spine	"<b>Neutral </b>(0°) for <b>Lumbar</b> spine except <b>L5 (Caudal)<br><br></b><img src=""sagittal pedicle angle.jpg""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-08-15 at 1.12.49 AM.png""><b><br></b>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"
The <b>Sagittal Pedicle Angle</b> is {{c1::<b>Neutral&nbsp;</b>(0°)}}&nbsp;for&nbsp;<b>Lumbar</b>&nbsp;spine except&nbsp;{{c1::L5 (Caudal)}}	"<img src=""sagittal pedicle angle.jpg""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2022-08-15 at 1.12.49 AM.png""><b><br></b>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2070/thoracic-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Thoracic Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Thoracic"

<b>Lumbar Lordosis</b> is on <b>Average</b> {{c1::60}}<b><sup>o</sup></b>, with a <b>Normal Range </b>of {{c1::20-80}}<b><sup>o</sup></b>	<b>Apex </b>of Lordosis at <b>L3</b><br><b>Disc Spaces</b> Responsible for <b>Most</b> of Lordosis								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2071/lumbar-spine-anatomy"">Orthobullets: Lumbar Spine Anatomy</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Basic_ClinicalScience::Anatomy::Lumbar"

</div></div><b><u><br></u></b></div><div>Origin: {{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);""><b>Spinous</b> process <b>T1-T6</b></span>}}<br>Insertion: {{c1::<b>T</b><span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);""><b>ransverse</b> process <b>C1-C4</b></span>}}<br>Action: {{c2::<b>Laterally Rotate &amp; Flex Neck </b>to <b>SAME</b> Side}}<br>Nerve: {{c2::<b>Dorsal Rami </b>of <b>Inferior Cervical </b>Nerves}}<span style=""color: rgb(35, 31, 32);""><br></span></div>

With&nbsp;<b>Treatment </b>of&nbsp;<b>Subtrochanteric Femur </b>Fractures, How can a <b>Blade Plate function</b> as a <b>Tension Band Construct</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Femur <u>Eccentrically Loaded</u> with <u>Tensile force on the Lateral</u> cortex converted to <u>Compressive force on Medial</u> cortex}}	"<span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">In order for a fracture to be successfully treated w</span><span style=""background-color: rgb(211, 233, 226); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">ith tension band principles the bone must be eccentrically loaded,</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;the construct must be</span><span style=""background-color: rgb(211, 233, 226); color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">&nbsp;applied on the tensile side</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"">, and the opposite cortex must be able to withstand compressive forces.&nbsp;<br><br></span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51); background-color: rgb(252, 252, 252);"">Tension bands function by <b>converting distraction forces into compressive forces that are evenly distributed across a fracture site</b>, to create an environment favourable for fracture healing.</span><span style=""color: rgb(51, 51, 51);""><br></span><br><img src=""jr_xr_pelvis_postop.jpg""><br><img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-030-36990-3_9/MediaObjects/459434_1_En_9_Fig1_HTML.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-03-30 at 3.27.31 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1039/subtrochanteric-fractures"">Orthobullets: Subtrochanteric Femur Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Shaft&Distal_Femur::SubtrochFx"

With <b>Terrible Triad</b> Injuries of the <b>Elbow</b>, what is the <b>Order</b> in which the <b>Soft </b>Tissue&nbsp;<b>Structures Fail</b>?<br><br><b>1st</b>: {{c1::LCL}}<br><b>2nd</b>: {{c1::Anterior Capsule}}<br><b>3rd</b>: {{c1::MCL}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-10-05 at 3.48.02 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1021/terrible-triad-injury-of-elbow"">Orthobullets: Terrible Triad Injury of the Elbow</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Elbow::TerribleTriad"
What are the <b>Step-wise</b> principles for the <b>Operative</b> management of <b>Terrible Triad Injuries</b>?<br><br>1: Restore {{c1::<b>Coronoid</b>}}<b>&nbsp;Stability</b> through <b>Fracture Fixation</b>&nbsp;or <b>Capsular Repair</b><br>2: Restore {{c1::<b>Radial Head</b>}}<b>&nbsp;Stability</b> through <b>Fracture Fixation</b> or <b>Replacement</b> with a <b>Metal prosthesis</b><br>3: Restore<b>&nbsp;</b>{{c1::<b>Lateral Elbow&nbsp;</b>}}<b>Stability</b> through <b>Repair</b> of the<b> LCL complex </b><br>4: Repair the {{c1::<b>MCL</b>}}&nbsp;in patients with <b>Residual Posterior Instability</b><br>5: Apply a {{c1::<b>Hinged External Fixator or Internal joint stabilizer (IJS)</b>}}<b>&nbsp;</b>when conventional Repair did <b>NOT</b> establish <b>Sufficient Joint Stability</b> to allow <b>Early Motion</b>	These patients will get stiff without early ROM								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1021/terrible-triad-injury-of-elbow"">Orthobullets: Terrible Triad Injury of the Elbow</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Elbow::TerribleTriad"
<b>Treatment</b> of <b>Elbow&nbsp;Terrible Triad</b>&nbsp;Injuries involves {{c2::<b>ORIF</b> of the <b>Radial Head</b>}}&nbsp;if there is&nbsp;<b>&lt;</b>{{c1::40}}<b>% involvement </b>of the <b>Articular Surface</b> and <b>Without Comminution</b>	Otherwise Radial head arthroplasty								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1021/terrible-triad-injury-of-elbow"">Orthobullets: Terrible Triad Injury of the Elbow</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Elbow::TerribleTriad"

"Where is the <b>Incision</b> made<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the <b>ANTERIOR Approach</b> to the <b>Ankle </b>Joint?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::<b>15-cm Longitudinal </b>incision over the <b>Anterior</b> aspect of the <b>Ankle</b> Joint. Begin about <b>10 cm Proximal</b> to the Joint
and <b>Extend </b>the incision so that it <b>Crosses the joint</b> about <b>Midway</b> between the <b>Malleoli</b>, <b>Ending</b> on the <b>Dorsum</b> of the <b>Foot.</b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><br><br>ALTERNATIVELY:<br><br></span><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c2::<b>15-cm</b> Longitudinal Incision with its <b>Center Overlying</b> the <b>Anterior Aspect</b> of the <b>Medial Malleolus</b>}}<br></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>

"What is the <b>Internervous/Intermuscular Plane</b> used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the <b>ANTERIOR Approach</b> to the <b>Ankle </b>Joint?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::NO True Internervous Plane - EHL &amp; EDL (both DPN) define a Clear Intermuscular plane}}</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-19 at 11.01.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.05.19 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.05.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.06.27 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.06.46 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::Anterior"
"What is the <b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b> used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the <b>ANTERIOR Approach</b> to the <b>Ankle </b>Joint?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>1.<b> Incise</b> the {{c1::<b>Deep Fascia</b> of the Leg}}<b> IN LINE </b>with the <b>Skin Incision</b>, cutting through the {{c1::<b>Extensor Retinacula</b>}}<br>2. Find
the <b>Plane b/w</b> the {{c2::<b>EHL </b>and <b>EDL</b> <b>muscles</b>}} a few <b>CM </b>ABOVE the <b>Ankle</b> joint, and Identify the <b>{{c2::Neurovascular Bundle (AT artery and DPN)}}</b> just <b>{{c2::MEDIAL}}</b> to the <b>Tendon</b> of the <b>{{c2::EHL}}</b>. <br>3. <b>Trace</b> the <b>Bundle Distally</b> until it Crosses the <b>Front </b>of the <b>Ankle</b> joint <b>BEHIND </b>the Tendon of the <b>EHL</b>. <br>4. <b>Retract </b>the Tendon of the <b>{{c3::EHL}} Medially</b>, together with the <b>{{c3::NV bundle}}</b>. <br>5. Retract the Tendon of the {{c4::EDL}} <b>Laterally</b>. The <b>Tendons</b> become <b>Mobile </b>after the <b>Retinaculum</b> has been <b>Cut</b>, but the <b>NV Bundle adheres</b> to the <b>Underlying Tissues</b> and <b>Requires Mobilization.</b></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"Alternatively, in<b> Pilon Fractures</b>, incise the <b>Deep Fascia </b>to the <b>Medial side</b> of the <b>Tibialis Anterior</b> tendon, and Expose the <b>Underlying Surface </b>of the <b>Tibia</b> together with the <b>Anteromedial Ankle Joint Capsule</b>.&nbsp;<br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.05.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.06.27 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-08 at 2.06.46 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::Anterior"

What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>ANTERIOR (Deltopectoral) Approach</b>&nbsp;to "With&nbsp;<b>Lunate Dislocation / Perilunate Dissociations</b>, what are the <b>2 Main Benefits</b> of&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Emergent Closed Reduction/Splinting</span>?<span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span><br>{{c1::Decreased Risk of Median n. Damage}}<br>{{c1::Decreased Risk of Cartilage Damage}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6045/lunate-dislocation-perilunate-dissociation"">Orthobullets: Lunate Dislocation (Perilunate Dissociation)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Trauma::Carpal::LunateDislocation_PerilunateDissociation"
"With&nbsp;<b>Lunate Dislocation / Perilunate Dissociations</b>, what are <b>2 </b>Common <b>Complications</b> DESPITE&nbsp;<b>Prompt Surgical </b>Treatment?<span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span><br>{{c1::Return to Full Function UNLIKELY}}<br>{{c1::Decreased Grip Strength and Stiffness are Common}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6045/lunate-dislocation-perilunate-dissociation"">Orthobullets: Lunate Dislocation (Perilunate Dissociation)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Trauma::Carpal::LunateDislocation_PerilunateDissociation"
"With&nbsp;<b>Lunate Dislocation / Perilunate Dissociations</b>, what is the&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Indication&nbsp;</span>for <b>Proximal Row Carpectomy</b>?<span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span><br>{{c1::Chronic Injury (&gt;8 weeks after initial Injury)}}"	Relatively Common since Initial Diagnosis often missed								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6045/lunate-dislocation-perilunate-dissociation"">Orthobullets: Lunate Dislocation (Perilunate Dissociation)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Trauma::Carpal::LunateDislocation_PerilunateDissociation"
"With&nbsp;<b>Lunate Dislocation / Perilunate Dissociations</b>, what is the&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Indication&nbsp;</span>for <b>Total Wrist Arthrodesis</b>?<span style=""font-weight: 700;""><br></span><br>{{c1::Chronic Injury (&gt;8 weeks after initial Injury) with DEGENERATIVE CHANGES}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6045/lunate-dislocation-perilunate-dissociation"">Orthobullets: Lunate Dislocation (Perilunate Dissociation)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Trauma::Carpal::LunateDislocation_PerilunateDissociation"
With&nbsp;<b>Lunate Dislocation / Perilunate Dissociations</b>, what are <b>5 Steps</b> for <b>Closed Reduction</b> and <b>Splinting</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Finger Traps, Elbow at 90 degrees of Flexion}}<br>{{c1::Hand 5-10 lbs Traction for 15 Minutes}}<br>{{c1::Dorsal Dislocations are Reduced through Wrist Extension, Traction, and Flexion of Wrist}}<br>{{c1::Apply Sugar Tong Splint}}<br>{{c1::Follow with Surgery}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6045/lunate-dislocation-perilunate-dissociation"">Orthobullets: Lunate Dislocation (Perilunate Dissociation)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Trauma::Carpal::LunateDislocation_PerilunateDissociation"
"With&nbsp;<b>Lunate Dislocation / Perilunate Dissociations</b>,<b>&nbsp;</b>where<b> </b>is the <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Incision Centered </span>for the <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Dorsal </span>Approach for <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Open Reduction</span> w/ <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Ligament Repair</span> and Fixation?<br><br>{{c1::Longitudinal Incision Centered at Lister's Tubercle}}"	"Excellent <b>Exposure</b> of <b>Proximal Carpal Row</b> and <b>Midcarpal joints</b><br><br>Does <b>NOT</b> allow for <b>Carpal Tunnel Release<br></b><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/combined-approach-to-perilunate-fractures-and-dislocations#elevate-the-skin-flap"">AO: Combined Approach to Perilunate Dislocation</a><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-30 at 9.42.26 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6045/lunate-dislocation-perilunate-dissociation"">Orthobullets: Lunate Dislocation (Perilunate Dissociation)</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Hand::Trauma::Carpal::LunateDislocation_PerilunateDissociation"

What makes a Good <b>PA Radiograph</b> of the <b>Wrist</b>?<br><br>{{c1::ECU Groove at or just Radial to the Ulnar Styloid}}	"<img src=""Normal-wrist-AP-9.jpg"">"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::UE"
"What are some <b>Indications</b> for using the <b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br>{{c1::ORIF <u>Irreducible, Displaced</u> Scaphoid fractures, in the <u>Distal 2/3s</u>}}<br>{{c1::ORIF <u>Comminuted</u> fractures}}<br><div>
<div>
<div><div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><u>Bone Grafting for Nonunion</u> of the Scaphoid</span>}}</div>
<div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><u>Excision</u> of the <u>Proximal 1/3</u> of the Scaphoid</span>}}</div>
<div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><u>Excision</u> of the <u>Radial Styloid</u>, either Alone or Combined with one of the Above Procedures</span>}}</div></div></div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"									"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
"What is the <b>Position</b> of the Patient during the <b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::SUPINE on the Operating Table, with the Arm Lying on an Arm Board. <u>Supinate the Forearm</u> to Expose
the <u>Volar Aspect</u> of the Wrist, and apply a Tourniquet}}<br></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-28 at 9.19.59 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
"What are the <b>Landmarks&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Scaphoid Tubercle - Volar Wrist, just DISTAL to the Wrist Crease}}<br>{{c1::FCR - Radial to the Palmaris Longus at level of Wrist}}<br></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""70_22_palmar_approach_scaphoid_2_illustration.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
"Where is the <b>Incision&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Over FCR tendon, starting at Scaphoid Tubercle, &amp; Running Proximally ~ 2 cm. Distal to the Scaphoid Tubercle, Incision angles Towards the Base of the Thumb, over the Scaphotrapezial joint}}<br><br>ALTERNATIVELY,<br><br>{{c1::a Zig-Zag incision can be used with the same landmarks}}<br></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""70_22_palmar_approach_scaphoid_2_illustration.png""><img src=""70_22_palmar_approach_scaphoid_2_photo.png""><br><img src=""70_22_palmar_approach_scaphoid_3.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
"What is the <b>Internervous Plane&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::NONE -&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">the only muscle mobilized is the FCR (supplied by the Median n.)</span>}}</div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""70_22_palmar_approach_scaphoid_2_illustration.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>1. Incise</b> the <b>Deep Fascia</b> in <b>Line</b> with the <b>Skin Incision</b> &amp; <b>Identify</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Radial a.}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;</b>on the <b>Radial Side</b><br><b>2. Retract</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Radial a.}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;&amp;&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Radial Skin Flap}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;to the <b>RADIAL&nbsp;</b>Side. <br><b>3.&nbsp;</b>The&nbsp;</span>{{c3::<b>Superficial Palmar Branch</b> of
the <b>artery</b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">, which runs Close to the <b>Scaphoid Tubercle</b>, may <b>Cross</b> the Field &amp; need <b>Ligation</b>.<br><b>4. Identify</b> the <b>Tendon</b> of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c4::FCR}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;and Trace it <b>Distally</b>, <b>Incising</b> that portion of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c4::Flexor Retinaculum}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;that lies <b>Superficial</b> to it. <br><b>5. After </b>the <b>Tendon</b> has been <b>FREED</b> from its <b>Tunnel</b> in the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c5::Flexor Retinaculum}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>, Retract</b> it&nbsp;</span><b>{{c5::Ulnarly}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;to
expose the <b>Volar Aspect </b>of the <b>Radial Side</b> of the <b>Wrist joint&nbsp;</b></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.45.06 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.45.28 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Volar</b> Approach to the <b>Scaphoid</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>1. Incise</b> the <b>C</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>apsule</b> of the <b>Wrist</b> Joint <b>Obliquely</b> Over the <b>Scaphoid </b>to <b>Expose</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Distal 2/3s}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;of the <b>Scaphoid</b>. <br><b>2.&nbsp;</b>Begin
at the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<b>Tubercle</b> of the <b>Scaphoid</b> <b>Distally</b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;and <b>Extend</b> the <b>Incision</b> <b>Proximally</b> until the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Palmar Rim}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;of the <b>Distal Radius </b>is
reached. <br><b>3.&nbsp;</b>Try to Preserve as Much of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c3::Palmar Ligament Complex}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;as possible to <b>Stabilize</b> the <b>Proximal Pole</b> of the <b>Scaphoid</b>. This <b>Anterior</b> area of Bone is <b>Nonarticular</b>. <br><b>4.&nbsp;</b>To gain the <b>Best View</b> of the <b>Proximal 1/3</b> of the <b>Bone</b>, place the <b>Wrist</b> in <b>Marked</b>&nbsp;</span><b>{{c4::Dorsiflexion&nbsp;}}</b></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.53.18 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.53.36 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.54.42 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.55.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-17 at 2.55.37 PM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/carpal-bones/approach/palmar-approach-to-the-scaphoid"">AO: Palmar Approach to the Scaphoid</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Volar_Scaphoid"
What is the&nbsp;<b>POSITION</b>&nbsp;of the Patient when using&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Malleolus</b>?<br><br><div><div><div><div>{{c1::Supine with <u>Sandbag</u> under Buttock of <u>Affected Limb</u>. Tilt Table AWAY from you Increase <u>INTERNAL Rotation</u>. Exansanguinate by <u>Elevating for 1 Minute</u>, then Inflate a <u>Tourniquet</u>.}}</div></div></div></div>	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-19 at 9.07.06 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-19 at 9.09.25 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/malleoli/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Malleoli</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::LateralMal"
"What are the&nbsp;<b>Landmarks&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Malleolus</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::Subcutaneous Surface of Fibula &amp; Lateral Mal<br><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">Short Saphenous Vein -</span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;seen running along Posterior Border of Lateral Mal Before the Limb is Exsanguinated</span>}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-19 at 10.56.12 AM.png""><br><img src=""44_a010_i100.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/malleoli/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Malleoli</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::LateralMal"
Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Malleolus</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::10-15 cm Incision in Line with the Fibula, starting Proximally}}<br></div>	"If Necessary, continue&nbsp;<b>Distally</b>&nbsp;a&nbsp;<b>Further 2 cm</b>, curving&nbsp;<b>Slightly Anteriorly&nbsp;</b>in Relation to the&nbsp;<b>Tip&nbsp;</b>of the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Mal</b>, in order to&nbsp;<u><b>Increase Exposure</b>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<b>Release Tension</b></u><br><br>In <b>Fracture</b> Surgery, Center Incision at <b>Level</b> of <b>Fracture</b><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-19 at 9.22.46 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/malleoli/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Malleoli</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::LateralMal"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Malleolus</b>?<br><br><div><b>1. </b>The <b>Dissection Plane</b> is <b>Between</b> the <b>{{c1::Peroneus Tertius}}</b> <b>Anteriorly</b> and the <b>{{c1::Peroneus Longus}}</b> AND&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Brevis}} Posteriorly<br></b><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>2. Elevate</b> the <b>Skin Flaps</b>, taking care Not to <b>Damage</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Short Saphenous}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;Vein&nbsp;</b>AND&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Sural}} nerve</b>&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">which lie&nbsp;<b>Posterior</b> to the <b>Lateral Mal</b>.&nbsp;<br><b>3. </b>Be Careful Not to <b>Damage</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c3::SPN}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">, which lies very close <b>Anteriorly</b>, Especially in the <b>Proximal Portion</b> of the Incision.</span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<em>In more <b>Anterior incisions</b>, <b>SPN </b>should be <b>Identified </b>and <b>Protected</b>.</em><br><img src=""44_a010_i110.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/malleoli/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Malleoli</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::LateralMal"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Malleolus</b>?<br><br><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>1. Incise</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Periosteum}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;of the <b>Subcutaneous Surface</b> of the Fibula <b>Longitudinally</b> and <b>Strip</b> off just enough at the <b>Fracture Site</b> to <b>Expose</b> the Fracture Adequately. <br><b>2.&nbsp;</b>Take care to Keep ALL <b>Dissection Strictly</b>&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Subperiosteal}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">, because the&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<b>Terminal Branches</b> of the <b>Peroneal Artery</b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">, which lie close to the <b>Lateral Mal</b>, may be <b>Damaged</b>.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">Strip off only as much Periosteum as is Necessary for Accurate Reduction; Periosteal Stripping Markedly Reduces the Blood Supply of Bone in cases of Fracture. <br>The Anterior Distal Tibiofibular joint can be Visualized by Following the Distal Fibula Anteriorly, allowing careful checking of the Distal Syndesmosis Following Fracture Fixation&nbsp;</span><br><img src=""44_a010_i120.jpg""><br><img src=""44_a010_lat_4b.png"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-19 at 9.37.29 AM.png"">"				"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/malleoli/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Malleoli</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Foot_Ankle::Ankle::LateralMal"
"What are some&nbsp;<b>Indications</b>&nbsp;for using the <b>Dorsal Approach</b> to the <b>Forearm, Wrist,</b> and <b>Carpus</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Synovectomy of the Extensor Tendons<br>Dorsal Ganglion Cyst Excision<br>Wrist
arthrodesis<br>Proximal Row Carpectomy<br><u>ORIF of Distal Radius Fractures</u><br><u>Scapholunate</u> Ligament Repairs<br>Extensor Tendon Repairs at the <u>Level of the Distal Forearm</u><br>Vascularized Bone Grafting from the Distal Radius<br>Fixation of <u>Proximal Pole Scaphoid</u> fractures<br>PIN Neurectomy&nbsp;}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.52.46 AM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.56.08 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.00 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.17 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-forearm/approach/dorsal-approach"">AO: Dorsal Approach to Distal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Dorsal_ForearmWristCarpus"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Position</b>&nbsp;of the Patient during&nbsp;the <b>Dorsal Approach</b> to the <b>Forearm, Wrist,</b> and <b>Carpus</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::SUPINE on the Operating Table, Arm Pronated on Hand Table<br>Exsanguinate the Arm and Elevate Tourniquet if Indicated}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.36.29 AM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.56.08 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.00 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.17 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-forearm/approach/dorsal-approach"">AO: Dorsal Approach to Distal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Dorsal_ForearmWristCarpus"
"Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Dorsal Approach</b> to the <b>Forearm, Wrist,</b> and <b>Carpus</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::<u>6-8 cm Vertical</u> Incision Centered on the <u>Dorsal Aspect</u> of the Wrist <u>Between the Radius
and Ulna</u>, just <u>ULNAR to Lister’s Tubercle</u>}}
<br><br></div>
<div>The <b>Incision Extends</b> {{c1::3}} cm <b>Proximal</b> to the <b>Wrist joint</b> and {{c1::5}} cm <b>Distal
</b><br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"The length of the incision depends on the procedure being performed&nbsp;<br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.39.15 AM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.56.08 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.00 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.17 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-forearm/approach/dorsal-approach"">AO: Dorsal Approach to Distal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Dorsal_ForearmWristCarpus"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Dorsal Approach</b> to the <b>Forearm, Wrist,</b> and <b>Carpus</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::<u>Skin and Subcutaneous Tissues</u>}} are <b>Dissected down</b> to the {{c1::<u>Extensor Retinaculum</u>}} <b>Above</b> the {{c1::<u>4th</u>}}<b> Extensor Compartment</b></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.40.56 AM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.56.08 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.00 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.17 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-forearm/approach/dorsal-approach"">AO: Dorsal Approach to Distal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Dorsal_ForearmWristCarpus"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Dorsal Approach</b> to the <b>Forearm, Wrist,</b> and <b>Carpus</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>1. Incise</b> the <b>{{c1::Extensor Retinaculum}}</b> BETWEEN the <b>{{c1::3rd}}</b> and <b>{{c1::4th}} Compartments</b><br><b>2. Transpose</b> the <b>{{c2::EPL}}</b> and <b>Dissect UNDER&nbsp;</b>the <b>{{c2::Extensor Compartments}}</b> but <b>ABOVE</b> the <b>{{c2::Joint Capsule&nbsp;}}</b><br><b>3. Retract</b> the <b>3rd</b> and <b>4th Extensor Compartments</b> to <b>Expose</b> the {{c3::<b>Dorsal Extrinsic Wrist Ligaments</b>}} and <b>{{c3::Joint Capsule}}</b></div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>

<div><b>4. Incise</b> the <b>{{c4::Dorsal Capsule}}</b> over the <b>Distal Radius</b> and <b>Extend</b> the Incision <b>Distally</b> to <b>Expose</b> the <b>{{c4::Distal Radius, Radiocarpal joint, and Carpal bones::3}}</b><br>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.40.56 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.43.25 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-01-20 at 9.43.47 AM.png"">"							"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.56.08 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.00 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-02-03 at 3.57.17 PM.png"">"	"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-forearm/approach/dorsal-approach"">AO: Dorsal Approach to Distal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Hand_Wrist::Dorsal_ForearmWristCarpus"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Closure</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;After</b>&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Dorsal Approach</b> to the <b>Forearm, Wrist,</b> and <b>Carpus</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Repair the Capsule with Suture<br>
Return the EPL to the 3rd Compartment or keep it Transposed and <u>Repair the Retinaculum</u>
<br>Subcutaneous Tissue and Skin are Approximated with Suture&nbsp;}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
