<div><div>What finding on <b>Spine MRI</b> would suggest a <b>PLC injury</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Increased <u>Signal Intensity</u> on <u>T2-Weighted</u> Images in PLC}}</div></div>	"<div><div>Concerning for <b>Instability </b>and may warrant <b>Surgical Intervention<br></b><br>Best Visualized on the <b>Sagittal Images<br><br></b><img src=""1-s2.0-S1529943011004773-gr1.jpg""><b><br></b></div></div>"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
<div><div>What are the <b>Indications</b> for <b>Treating Burst</b> Fractures <b>Nonoperatively</b>?<br><br>Patients that are&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Neurologically Intact}}</b>&nbsp;and <b>{{c1::Mechanically Stable}}</b><br><br><b>{{c2::PLC}} Preserved</b><br><b>No {{c2::Focal Kyphosis}}</b> on <b>Flexion</b> and <b>Extension</b> Lateral <b>Radiographs</b><br><b>Kyphosis &lt; {{c3::30}}° </b>(Controversial)<br><b>Vertebral Body</b> has <b>Lost &lt; {{c3::50}}%</b> of <b>Body Height</b> (Controversial)</div></div>	<b>Decreased Complication Rates</b> in <b>Neurologically Intact </b>patients treated <b>Nonsurgically</b><br><b><br>Equivalent Outcomes</b> in <b>Neurologically Intact</b> patients								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
The <b>Indications</b> for <b>Posterior Instrumented Fusion/Stabilization</b> of <b>Burst</b> Fractures are <b>Unstable</b> Fracture <b>Patterns</b> as defined by:<br><br>{{c1::Injury to the <u>PLC</u>}}<br>{{c1::Progressive <u>Kyphosis</u>}}<br>{{c1::<u>Lamina</u> Fractures (controversial)}}<br>{{c1::Polytrauma&nbsp;}}	Surgical stabilization in Polytrauma can Assist with Recovery and Rehabilitation of Other injuries								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
What are the <b>Indications</b> for <b>Neurologic Decompression &amp; Stabilization</b>&nbsp;of <b>Burst</b> Fractures?<br><br><div>{{c1::Neurologic Deficits with Radiographic Evidence of Cord/Thecal Sac Compression }}<br>{{c1::TLICS Score = 5 or Higher}}<br></div>	"Both <b>Complete</b> and <b>Incomplete Spinal Cord injuries</b> require <b>Decompression </b>and <b>Stabilization</b> to Facilitate <b>Rehabilitation&nbsp;<br></b><br><img src=""a54c216784651b_9j-TAB-overview.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
What are <b>3 Instances</b> that a <b>Posterior Decompression</b> is Preferred for the <b>Treatment </b>of&nbsp;<b>Burst</b>&nbsp;Fractures?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Below Conus</u> so possible to <u>Medialize Thecal Sac</u> to perform <u>Decompression of Canal</u> / <u>Posterior Corpectomy and Expandable Cage</u>}}<br><br>{{c1::Injury to <u>PLC</u> so Posterior Tension-Band Stabilization Required}}<br><br>{{c1::Fracture Dislocations}}	<b>Possible Complication</b> of Posterior Stabilization = <b>Loss</b> of <b>Sagittal Plane Correction</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
What are 5<b>&nbsp;Instances</b> that an <b>Anterior&nbsp;Decompression</b> is Preferred for the <b>Treatment </b>of&nbsp;<b>Burst</b>&nbsp;Fractures?<br><br><b>Neurologic Deficits</b> caused by {{c2::<b>Anterior Compression</b> (Bony <b>Retropulsion</b>)}}, especially <b>Above</b> the {{c2::<b>Conus</b> Medullaris (above L2)}}<br>Allow for {{c2::<b>Thorough Decompression</b>}} of the <b>Thecal Sac</b><br>Substantial <b>Vertebral Body&nbsp;</b>{{c3::<b>Comminution</b>}} in order to <b>Reconstitute</b> the {{c3::<b>Anterior Column</b>}}<br><b>Kyphotic Deformity &gt;{{c1::30°}}</b><br><b>&gt;{{c1::4-5 days}}</b> from the Injury									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
With&nbsp;<b>Burst</b>&nbsp;Fractures, what are <b>3 Complications</b> of <b>Over-Distracting</b> a <b>Posterior Instrumented Construct</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Pseudoarthrosis}}<br>{{c1::Chronic Pain}}<br>{{c1::Recurrent Deformity}}									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
With&nbsp;<b>Burst</b>&nbsp;Fractures, How Many <b>Levels</b> should be included in <b>Posterior Constructs</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Modern Constructs typically involve <u>1 Level Above</u> and <u>1 Level Below</u> the Injury}}	<b>Short Segment Fixation</b> <b><u>NOT</u></b> Suitable for injuires involving the <b>Thoracolumbar Junction</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
With&nbsp;<b>Burst</b>&nbsp;Fractures, How is <b>Indirect Decompression</b> Performed through a <b>Posterior Instrumented</b> Construct?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Distraction and Lordosing Rod</u> Construct leads to <u>Ligamentotaxis</u> of the Retropulsed Fragments}}	"<b>Attachments</b> of the <b>Annulus Fibrosis</b> and<b> PLL</b> to the Fragments <b>Facilitates Reduction</b><br><br><b>LESS </b>Effective if Performed<b> 4-5 Days after</b> the Injury<br><br><img src=""ligamentotaxis.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
With&nbsp;<b>Burst</b>&nbsp;Fractures, What are the <b>Goals</b> of <b>Posterior Distraction Instrumentation</b>?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Posterior Instrumentation</u> should be Under <u>Distraction and Lordosis</u> to Restore <u>Vertebral Body Height</u>&nbsp;and Achieve <u>Indirect Decompression</u>}}	"<img src=""ligamentotaxis.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"
<div><div>What are <b>3 Complications </b>of <b>Posterior Decompression</b> in <b>Burst </b>fractures?<br><br><b>{{c1::Dural}} Tear</b><br><b>{{c2::Iatrogenic Cord Injury}}</b> d/t <b>Excessive Thecal Retraction</b> ABOVE the <b>Conus Medullaris</b><br><b>{{c3::Iatrogenic Instability}}</b> d/t <b>Laminectomy</b> in the setting of <b>Disrupted PLC</b></div></div>									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2022/thoracolumbar-burst-fractures"">Orthobullets: Thoracolumbar Burst Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::Thoracic_Lumbar::Thoracolumbar_BurstFx"

"<div><div><div><div><div>What is the <b>Potential Benefit</b> of <b>M</b><span style=""font-weight: 700;"">onosialotetrahexosylganglioside (GM-1)</span>&nbsp;as part of <b>Early</b>&nbsp;<b>Management</b>&nbsp;of a&nbsp;<b>Spinal Cord Injury</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Some Evidence of Faster Recovery}}</div></div></div></div></div>"	Large Multicenter RCT did NOT Show Long-Term Benefit								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2006/spinal-cord-injuries"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Injuries</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCord_Injuries::Cord_Injuries"
What are <b>3 Criteria</b> for <b>Acute Closed Reduction</b> with <b>Axial Traction</b> of a <b>C-Spine</b> Injury?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Alert and Oriented</u> Patient with <u>Neurologic Deficits</u> and <u>Compression</u> due to <u>Fracture/Dislocation</u>}}	Bilateral Facet Dislocation with SCI in Alert and Oriented patient is Most Common reason to Perform acute reduction with axial traction								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2006/spinal-cord-injuries"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Injuries</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCord_Injuries::Cord_Injuries"
What is the Most <b>Common Reason</b>&nbsp;for <b>Acute Closed Reduction</b> with <b>Axial Traction</b> of a <b>C-Spine</b> Injury?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Bilateral Facet Dislocation</u> with SCI in Alert and Oriented patient}}	Bilateral Facet Dislocation with SCI in Alert and Oriented patient is Most Common reason to Perform acute reduction with axial traction<br><br><u>Alert and Oriented</u>&nbsp;Patient with&nbsp;<u>Neurologic Deficits</u>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>Compression</u>&nbsp;due to&nbsp;<u>Fracture/Dislocation</u>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2006/spinal-cord-injuries"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Injuries</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCord_Injuries::Cord_Injuries"
What are <b>3&nbsp;Reasons</b>&nbsp;to <b>ABORT</b>&nbsp;<b>Acute Closed Reduction</b> with <b>Axial Traction</b> of a <b>C-Spine</b> Injury?<br><br>{{c1::Overdistraction}}<br>{{c1::Worsening Neurologic Exam }}<br>{{c1::Failure to Obtain Reduction}}	Bilateral Facet Dislocation with SCI in Alert and Oriented patient is Most Common reason to Perform acute reduction with axial traction<br><br><u>Alert and Oriented</u>&nbsp;Patient with&nbsp;<u>Neurologic Deficits</u>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<u>Compression</u>&nbsp;due to&nbsp;<u>Fracture/Dislocation</u>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2006/spinal-cord-injuries"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Injuries</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCord_Injuries::Cord_Injuries"
Is <b>Hypothermia</b> a <b>Currently Recommended</b> Treatment for&nbsp;<b>Acute Spinal Cord injuries</b>?<br><br>{{c1::NO -&nbsp;due to Increased Complications}}	Systemic and Local<br>Evidence is Weak and Limited<br><br>Complications:<br><b>Coagulopathy <br>Sepsis <br>Pneumonia <br>Rebound Hypertension <br>Arrhythmias</b>								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/spine/2006/spinal-cord-injuries"">Orthobullets: Spinal Cord Injuries</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Spine::Trauma::SpinalCord_Injuries::Cord_Injuries"

What is the&nbsp;<b>POSITION</b>&nbsp;of the Patient when using&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the <b>Femoral Shaft?<br></b><br>{{c1::Supine - Fracture Table or with Sandbag Below Buttock to Internally Rotate Operative leg}}<br><br>OR<br><br>{{c1::Lateral Decubitus - Best for Shaft of Femur}}	"<div>

<div>For most Extracapsular Hip
fractures, INTERNAL Rotation helps Fracture Reduction. <br>Having the Femoral Neck Parallel to the Floor is Helpful in Positioning the Femoral Neck Guidewire Correctly. <br>Always ensure that you can get Adequate Anteroposterior and Lateral
images of the Femoral Head and Neck before Prepping and Draping.&nbsp;</div>

What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Approach</b>&nbsp;to the <b>Femoral Shaft?<br></b><br><div>1.&nbsp;<b>Carefully Incise</b> the <b>Fascial Covering</b> of the {{c1::Vastus Lateralis}}<br>2. <b>Split</b> the <b>{{c2::Vastus Lateralis}}</b> OR <b>Lift </b>it off the <b>{{c2::Intermuscular Septum}}</b><br>3. Continue <b>Splitting Bluntly</b>, taking care to Watch for <b>{{c3::Perforators}}; {{c3::Coagulate}} </b>as Necessary<br>4. <b>Avoid Sharply cutting </b>down to Bone, As this will {{c4::<b>Cut Numerous Vessels</b> and cause them to <b>Retract</b> Into Muscle}}<br>5. To <b>Increase Exposure</b>, Helpful to place <b>{{c5::Hohman Retractors}}</b>&nbsp;over <b>{{c5::Anterior}}&nbsp;</b>and <b>{{c5::Posterior}}</b>&nbsp;Aspects of <b>Femur</b></div>	"<b>Perforating</b> Branches of <b>Profunda Femoris</b> at Risk - Should be <b>Coagulated</b> to Avoid <b>Hematoma</b> &amp; Significant <b>Hemorrhage</b><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.33.31 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.33.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.33.59 PM.png"">"			"<img src=""0.1.jpg""><br><img src=""1.1.jpg""><br><img src=""3.1.jpg""><br><img src=""4.1.jpg""><br><img src=""5.1.jpg""><br><img src=""6.1.jpg""><br><img src=""7.1.jpg"">"					"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12024/femur-lateral-approach"">Orthobullets: Lateral Approach to the Femur</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/femoral-shaft/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Femoral Shaft</a>"	"<iframe width=""560"" height=""315"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/64qdX1Qyl7o"" title=""YouTube video player"" frameborder=""0"" allow=""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe>"	"#Ortho::Approaches::Femur::Lateral"

"What is the&nbsp;<b>POSITION</b>&nbsp;of the Patient when using&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Swashbuckler</b> Approach to the <b>Distal Femur</b>?<br><br><div>

<div>{{c1::<u>Supine</u> with a <u>Bump under the Thigh</u> so Knee rests in 10<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;Flexion}}<br></div>
</div>

<div>This will <b>Relax </b>the <b>Pull</b> of the <b>Gastroc</b> Muscles on the <b>Distal Fragment</b> of the <b>Fracture<br><br></b></div>

"What are the&nbsp;<b>Landmarks</b>&nbsp;used during the&nbsp;<b>Swashbuckler</b> Approach to the <b>Distal Femur</b>?<br><br><div>

<div>{{c1::Lateral Joint Line of the Knee<br>Lateral Margin of the Patella<br>Anterior Surface of the Lateral Femoral Condyle<br>Femoral Shaft}}<br></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 2.04.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.57.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.50 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.46 PM.png"">"					"#Ortho::Approaches::Femur::Swashbuckler"
"Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision</b>&nbsp;made<b>&nbsp;</b>when using the&nbsp;<b>Swashbuckler</b> Approach to the <b>Distal Femur</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">20-cm Longitudinal Incision Centered on and just Lateral to the Patella.</span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><br>Proximally, Angle the Incision Slightly LATERALLY.&nbsp;</span>}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.57.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.50 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.46 PM.png"">"					"#Ortho::Approaches::Femur::Swashbuckler"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Internervous Plane&nbsp;</b>for the&nbsp;<b>Swashbuckler</b> Approach to the <b>Distal Femur</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Between TFL (Superior Gluteal n.) and Vastus Lateralis (Femoral n.)}}<br></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/chp%3A10.1007%2F978-3-319-28806-2_4/MediaObjects/335264_1_En_4_Fig2_HTML.gif"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.57.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.50 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.46 PM.png"">"					"#Ortho::Approaches::Femur::Swashbuckler"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Swashbuckler</b> Approach to the <b>Distal Femur</b>?<br><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">1. <b>Divide</b> the <b>Subcutaneous fat </b>in line with&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Skin Incision}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;to <b>Reveal</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Fascia}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;Overlying&nbsp;</span>{{c1::Vastus Lateralis}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><br>2. <b>Split</b> this <b>Fascia</b> in line with the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Skin Incision}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">, and <b>Lift </b>it off the <b>Underlying</b>&nbsp;</span>{{c2::<b>Vastus Lateralis</b> Muscle}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">. <br>3. <b>Continue</b> the <b>Dissection</b>&nbsp;</span><b>{{c3::Laterally}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;until the <b>Fascia</b> over the <b>Vastus Lateralis</b> becomes <b>Confluent</b> with the <b>IT Band</b>. <br>4. <b>Divide</b> the <b>F</b></span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>ascia</b> between the</span> {{c4::<b>Lateral</b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;Edge</b> of the&nbsp;</span>{{c4::<b>Vastus Lateralis</b>}}&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">and the&nbsp;</span>{{c4::<b>Iliotibial Tract</b>}}</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.32 PM.png"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.57.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.50 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.46 PM.png"">"					"#Ortho::Approaches::Femur::Swashbuckler"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Swashbuckler</b> Approach to the <b>Distal Femur</b>?<br><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">1. <b>Distally</b>, Enter the <b>Knee joint </b>by Dividing the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Lateral Patellar Retinaculum}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Knee Joint Capsule}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><br>2. <b>Elevate</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Vastus Lateralis}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;muscle</b> from the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Lateral Intermuscular Septum}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;until the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Shaft}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;</b>of the <b>Femur </b>is Reached<br>3. <b>Identify</b> and <b>Ligate</b> the&nbsp;</span>{{c3::<b>Lateral Superior Geniculate</b> Artery &amp; Vein}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">, which are <b>Adherent </b>to the <b>Periosteum</b><br>4. Fully&nbsp;</span><b>{{c4::Extend}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;the <b>Knee</b>, <b>Retract </b>the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c4::Vastus Lateralis}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;Medially</b>, and<b> Evert</b> the <b>Patella&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c4::Medially}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><br></span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>"	"<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">The <b>Distal Femur</b> and the <b>Anterior Distal Femoral Joint Surface</b>&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">are Exposed&nbsp;</span><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.46 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.50 PM.png"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.57.37 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.58.50 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.32 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-18 at 1.56.46 PM.png"">"					"#Ortho::Approaches::Femur::Swashbuckler"
What are the&nbsp;<b>Indications</b>&nbsp;to use the&nbsp;<b>Anterior </b>Approach to the <b>Pubic Symphysis</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Pubic <u>Symphysis Disruption/Diastasis</u>}}<br>{{c1::Fractures of the <u>Anterior Pelvic Ring</u> including <u>Superior Pubic Rami</u>}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.54.08 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.28 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.35 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/pelvic-ring/approach/approach-to-the-pubic-symphysis"">AO: Approach to Symphysis</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::Anterior_Symphysis"

Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision</b>&nbsp;made<b>&nbsp;</b>when using the&nbsp;<b>Anterior </b>Approach to the <b>Pubic Symphysis</b>?<br><br>{{c1::5-10 cm Horizontal Incision about 2 Fingerbreadths Proximal to the Pubic Tubercle<br>Should be in Line with the Horizontal Skin Crease}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.50 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.28 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.35 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/pelvic-ring/approach/approach-to-the-pubic-symphysis"">AO: Approach to Symphysis</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::Anterior_Symphysis"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Anterior </b>Approach to the <b>Pubic Symphysis</b>?<br><br>1. <b>Subcutaneous Tissue</b> is <b>Incised</b> in <b>Line</b> with the <b>Incision</b>, <b>Uncovering</b> the <b>{{c1::Rectus Sheath}}
</b><br>2. <b>Ligation</b> of the {{c2::<b>Superficial Epigastric</b> artery and vein}} as they Run Across the field from <b>{{c2::Inferior}}</b> to <b>{{c2::Superior}} </b>may be <b>Necessary</b>, but will likely be <b>Avoided</b> for <b>Incisions</b> <b>Less</b> than <b>{{c2::12 cm}}</b>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.28 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.35 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/pelvic-ring/approach/approach-to-the-pubic-symphysis"">AO: Approach to Symphysis</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::Anterior_Symphysis"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Anterior </b>Approach to the <b>Pubic Symphysis</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><b>Rectus Abdominis Insertion</b> is Fairly <b>Broad </b>and can be <b>Elevated</b> off the <b>Superior</b> and <b>Posterior Aspects</b> of the Pubic <b>Symphysis</b> to just <b>Past</b> the <b>Pubic Tubercle</b> WITHOUT the need to <b>Repair</b>
back to Bone; One or Both <b>sides </b>of the <b>Insertion </b>may be <b>Traumatically Avulsed</b> (Typically it is
the <b>More Seriously Injured side</b> of the <b>Hemipelvis</b>)
<br><br></div>
<div>1. <b>Retract</b> the <b>Rectus Abdominis</b> <b>{{c1::Laterally}}</b> and <b>{{c1::Superiorly}}</b><br>2. A <b>Layer </b>of <b>Extraperitoneal Fat</b> may be present <b>Between</b> the <b>{{c2::Rectus Abdominis}}</b> and the <b>{{c2::Bladder}}
</b><br>3. <b>Dissection</b> of the <b>Posterior</b> Aspect of the <b>Superior Rami</b> and <b>Pubic Symphysis </b>can be Accomplished <b>{{c3::Digitally}} </b>(<b>Preperitoneal Space</b> of <b>{{c3::Retzius}}</b>)</div><div>4. Use a <b>Medium </b>or <b>Wide Malleable Retractor</b> Along the <b>Posterior Aspect </b>of the <b>{{c4::Symphysis}}</b> to <b>Protect </b>the <b>{{c4::Bladder}}</b></div></div></div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.28 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.35 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/pelvic-ring/approach/approach-to-the-pubic-symphysis"">AO: Approach to Symphysis</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::Anterior_Symphysis"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Closure</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;After</b>&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Anterior </b>Approach to the <b>Pubic Symphysis</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>1. Use of a <b>Closed Suction Drain</b> in the {{c1::<b>Space</b> of <b>Retzius</b>}} is Advised to <b>Decrease</b> the <b>Risk</b> of a <b>Postoperative {{c1::Hematoma}}</b> and <b>{{c1::Infection}}
</b></div>
<div>2. <b>Repair </b>of the <b>Rectus Abdominis Superficial</b> and<b> Deep Fascia</b> can be Performed by {{c2::<b>Incorporating Both</b> as <b>One</b> <b>Layer</b>}}, but <b>Avoid Incorporating</b> Significant <b>{{c2::Muscle}} </b>into the <b>Repair
</b></div>
<div>3. <b>Subcutaneous</b> and <b>Skin Closure </b>is accomplished in the <b>Normal Fashion&nbsp;</b></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.28 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.49.48 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.02 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.16 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.35 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.50.50 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-19 at 12.51.37 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/pelvic-ring/approach/approach-to-the-pubic-symphysis"">AO: Approach to Symphysis</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::Anterior_Symphysis"
"<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Increased Incidence </span>of <b>Pediatric Femoral Shaft Fractures&nbsp;</b>is seen in what <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Age Group(s)</span>?<br><br style="""">{{c1::Toddlers (2-4) and Adolescents}}"									"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4019/femoral-shaft-fractures--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Pediatric Femoral Shaft Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Pelvis_Femur::FemoralShaft"

"How many <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Terminal Branches </span>does the <span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Superficial Peroneal </span>nerve have?<br><br>{{c1::2 - Innervate Dorsum of Foot}}"	"<img src=""sddefault-5bff668e73b787bbde21791035e7daf43210f63a.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1047/ankle-fractures"">Orthobullets - Ankle Fxs</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::LowerExtremity::Ankle::Ankle_Fx"
What <b>Finding</b> on <b>E</b><b>xamination under anesthesia&nbsp;</b>(EUA) for&nbsp;<b>Posterior Wall&nbsp;</b>Acetabulum Suggests <b>Instability?<br><br></b>{{c1::Opening&nbsp;of the Medial Clear Space&nbsp;}}<b><br></b>	"<b>Hip</b>&nbsp;Positioned in<b> Flexion, ADduction</b> and <b>Axial Load</b><br>Obtain <b>Obturator Oblique</b>&nbsp;view<br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""acetabular-fractures-22-638.jpg"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2022-07-25 at 3.11.33 PM.png"">"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1034/acetabular-fractures"">Orthobullets - Acetabulum Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::Pelvic::Acetabulum::TabFxs"
What is the&nbsp;<b>Position</b>&nbsp;of the Patient during&nbsp;the <b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::Supine - Bump under Ipsilateral Hip (Internally Rotates), Commercially available Holders (Keeps knee at 90)}}						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 3.15.13 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 3.15.38 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 3.16.27 AM.png""><br>"		"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
What are the&nbsp;<b>Indications</b>&nbsp;to use the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::Total Knee Arthroplasty<br>Synovectomy<br>Open Medial Menisectomy<br>Open Removal of Loose Bodies <br>Open Ligamentous Reconstructions <br>Patellectomy<br>I&amp;D of knee<br>ORIF of Distal Femoral fractures (Medial plate)}}						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
What is a <b>Relative</b>&nbsp;<b>Contraindication</b>&nbsp;to using the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::Previous Lateral Parapatellar Approach}}						"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision</b>&nbsp;made<b>&nbsp;</b>when using the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::Palpate Midline of Patella to Tibial Tubercle<br>5 cm / 2 Fingerbreadths Above Patella to Tibial Tubercle}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>1. <b>Subcutaneous Tissue</b> is <b>Dissected</b>&nbsp;(<b>Medial Flap</b>) to <b>Expose</b> the <b>{{c1::Quadriceps Tendon}}, {{c1::Patella}}</b>, and <b>{{c1::Patellar Tendon}}</b></div><div>2. A <b>{{c2::Vertical}} Incision</b> is made in the <b>{{c2::Retinaculum}}</b>, leaving a <b>{{c2::5-mm}} strip</b> of <b>Tendon</b> for Later Closure; the Incision is <b>Curved</b> around the <b>{{c2::Patella}} </b>and immediately <b>Adjacent</b> to the <b>{{c2::Patellar Tendon&nbsp;}}</b></div><div>3. The <b>Patella</b> can be <b>{{c3::Everted}}</b>, the <b>Knee {{c3::Flexed}}</b>, and the <b>Joint Exposed</b><br>4. <b>Additional Exposure</b> of the <b>Proximal Tibia</b> can be accomplished by <b>{{c4::Fat Pad}} Excision</b> and <b>Subperiosteal Dissection</b> of the <b>Proximal Medial Tibia</b></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
"What is the <b>Difference</b>&nbsp;with the <b>Midvastus Variation</b> of the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::<u>Proximal</u> Portion of the Arthrotomy Extends into the <u>Muscle Belly of the Vastus Medialis</u>}} <br><br><b>Patella </b>can be <b>Difficult</b> to <b>{{c1::Evert}}</b> and is <b>Subluxated {{c1::Laterally}}</b> instead</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
"What is the <b>Difference</b>&nbsp;with the <b>Subvastus Variation</b> of the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Muscle Belly of the <u>Vastus Medialis</u>&nbsp;is Lifted Off the <u>Medial Intermuscular Septum</u>}} <br><br><b>Patella </b>can be <b>Difficult</b> to <b>{{c1::Evert}}</b> and is <b>Subluxated {{c1::Laterally}}</b> instead</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"Benefits include:<br>Preserving the <u>Blood Supply</u> to the <u>Patella</u><br>Preserving the <u>Anatomy</u> of the <u>Quadriceps Tendon</u> (maintains <u>Stability of knee</u>)<br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
When is the <b>Superior Lateral Genicular artery</b> at<b> Risk</b> during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Medial Parapatellar</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::During Lateral Retinacular Release}}	"May be <b>Last Remaining Blood Supply</b> after <b>Medial Parapatellar approach</b> and <b>Fat Pad Excision</b><br><br><img src=""aps-2021-01123f1.gif"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
The <b>Saphenous nerve</b> becomes <b>Subcutaneous</b> on<b> {{c1::Medial}}</b>&nbsp;<b>Aspect</b> of the <b>Knee</b> after <b>Piercing</b> the <b>Fascia</b> between the <b>{{c1::Sartorius}}</b> and <b>{{c1::Gracilis}}</b>, where it Gives off the <b>{{c2::Infrapatellar}} branch</b> that provides <b>Sensation</b> to the <b>{{c2::Anteromedial}} Aspect</b> of the <b>Knee</b>	Injury can lead to <b>Postoperative Neuroma</b> -&nbsp;if cut during surgery, <b>resect</b> and <b>bury end</b> to <b>decrease</b> chance of <b>painful neuroma</b>					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.25.44 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.07 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.23 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.26.54 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.19 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 1.27.36 AM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12028/knee-medial-parapatellar-approach"">Orthobullets: Knee Medial Parapatellar Approach</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/medial-parapatellar-approach"">AO: Medial Parapatellar Approach to the Distal Femur</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::MedialParapatellar"
What are the&nbsp;<b>Indications</b>&nbsp;to use the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatellar</b>&nbsp;Approach?<br><br>{{c1::ORIF Distal Femur (Articular Block, Insertion of LISS Plates)<br>TKA (Fixed Valgus Deformity)<br>ORIF Lateral Tibial Plateau}}									"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
What are the <b>Neurovascular Structures</b>&nbsp;at RISK with&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatellar</b>&nbsp;Approach?<br><br>{{c1::Superior Lateral Geniculate artery}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 3.46.15 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
What is the&nbsp;<b>POSITION</b>&nbsp;of the Patient when using&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatellar</b>&nbsp;Approach?<br><br>{{c1::Supine with a Towel under the Knee to produce 20-30° of Flexion}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 3.47.36 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision</b>&nbsp;made<b>&nbsp;</b>when using the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatellar</b>&nbsp;Approach?<br><br>{{c1::15-18 cm Incision just Lateral to the Midline<u> between Patella and Tibial Tubercle</u>}}	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-26 at 3.47.36 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
What is the&nbsp;<b>Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatellar</b>&nbsp;Approach?<br><br><div>1. Deep Dissection <b>Exposes</b> the <b>Lateral Aspect</b> of the <b>{{c1::Patella}}</b></div><div>2. The <b>{{c2::Extensor Retinaculum}}</b> is <b>Preserved Over</b> the <b>Front </b>of the <b>Patella</b></div><div>3. The <b>Skin Incision</b> is <b>Long </b>enough to <b>Define</b> Both the <b>Medial</b> and <b>Lateral Aspects</b> of the <b>{{c3::Quadriceps tendon}}</b></div><div>4. Make a <b>Full Thickness, Longitudinal Incision</b> through the <b>{{c4::Lateral Parapatellar Retinaculum}}</b> and <b>{{c4::Quadriceps Tendon}}</b>. It begins<b> Slightly Lateral</b> to <b>Midline</b> (<b>40% lateral; 60% medial</b>) and Curves to the <b>Lateral </b>Aspect of the <b>Patella</b>. It should leave a(n) <b>{{c4::8–10}} mm</b>&nbsp;Cuff of <b>Parapatellar Retinaculum</b> on the <b>Lateral Aspect</b> of the <b>Patella</b>.</div><div>5. The <b>Split</b> in the <b>Quadriceps Tendon </b>Extends Approximately {{c5::10 cm}} <b>Above</b> the <b>Superior Pole</b> of the <b>Patella</b>. If an <b>Adequate Release</b> is <b>NOT Performed</b>, the surgeon <b>Risks</b> <b>{{c5::Patellar Tendon Avulsion}} </b>during <b>Patellar Dislocation</b></div>	"<img src=""33_a021_i100.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
How can teh&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatellar</b>&nbsp;Approach be <b>Extended Distally</b>?<br><br><div>Carry the <b>Division</b> down <b>Distally</b> to the <b>Lateral Aspect</b> of the <b>{{c1::Patellar Tendon}}</b> and then, by <b>{{c2::Flexion}}</b> of the <b>Knee </b>and <b>{{c2::Medial}} Traction</b> on the <b>{{c2::Extensor Mechanism}}</b>, the Patella is <b>Dislocated {{c1::Medially}}</b>.<br></div>	"<img src=""33_a021_i120.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Closure</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;After</b>&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Lateral Parapatella</b>&nbsp;Approach?<br><br><div><b>Close</b> the {{c1::Quadriceps Tendon}} and <b>Cuff</b> of <b>Tissue</b> along the <b>Lateral Aspect</b> of the <b>Patella</b> with <b>{{c1::Interrupted #2}}</b>, or <b>Larger</b>, Sutures. Close the skin and subcutaneous tissue in a routine manner.<br></div>"	"<img src=""33_a021_i160.png"">"								"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::LateralParapatellar"
"What are the&nbsp;<b>Indications</b>&nbsp;to use the&nbsp;<b>Posterior </b>Approach to the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::<div><div><div>Repair of the <u>Neurovascular Structures Behind the Knee</u> (Trauma)</div>
<div>Repair of Avulsion Fractures of PCL Attachment to the Tibia and Midline Posterior Tibial Plateau fractures
</div>
</div>

<div>
<div>Recession of Gastrocnemius Heads (Contracture)<br><div>
<div>

<div>Lengthening of Hamstring tendons<br>
Excision of Baker Cyst and other Popliteal cysts
<br>Access to the Posterior Capsule of the knee&nbsp;</div></div></div></div></div></div></div>}}<br></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div>

"What are the&nbsp;<b>Landmarks</b>&nbsp;when using&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Posterior </b>Approach to the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Gastrocs<br>Semimembranosus and Semitendinosus}}<br></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.45.38 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.34 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.34.18 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.35.41 PM.png""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.11 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.59 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.32 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.37.49 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.42 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.39.14 PM.png"">"		"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::PosteriorKnee"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Position</b>&nbsp;of the Patient during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Posterior </b>Approach to the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Prone}}<br></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div>
</div>

</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.46.18 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.34 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.34.18 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.35.41 PM.png""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.11 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.59 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.32 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.37.49 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.42 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.39.14 PM.png"">"		"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::PosteriorKnee"
"Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision</b>&nbsp;made<b>&nbsp;</b>when using the&nbsp;<b>Posterior </b>Approach to the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Lazy S - Starts Laterally over Biceps Femoris, Obliquely across Popliteal Fossa, and Downward over Medial Gastroc<br>~8 cm Proximally and Distally}}<br></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.47.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-29 at 12.18.24 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.46.53 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.34 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.34.18 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.35.41 PM.png""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.11 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.59 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.32 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.37.49 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.42 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.39.14 PM.png"">"		"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::PosteriorKnee"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Posterior </b>Approach to the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">1. Reflect the <b>Skin Flaps</b> with the <b>Underlying Subcutaneous Fat</b>. <br>2. Running on the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Lateral}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;Side of the <b>Popliteal Vein</b> is the <b>Medial Sural Cutaneous n</b>. The&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Small Saphenous}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;Vein</b> can be used as a <b>Guide</b> to the <b>nerve</b>, and the <b>Nerve</b> can be used as a <b>Guide</b> to <b>Dissecting</b> the <b>Popliteal Fossa</b>.<br>3.&nbsp;</span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">Incise the <b>Fascia</b> of the <b>Fossa</b> just <b>Medial</b> to the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Small Saphenous vein}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">. <b>Trace</b> the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::Medial Sural Cutaneous}}</b>&nbsp;<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">n. <b>Proximally</b> back to the<b> Tibial n</b>. <b>Dissect </b>up to the <b>Apex </b>of the <b>Fossa</b>, following the <b>Tibial
nerve</b>.<br></span></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-29 at 12.26.13 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-29 at 12.26.38 AM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.34 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.34.18 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.35.41 PM.png""><br><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.32.20 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.11 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.33.59 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.09 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.36.32 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.37.49 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.05 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.38.42 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-04-28 at 11.39.14 PM.png"">"		"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/distal-femur/approach/lateral-parapatellar-approach-to-the-distal-femur"">AO: Lateral Parapatellar Approach</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Knee_LowerLeg::PosteriorKnee"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Posterior </b>Approach to the <b>Knee</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">1. A</span><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">t the <b>Apex</b> of the <b>Popliteal Fossa</b>, <b>Dissect</b>
out the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Common Peroneal}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;nerve</b> in a&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Proximal}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;</b>to&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Distal}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;Direction</b> as it Runs along the <b>Posterior Border</b> of the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c1::Biceps Femoris}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;muscle</span></b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><br></span></div><div>
<div>
<div>

<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">2. Turn to the <b>Popliteal </b>artery &amp; vein, which lie&nbsp;</span><b>{{c2::DEEP}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;and<b>&nbsp;</b></span><b>{{c2::Medial}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;to the <b>Tibial n</b>. The <b>Artery</b> has</span> <b>{{c2::5}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);""><b>&nbsp;Branches </b>around the <b>Knee:</b></span> {{c2::<b>2 Superior, 2 Inferior, 1 Middle Genicular</b>}}<span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">. <b>1+</b> of these branches
may have to be <b>Ligated</b> if the <b>Artery</b> needs to be <b>Mobilized</b>.
</span></div>
<div><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">3. The <b>Popliteal vein</b> lies&nbsp;</span><b>{{c3::Medial}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;to the <b>Artery</b> as it <b>Enters</b> the<b> Popliteal Fossa</b> from <b>Below.</b> Then it Curves, lying directly&nbsp;</span><b>{{c3::Posterior}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;to the <b>Artery</b> while in the <b>Fossa</b>. <b>Above</b> the <b>Knee Joint,</b> the <b>Popliteal vei</b>n moves to the&nbsp;</span><b>{{c3::Posterolateral}}</b><span style=""color: rgb(10, 9, 5);"">&nbsp;side of
the <b>Artery</b>. <br>- Be <b>Very Careful</b> in <b>Mobilizing</b> this structure. <b>Intimal Damage</b> may cause <b>Thrombosis</b>.&nbsp;</span></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>

What is the <b>AO/OTA </b>Classification of <b>Humeral Shaft</b> Fractures?<br><br><b>Bone Number</b>: {{c1::1}}<br>Fracture <b>Location</b>: {{c1::2}}<br><b>Pattern</b> - <b>A</b>: {{c1::Simple}}<br><b>B</b>: {{c1::Wedge}}<br><b>C</b>: {{c1::Complex}}	"<img src=""figure-1-ota-ao-classification-for-humeral-shaft-fractures1-3mq6imci.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/trauma/1016/humeral-shaft-fractures"">Orthobullets: Humeral Shaft Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Trauma::UpperExtremity::Humerus::Shaft"
<div>Following a&nbsp;<b>Radial nerve injury</b>, what is the&nbsp;<b>FIRST muscle</b>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<b>regain</b>&nbsp;function?</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Brachioradialis}}</div>	"<div><b>Woody says it’s: Triceps, Anconeus, BR, ECRL, ECRB, EDC, ECU, EIP</b></div><b><div><b><br></b></div>Reinnervation Sequence</b>&nbsp;depends on&nbsp;<b>nerve Length</b>. Based on the&nbsp;<b>Shortest Mean nerve&nbsp;</b>and&nbsp;<b>Branch Length</b>, the&nbsp;<b>Order</b>&nbsp;of Reinnervation is&nbsp;<b>BR, ECRL, Supinator, ECRB, EDC, ECU, EDM, APL, EPL, EPB, EIP.<br></b><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-01 at 4.11.39 PM.png"">"										"#Ortho::PP::Arm::GeneralAnatomy"

What are the Major<b> Deforming Forces </b>on the <b>PROXIMAL</b>&nbsp;Fragments of&nbsp;<b>Pediatric</b>&nbsp;<b>Both Bone Forearm</b> Fractures?<br><br><b>{{c1::Biceps}}</b> and <b>{{c1::Supinator}} {{c2::Flex}}</b>&nbsp;and <b>{{c2::Supinate}}</b> the Proximal Fragment 	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-15 at 11.31.17 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4126/both-bone-forearm-fracture--pediatric?section=cards"">Orthobullets: Both Bone Forearm Fracture - Peds</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/pediatric-trauma/forearm-shaft/22-d"">AO: Pediatric Both Bone Forearm Fracture Fixation Techniques</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Forearm::BBFF"
With&nbsp;<b>Pediatric</b>&nbsp;<b>Both Bone Forearm</b> Fractures, The <b>Periosteum</b> is generally <b>intact</b> on the {{c3::Concave::Concave/Convex?}} <b>Side</b> of the fracture	"<b>Interosseous Membrane </b>is <b>Taut </b>in <b>Neutral </b>to Slight <b>Supination</b><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-16 at 9.28.43 AM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-15 at 11.31.17 AM.png"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4126/both-bone-forearm-fracture--pediatric?section=cards"">Orthobullets: Both Bone Forearm Fracture - Peds</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/pediatric-trauma/forearm-shaft/22-d"">AO: Pediatric Both Bone Forearm Fracture Fixation Techniques</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Forearm::BBFF"
What are the <b>Borders</b> of the <b>Iliopectineal Line</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::<u>Iliac Wing Medial</u> Margin, along the <u>Superior</u> Margin of the <u>Superior Pubic Ramus</u>, to the <u>Pubic Symphysis</u>&nbsp;}}</div>	"Represents the <b>Anterior Column<br><br></b><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 3.38.51 PM.png""><b><br></b>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
What are the <b>Borders</b> of the <b>Ilioischial Line</b>?<br><br><div>{{c1::Starts at the&nbsp;<u>Iliac Wing Medial</u> Margin and extends to the <u>Ischial Tuberosity</u> along the <u>Medial Margin</u> of the <u>Ischial</u> Bone}}</div>	"Represents the <b>Posterior Column<br><br></b><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 3.38.51 PM.png""><b><br></b>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"What is&nbsp;the <b>Arcuate Line</b>&nbsp;of the Sacrum?<br><br><div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Defines the <u>Inferior Surface
of the Costal Element</u> that forms the <u>Anterior Sacral Canal Roof</u>
and <u>Neural Groove</u>}}</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Should be <b>Smooth</b> and <b>Symmetrical</b>; <b>Discontinuity</b> may be caused by <b>Sacral fractures&nbsp;</b></div>
</div>
</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 3.38.51 PM.png""><br><b><br></b><br>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"<div><div><div><div><div><div>What is the <b>Name</b> of the <b>Sign</b> when <b>Klein's Line</b> does <b>NOT Cross </b>the <b>Femoral Head Epiphysis (SCFE)</b>?<br><br><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>{{c1::Trethowan’s sign}}</div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>The line of Klein runs along the Superior Margin of the Femoral Neck and Traverses the Lateral portion of the Femoral Head Epiphysis&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 3.38.51 PM.png""><br>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"<div><div><div><div><div><div>What can be seen on<b> X-Ray</b> with the <b>Acetabular Roof</b> in <b>Achondroplasia</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Flattening of the Acetabular Roof}}<div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div></div>"	"<div>
<div>
<div><div>
<div>
<div>
<div>Radiographic features include <b>horizontal acetabular
roof</b>, <b>small sciatic notches</b>, <b>small square-shaped iliac wings</b>
(tombstone), <b>champagne glass-type pelvic inlet</b>, small<b> trident
pelvis</b> and <b>metaphyseal flaring</b>&nbsp;</div>
</div>
</div></div><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 4.06.08 PM.png""><br></div></div></div>"										"#Ortho::PP::TheBasics::X-rays::Pelvis"
"<div><div><div><b>Torode </b>Classification of <b>Pediatric Pelvic</b> Fractures<br><br>Type I: {{c1::<u>Avulsion</u> Fractures}}<br>Type II: {{c1::Fractures of the <u>Iliac Wing</u>}}</div><div>Type III: {{c1::Fractures of the <u>Ring</u> with <u>NO Segmental</u> Instability}}</div><div>Type IV: {{c1::Fractures of the <u>Ring</u> WITH <u>Segmental</u> Instability}}</div><div><div><div><div>

"<div><div><div><b>Bucholz&nbsp;</b>Classification of <b>Pediatric Acetabulum</b>&nbsp;Fractures<br><br>{{c1::Shearing - SH I or II}}<br>{{c1::Crushing/Impaction - SH V}}<br></div><div><div><div><div>
</div>
</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
"	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 10.16.51 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-17 at 10.17.15 PM.png"">"	"<div>The <b>Bucholz</b> classification divides injury patterns into two groups.&nbsp;</div>
<ul>
<li>The first group involves a <b>shearing injury</b> causing a <b>Salter-Harris Type 1 </b>or <b>Type 2 injury</b> to the<b> triradiate</b> cartilage.&nbsp;</li>
<li>The second group is a <b>crush injury</b> or <b>Salter-Harris Type 5</b> injury to the <b>triradiate</b> cartilage.</li>
<li>The Bucholz classification has been modified to also include a <b>Type 4</b> injury involving the <b>metaphysis </b>on either side of the <b>triradiate cartilage</b> and a&nbsp;</li>
<li><b>Type 6</b> injury where a <b>hematoma</b> forms <b>adjacent</b> to the <b>triradiate </b>cartilage resulting in <b>bony bridge formation</b>.&nbsp;</li></ul>"							"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/3000/pelvis-fractures--pediatric"">Orthobullets: Pediatric Pelvis Fractures</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Pelvis_Femur::Pelvis"
What does the <b>Modified Stoppa</b> Approach provide <b>Access</b> to?<br><br>{{c1::Pubic Body<br>Superior Pubic Ramus<br>Pubic Root<br>Ilium Above and Below the Pectineal line<br>Quadrilateral Plate<br>Medial Aspect of the Posterior Column<br>Sciatic Buttress<br>Anterior SI Joint<br>Upper Ilium and Iliac Crest}}	"<a href=""https://www.aaos.org/videos/video-detail-page/25428__Videos"">OVT: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.57.26 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.51.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.19 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.54.07 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/acetabulum/approach/modified-stoppa-approach"">AO: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12056/stoppa-approach-to-acetabulum"">Orthobullets: Stoppa Approach to the Acetabulum</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::ModifiedStoppa"
What is the&nbsp;<b>POSITION</b>&nbsp;of the Patient when using&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Modified Stoppa</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::<u>Supine</u> on a RadioLUCENT Table, <u>Foley Catheter</u> in Place, <u>Ipsilateral Limb draped</u> into field with <u>Hip and Knee FLEXED</u> to relax the Iliopsoas/Femoral NV Bundle}}	"<a href=""https://www.aaos.org/videos/video-detail-page/25428__Videos"">OVT: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 4.00.06 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.51.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.19 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.54.07 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/acetabulum/approach/modified-stoppa-approach"">AO: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12056/stoppa-approach-to-acetabulum"">Orthobullets: Stoppa Approach to the Acetabulum</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::ModifiedStoppa"
Where is the&nbsp;<b>Incision</b>&nbsp;made<b>&nbsp;</b>when using the&nbsp;<b>Modified Stoppa</b> Approach?<br><br>{{c1::<b><u>Transverse</u></b>}}<b>&nbsp;Incision</b> is made approximately {{c1::<u><b>2 cm</b></u>}}<u><b>&nbsp;Above</b> the&nbsp;</u>{{c1::<u><b>Symphysis</b></u>}}&nbsp;and Carried <u><b>Short</b></u> of each {{c1::<b>External Inguinal Ring</b>}}<br><br><b>Lateral Window</b>: <b>Incision</b> is made along the <b>{{c2::Iliac Crest}}</b>, starting <b>{{c2::~2</b><b>}}&nbsp;</b><b>cm&nbsp;</b><b>Posterior&nbsp;</b>to the<b> {{c2::ASIS}}</b>, following the <b>{{c2::Iliac Crest}} Posteriorly</b>	"<a href=""https://www.aaos.org/videos/video-detail-page/25428__Videos"">OVT: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 4.00.54 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 4.09.27 PM.png"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.51.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.19 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.54.07 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/acetabulum/approach/modified-stoppa-approach"">AO: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12056/stoppa-approach-to-acetabulum"">Orthobullets: Stoppa Approach to the Acetabulum</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::ModifiedStoppa"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Modified Stoppa</b> Approach?<br><br>1. <b>{{c1::Subcutaneous Tissue}}</b> and <b>{{c1::Rectus Fascia}}</b> are <b>Incised Transversely</b><br>2. <b>{{c2::Pyrimidalis}}&nbsp;</b>Muscle is Released and Tagged for Later Repair <br>3. <b>{{c3::Rectus Abdominus}}</b>&nbsp;Fascia is Split along the <b>{{c3::Linea Alba}}</b><br>4. <b>{{c4::Transversalis}}</b>&nbsp;Fascia is <b>Opened Superior</b> to the <b>{{c4::Pubic Symphysis}}</b>&nbsp;-&nbsp;<b>Opens</b> the <b>Potential</b> Space of <b>{{c4::Retzius}}</b><a href=""http://upload.orthobullets.com/topic/12056/images/pfannenstiel%203g.jpg""><br></a><div><br>5. For the <b>Lateral Window</b>, the <b>Insertion</b> of the <b>{{c5::External oblique}}</b> is <b>Released</b>, Permitting <b>Dissection</b> into the <b>{{c5::Internal Iliac Crest Fossa}}</b> (requires <b>Elevation</b> of the <b>{{c5::Iliacus muscle}}</b>)</div>"	"<a href=""https://www.aaos.org/videos/video-detail-page/25428__Videos"">OVT: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><br>1.<br><img src=""pfannenstiel 3e.jpg""><br><br>3.<br><img src=""pfannenstiel 3f.jpg""><br><br>4.<br><img src=""pfannenstiel 3g.jpg"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.51.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.19 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.54.07 PM.png"">"	"<img src=""maxresdefault-3f3761bfb9d1fc4e5694426b27f41faf037e769a.jpg"">"		"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/acetabulum/approach/modified-stoppa-approach"">AO: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12056/stoppa-approach-to-acetabulum"">Orthobullets: Stoppa Approach to the Acetabulum</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::ModifiedStoppa"
"What is the <b>DEEP&nbsp;Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Modified Stoppa</b> Approach?<br><br>1. The <b>Origin</b> of the<b> {{c1::Rectus Abdominus}} muscle</b> is <b>Released</b> off the <b>{{c1::Posterior}} Pubic Rami</b> but Maintained <b>{{c1::Anteriorly}}</b>. A&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Hohmann}}</b>&nbsp;<b>Retractor </b>is used to retract the&nbsp;<b>{{c1::Rectus}}</b>&nbsp;<b>Anteriorly</b>.<br>2. The <b>{{c2::Iliopectineal}}</b> Fascia is <b>Released</b> to enter the <b>True Pelvis</b><br>3. <b>Anastamoses</b> between the <b>External Iliac</b> and <b>Obturator </b>vessels (<b>Corona Mortis</b>) should be <b>identified</b> along the {{c3::<b>Lateral 1/3</b> of the <b>Superior Pubic Ramus</b>}} and <b>Ligated</b><br>4. The<b> {{c4::Iliopsoas}}</b> can now be <b>Subperiosteally Elevated</b>, and a <b>Retractor</b> is used to <b>Retract </b>the <b>{{c4::Iliopsoas}}</b> and <b>{{c4::External Iliac}}</b> vessels. T<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 255);""><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0);"">he entire <b>Pelvic Brim</b> should be <b>Visualized</b> at this time<br></span></span>5. The <b>{{c5::Obturator NV}}</b> Bundle is <b>Exposed</b> and <b>Protected</b> as the&nbsp;<b>{{c5::Quadrilateral Surface}}</b> and&nbsp;<b>{{c5::Posterior Column}}</b> are <b>Dissected</b>"	"<a href=""https://www.aaos.org/videos/video-detail-page/25428__Videos"">OVT: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><br>4.&nbsp;<br><img src=""img_2508.jpg"">"					"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.51.43 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.07 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.52.29 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.19 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.53.45 PM.png""><br><img src=""Screen Shot 2023-05-18 at 3.54.07 PM.png"">"			"<a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/acetabulum/approach/modified-stoppa-approach"">AO: Modified Stoppa Approach</a><br><a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/12056/stoppa-approach-to-acetabulum"">Orthobullets: Stoppa Approach to the Acetabulum</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Pelvis::ModifiedStoppa"

"What is the <b>Patterson&nbsp;Reduction</b>&nbsp;Maneuver for&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Pediatric Radial Head&nbsp;</span>and&nbsp;<span style=""font-weight: 700;"">Neck&nbsp;</span>Fractures?<br><br>{{c1::Hold the Elbow in Extension and apply Distal Traction with the Forearm Supinated and Pull the Forearm into Varus while applying Direct Pressure over the Radial Head}}"	"First Line Maneuver<br><img src=""patterson_maneuver..jpg"">"			"Judet Classification<br><br>Type I:<br><img src=""undisplaced.jpg""><br><br>Type II:<br><img src=""less_than_30_degrees.jpg""><br><br>Type III:<br><img src=""30-60_degrees.jpg""><br><br>Type IVa:<br><img src=""60_to_80_degrees.jpg""><br><br>Type IVb:<br><img src=""over_80_degrees.jpg"">"					"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4011/radial-head-and-neck-fractures--pediatric?section=bullets"">Orthobullets: Radial Head and Neck Fractures - Pediatric</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Elbow::RadialHeadNeck"

With&nbsp;<b>Pediatric</b>&nbsp;<b>Both Bone Forearm</b>&nbsp;Fractures, What are <b>4 Radiographic Methods</b> to assess for <b>Rotational Malalignment</b>?<br><br><b>Bicipital Tuberosity</b> and <b>Radial Styloid</b> should be <b>180</b> degrees apart on the <b>AP view </b><br><b>Ulnar Styloid</b> and <b>Coronoid</b> are <b>180</b> degrees apart on the <b>Lateral view </b><br>{{c1::<u><b>Diameter</b></u> of <b>Proximal</b> and <b>Distal Fragments</b> should Match}}<br>{{c1::<u><b>Thickness</b> of <b>Cortices</b></u> should Match on <b>Proximal</b> and <b>Distal Fragments</b>}}	"<img src=""ap_forearm.jpg""><br><img src=""lateral_forarm.jpg"">"								"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/pediatrics/4126/both-bone-forearm-fracture--pediatric?section=cards"">Orthobullets: Both Bone Forearm Fracture - Peds</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/pediatric-trauma/forearm-shaft/22-d"">AO: Pediatric Both Bone Forearm Fracture Fixation Techniques</a>"		"#Ortho::Orthobullets::Peds::Trauma::Forearm::BBFF"

What are the <b>Variable Inneravtions</b> of the <b>ECRB</b>?<br><br><b>{{c1::50}}</b>% <b>{{c2::PIN}}</b><br><b>{{c1::35}}</b>% <b>{{c2::Superficial Sensory}}</b><br><b>{{c1::15}}</b>% {{c2::<b>Radial</b> nerve Proper}}	"<a href=""https://www.vumedi.com/video/kocher-or-kaplan-approach-to-the-lateral-elbow-anatomical-understanding-to-avoid-posterolateral-in-2/"">Kaplan vs Kocher Approach to the Elbow</a><br><br><img src=""kaplan kocher.jpg"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-10 at 8.26.43 PM.png"">"				"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/3068/elbow-kaplan-approach"">Orthobullets: Kaplan Approach to the Elbow</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/proximal-forearm/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Proximal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Elbow::Kaplan"
"What is the&nbsp;<b>POSITION</b>&nbsp;of the Patient when using&nbsp;the <b>Kaplan&nbsp;Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Elbow</b>?<br><br>{{c1::Supine - ABducted Arm on Hand Table}}<br>{{c1::""Sloppy Lateral"" - Bump under Ipsilateral Scapula, Arm draped over Chest}}"	"<a href=""https://www.vumedi.com/video/kocher-or-kaplan-approach-to-the-lateral-elbow-anatomical-understanding-to-avoid-posterolateral-in-2/"">Kaplan vs Kocher Approach to the Elbow</a><br><br>Use <b>STERILE Tourniquet</b> if <b>Proximal </b>Extension expected<br><br><img src=""kaplan kocher.jpg"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-10 at 8.26.43 PM.png"">"				"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/3068/elbow-kaplan-approach"">Orthobullets: Kaplan Approach to the Elbow</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/proximal-forearm/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Proximal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Elbow::Kaplan"
What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Kaplan&nbsp;Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Elbow</b>?<br><br>1. Identify<b> {{c1::ECRB / EDC}} Interval</b> and <b>Bluntly</b> Develop Plane<br>2. <b>Retract&nbsp;</b>{{c2::<b>ECRB</b>}} <b>Radially</b> and <b>{{c2::EDC}}</b> <b>Ulnarly</b> to Expose&nbsp;<b>{{c2::Supinator}}</b>&nbsp;<b>Deep</b><br>3. <b>{{c3::Pronate}}</b>&nbsp;the <b>Forearm</b>&nbsp;to protect <b>PIN</b><br>4. <b>Detach Humeral </b>and <b>Ulnar Heads</b> of the <b>{{c4::Supinator}}</b>&nbsp;to <b>Visualize</b> <b>{{c4::Annular}} Ligament</b> and <b>{{c4::Capsule}} </b>Deep	"<a href=""https://www.vumedi.com/video/kocher-or-kaplan-approach-to-the-lateral-elbow-anatomical-understanding-to-avoid-posterolateral-in-2/"">Kaplan vs Kocher Approach to the Elbow</a><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Kaplan.png""><img src=""A328677_1_En_16_Fig5_HTML.gif"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-10 at 8.26.43 PM.png"">"				"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/3068/elbow-kaplan-approach"">Orthobullets: Kaplan Approach to the Elbow</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/proximal-forearm/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Proximal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Elbow::Kaplan"
What is the&nbsp;<b>DEEP Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Kaplan&nbsp;Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Elbow</b>?<br><br>Incise {{c1::Lateral Annular}} Ligament + {{c1::Capsule}} ANTERIOR to {{c1::LUCL}} Along the <b>Equator</b> of the {{c1::Radiocapitellar}} Joint to Expose the<b> Radial Head</b>	"<a href=""https://www.vumedi.com/video/kocher-or-kaplan-approach-to-the-lateral-elbow-anatomical-understanding-to-avoid-posterolateral-in-2/"">Kaplan vs Kocher Approach to the Elbow</a><br><br><img class=""resizer"" src=""Kaplan.png"">"				"<img src=""Screen Shot 2023-06-10 at 8.26.43 PM.png"">"				"<a href=""https://www.orthobullets.com/approaches/3068/elbow-kaplan-approach"">Orthobullets: Kaplan Approach to the Elbow</a><br><a href=""https://surgeryreference.aofoundation.org/orthopedic-trauma/adult-trauma/proximal-forearm/approach/lateral-approach"">AO: Lateral Approach to the Proximal Forearm</a>"		"#Ortho::Approaches::Elbow::Kaplan"

"What is the&nbsp;<b>Superficial Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Anterior (Smith-Peterson) Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Hip</b>?<br><br>1. Identify <b>Gap</b>&nbsp;between <b>{{c1::Sartorius}}</b> and <b>{{c1::TFL}}</b><br>2. <b>Dissect </b>through <b>{{c2::Subcutaneous&nbsp;Fat}}</b>&nbsp;(avoid&nbsp;<b>LFCN</b>)<br>3. Incise <b>Fascia </b>on <b>{{c3::Medial}}&nbsp;side </b>of <b>{{c3::TFL}}</b><br>4. <b>Detach Origin</b>&nbsp;of <b>{{c4::TFL&nbsp;}}</b> off <b>{{c4::Iliac}}</b> to develop <b>Internervous Plane</b><br>5. <b>Ligate</b> the {{c5::<b>Ascending branch</b> of the <b>Lateral Femoral Circumflex</b> artery}}&nbsp;(<b>Crosses Gap</b> between <b>Sartorius</b> and <b>TFL</b>)<br><div><div><div><div>

"What is the <b>DEEP&nbsp;Surgical Dissection</b>&nbsp;used<b>&nbsp;</b>during&nbsp;the&nbsp;<b>Anterior (Smith-Peterson) Approach</b>&nbsp;to the&nbsp;<b>Hip</b>?<br><br>1. Identify <b>Plane</b> between <b>{{c1::Rectus Femoris}}&nbsp;</b>and <b>{{c1::Gluteus Medius}}</b><br>2. <b>Detach {{c2::Rectus Femoris}}</b>&nbsp;from <b>BOTH</b> its <b>Origins</b><br>3. <b>Retract {{c3::Rectus Femoris}}</b> and <b>{{c3::Iliopsoas}} Medially</b> and <b>{{c3::Gluteus Medius}} Laterally</b> to<b> Expose</b> the <b>Hip Capsule</b><br>4. <b>{{c4::ADduct}}</b> and <b>{{c4::Externally Rotate}}</b>&nbsp;the <b>Hip</b> to Place the <b>Capsule</b> on <b>Stretch</b><br>5. <b>Incise Capsule</b>&nbsp;with a <b>{{c5::Longitudinal}}</b> or <b>{{c5::T-shaped}} Capsular Incision</b><a><br>6. <b>Dislocate Hip</b>&nbsp;with<b> {{c6::External Rotation}} </b>AFTER <b>Capsulotomy</b> is Complete</a><div><div><div><div>
